webTitle: Riots, crime and chaos ... welcome to London 2025

fields.headline: Riots, crime and chaos ... welcome to London 2025
fields.trailText: Riots will be commonplace, high crime levels perceived as normal and ghettos familiar norms in the London of 2025, according to a respected urban planner in a new book that will be digested by mayors from the world's major cities who meet to discuss future city growth today.
fields.body:
Riots will be commonplace, high crime levels perceived as normal and ghettos familiar norms in the London of 2025, according to a respected urban planner in a new book that will be digested by mayors from the world's major cities who meet to discuss future city growth today.

Unemployment will be concentrated in low-quality inner-city areas. A semi-permanent educational underclass has evolved. More deprived young adults take to hard drugs, becoming permanently detached from regular employment and social aspiration.

The affluent move out to safer, more attractive areas, where social disruption risk is lower. Increasingly, old age means poverty for those unable to save. Old people will again become dependent on their families, who may be reluctant to shoulder the bur den. This is the prediction of Sir Peter Hall, of University College, London, in a book published today called Urban Future 21, which looks at the potential of the world's larger cities in this century.

Today the mayors of the big cities meet in Berlin to discuss mutual problems and how to avoid Sir Peter's gloomy predictions coming true. A world commision on the future of the large urban centre was appointed to prepare for the conference of politicians and planners this week. Sir Peter, a planning adviser to the government, was the moderator.

In his book written jointly with Ulrich Pfeiffer, of Empirica in Germany, Professor Hall said that three out of five of the world's population will live in cities by 2025 - around 5bn people.

His vision for London with growing social divisions is a blueprint for all the mature cities in western style democracies in Europe, North America and Japan, unless radical action is taken to prevent the gradual decline into anarchy. He paints an equally depressing picture for developing countries, where people will be even more grindingly poor, and without basic services of any kind.

Wealth as well as poverty causes problems. The growth of the number of vehicles in cities not built or equipped to deal with them will be crippling. The number of cars in the developing world was 111m in 1995. By 2020 it will more than double to 283m and the total number of vehicles will climb to 580m.

Growth rates of cities are already enormous but those in the developed world are not expected to grow much more. Tokyo at 26m in 1995 will only reach 28m in 2015. By contrast Bombay will go from 15m to 27.3m and Karachi from 9.8m to 20.6m in the same time.

Urban Future 21, Spon £19.99.

webTitle: Blair to propose 48-hour shutdown for rowdy pubs in summit on lawlessness

fields.headline: Blair to propose 48-hour shutdown for rowdy pubs in summit on lawlessness
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today extend his crackdown on lawlessness by discussing the possibility of police powers to shut down rowdy pubs that lead to town centre violence.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today extend his crackdown on lawlessness by discussing the possibility of police powers to shut down rowdy pubs that lead to town centre violence.

A range of measures to stamp out drunken hooliganism will be on the agenda when chief constables meet the prime minister and the home secretary, Jack Straw, at No 10.

Among them will be powers to allow a senior police officer to shut a pub on the spot for up to 48 hours if there is a threat to public safety.

Courts may also be able to impose orders prohibiting known troublemakers from going into pubs, with life bans for the worst offenders.

The announcement of this crime initiative, which has been heavily trailed, follows an angry and sceptical reaction to Mr Blair's proposal of on-the-spot fines for Saturday night hooligans.

His proposal, made to an audience of students during a visit to Germany on Friday, was greeted with dismay by supporters of civil liberties.

The radical QC Michael Mansfield said it made the police "judge and jury to fine people on the spot".

The The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, described the idea as "daft". He said on BBC1's Breakfast With Frost: "How are the police actually going to operate that?

"They are not enamoured of this idea of where they're made judge and jury at one and the same time, as well as being the police."

Today's violent crime summit at Downing Street comes as figures indicated a rise in insurance claims for countryside crime.

The insurance firm NFU Mutual said the cost of thefts from homes and businesses in the countryside rose by 6% in 1999, to £168m. However, the cost of equipment and vehicle thefts from farms fell from £93m in 1998 to £82m last year.

NFU Mutual suggested this showed farmers had become more security conscious, but the message had not filtered through to homeowners and businesses.

Meanwhile, Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation, warned yesterday that "chaotic scenes" in town centres were certain to increase unless more investment was poured into policing. "We are seeing less police than we used to have. The government is looking for ways to improve the situation without spending too much more money," he told Sky News.

He called for "some investment in the system" in technical support and the number of officers.

"We are living in a pretty violent place. Lots of our towns and cities during certain times are pretty tough."

Mr Broughton applauded the "much more visible policing presence in New York" compared with the UK. "There are a lot more cops in New York than there are in London, comparatively. In American culture, police take people off the streets and lock them up because of their behaviour.

"That certainty, that police are going to act, is not there at the moment in the UK." Mr Broughton also warned that retaining good police officers was proving difficult.

"At the moment we are not getting the numbers and quality of people coming through the recruitment system. We are losing more than we are recruiting in London, it's a major problem. "It is about pay, the attitude towards the police service; and we need to work pretty hard to improve that."

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Are the Asian tiger economies still in trouble?
fields.body:
Are the Asian tiger economies still in trouble?

It is three years this week since the Thai government devalued the baht, triggering the financial and economic crisis which swept through Asia in the summer of 1997.

The crisis led to a slowdown in world trade, a collapse in commodity prices which hit all the developing world and contributed to the financial wobbles the following summer precipitated by Russia's debt default.

Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand have bounced back quickly, despite catastrophic collapses in output at the height of the crisis. Indonesia's economy shrank more than 13% in 1998, and Thailand's more than 10%. By the following year they were all growing again and growth this year is expected to be between 4% and 6%.

What caused the crisis?

Reckless lending by western investors - accustomed to high returns from the economies of the so-called Asian miracle - combined with poor investment decisions by local banks meant that companies in the region had built up large amounts of dollar-denominated short-term debt. Poor regulation disguised the extent of their indebtedness until it was too late. A property company failure in Bangkok early in 1997 sparked the first doubts about whether the investment boom was sustainable.

Once overseas investors started withdrawing their money, the governments quickly used all their reserves attempting to defend their currencies. That in turn caused the value of foreign debts to balloon.

How was the crisis checked?

The International Monetary Fund stepped in - but it demanded higher interest rates and fiscal austerity measures. Malaysia experimented with capital controls to stop the flight of foreign investment.

Meanwhile, currency depreciations made Asian goods much cheaper in world markets, enabling countries to export their way to recovery. The Fund changed its tune when it saw that austerity was not working and allowed crisis-hit countries to run into deficit.

Why have they recovered so quickly?

The key factor, according to Gerard Lyons, chief economist at Standard Chartered, has been the continued buoyancy of the world economy. The American economy in particular has sucked in imports from the rest of the world, keeping Asia afloat in the process.

Since last year, the region's economies have been on the mend, supporting each others' recoveries. Governments are using public spending to stimulate demand. Before the crisis, most countries in the region had a surplus of tax revenues over spending, now most are running demand-boosting deficits.

So is the crisis all over?

The effects linger on. Unemployment is still much higher than before the crisis. Foreign banks are reluctant to lend, forcing companies to raise money locally.

As growth has rebounded, structural reform has slowed. There are still a lot of debt-laden firms in the region, particularly in Thailand which has been slow at tackling restructuring. Overall foreign debt levels remain worrying high, particularly in Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia. The final problem in the region is Japan, the sick man of Asia. Its woes began before the crisis hit the rest of the region - and unlike the others it still shows no sign of recovery.

fields.headline: Funds draw up ethical code
fields.trailText: A group of leading fund managers is drawing up an informal City code on social responsibility reporting. Legislation coming into force today requires trustees to say whether they take social, environmental and ethical matters into account.
fields.body:
A group of leading fund managers is drawing up an informal City code on social responsibility reporting. Legislation coming into force today requires trustees to say whether they take social, environmental and ethical matters into account.

Leading insurers and pension funds will put pressure on companies to improve social and environmental standards and teams of ethical analysts have been hired to research the information.

Gavin Grant, managing director for social responsibility practice at the public relations firm Burson Marsteller, said companies had to take social responsibility seriously. The issue would "directly affect their corporate and brand reputations, commercial success and share price".

Fund managers are developing a standard approach to disclosure which will be finalised in the next few weeks. It will lay down issues on which companies should report, including labour standards, community activity and energy use, and how they should be reported.

PricewaterhouseCoopers has advised on the ethical reporting code. John Browne, a director of its reputation assurance practice, predicted that within a couple of years FTSE 100 companies would routinely provide social and environmental information alongside financial data.

Amnesty International has published a guide to human rights for trustees while Friends of the Earth is starting to scrutinise the top 100 pension funds on ethical issues.

webTitle: Dentistry firm to say it with a smile

fields.headline: Dentistry firm to say it with a smile
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A dentistry company, Oasis Healthcare, is raising £5.3m in an AIM flotation to fund plans for a national network of more than 100 surgeries.
fields.body:
A dentistry company, Oasis Healthcare, is raising £5.3m in an AIM flotation to fund plans for a national network of more than 100 surgeries.

The company already owns 14 surgeries employing 58 dentists mainly in the Midlands. It hopes to persuade Britons of the virtues of having cosmetic work done on their teeth.

Malcolm Hughes, the chief executive, said: "Dentistry is not just about clinical efficiency but about something crucially important to people - their smile."

Americans routinely paid for improvements to their teeth, regarding dentistry as just another consumer purchase. This attitude had yet to reach Britain. "We don't see a smile as something we can buy in, whereas in the US they do."

Oasis was founded four years ago by a dentist in the north of England but ran into trouble because of a lack of financial backing. New management took over in 1998 and Mr Hughes, a former managing director of Vernons pools, was appointed earlier this year. The business floated on Ofex early last year. It is likely to be valued at more than £11m on AIM.

Mr Hughes believes underfunding in the national health service is making life difficult for independent dentists. Many want to join larger organisations, to save money on purchasing equipment and to pay for marketing campaigns advertising cosmetic work.

Oasis says just under half of British adults visit their dentists less than once a year and only 45% are registered with NHS practices. Although many of Oasis' surgeries offer NHS work, the group hopes to take advantage of a trend towards the private sector.

webTitle: Had a nice day at the office, dear?

fields.headline: Had a nice day at the office, dear?
fields.standfirst:
British workers are much misunderstood, says a new survey. Not even their nearest and dearest really know what they do. Claire Phipps reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: British workers are much misunderstood, says a new survey. Not even their nearest and dearest really know what they do.
fields.body:
Ignorance is bliss, they say. Why else, when casual acquaintances ask how work is going, would we brush off the question with a casual "fine, thanks" when inside we're seething because the boss lost her temper, there were no envelopes left in the stationery cupboard, the ball disappeared from your computer mouse and . . . oh never mind, you don't want to hear my troubles; how was your day?

But if it's true that no knowledge is a wonderful thing, then - according to a poll last week by secretarial recruitment agency Office Angels - we should be a very happy nation of workers indeed: 63% of British workers believe their friends and family are totally (and blissfully?) in the dark when it comes to what they do at work. So why then were 54% of those who took part in the study annoyed that those closest to them often make wildly inaccurate assumptions about what they were getting up to between the hours of nine and five? (The fact that they think you work only between nine and five being just one irritation.)

"Our work is an important part of defining who we are," says Dr Malcolm Higgs, who works in the HR and organisational behaviour facility at Henley Management College. "Shared understanding of each other's jobs provides a basis for better understanding of each other's moods and behaviour. This in turn can provide a basis for a richer and more enduring relationship."

Judging by the 72% of the respondents who claimed that their parents were ignorant of their working life, a bit more shared understanding wouldn't go amiss. Even partners fail the basic test: 45% of those surveyed thought that their loved one would be incapable of reeling off an accurate job description. Worse than not knowing what you do in the office, though, is assuming - wrongly - that they do. Sixty per cent of workers claimed that friends and family were under the impression that they were always in meetings (easily solved: think of a different excuse not to answer their phonecalls).

Infuriating, too, were assumptions that the job was well-paid, glamorous, involved travel and was not particularly stressful. Would office workers be less frustrated if friends believed them to be hard-working, underpaid and chained to a desk overflowing with "to do" memos? A swift eavesdrop around any pub after hours will reveal table upon table of disgruntled employees battling to outdo each other in the "overworked and under-appreciated" stakes. It's a much-used prerogative to moan about one's job. That's not to say that we don't have cause for complaint: a recent study of working habits confirmed that the UK has the fastest growing work burden in Europe and that two in five of us feel that our jobs require us to "work very hard". And we want our friends and family to realise it too.

"Clearly it is very important for us to talk to friends and family about what we have done in the day, and seek advice and praise," says Paul Jacobs, corporate communications director at Office Angels. "Jobs are so varied these days that it is often difficult for people to comprehend totally what others do, but by taking the time to really listen they could help their partners get things off their chests and offer good solid advice."

Secretly, it seems, we'd all like to think that we work harder than our friends. Maybe we'd like their thoughts on our job to be a little more secret, too: a third of respondents to the Office Angels poll cited "blank expressions" and "non-committal nodding" as proof that their tales of office life were not keeping the listener amused. "Everyone must remember that this understanding is a two-way process," insists Jacobs. So the blank-faced nodders out there might like to start practising a more animated expression. And those who love to share their working day with friends, get ready. You think your job's bad? You're about to hear a lot worse.

fields.headline: From secretaries to success stories
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It could be you. There have, after all, been two winners this week alone: Liz Barker, just announced as the latest Blue Peter presenter, and Emma Jones, who today starts her job as deputy Bizarre editor at the Sun. Both success stories started out as - you guessed it - secretaries.
fields.body:
It could be you. There have, after all, been two winners this week alone: Liz Barker, just announced as the latest Blue Peter presenter, and Emma Jones, who today starts her job as deputy Bizarre editor at the Sun. Both success stories started out as - you guessed it - secretaries.

So just how easy is it to make the transition from secretary to star? And are the skills you've learned as a PA likely to be of any use when you're so high up the ladder that you have a personal assistant of your own? Most definitely, claims Barker, who says many of her communication skills were learned during her time as a receptionist for programmes including Time Watch and Paddington Green. But she is modest about her career move into TV presenting, putting it down largely to chance. "I'm still recovering from the shock of discovering I got the job, as it is a mystery to me how my show reel appeared at the Blue Peter office," she explains. "The first I knew of the job was when I had a call inviting me to audition. It's one of those stories that you think will never happen to you. I still can't believe it."

Emma Jones, on the other hand, saw starting out as a secretary as the perfect way to network - which is ultimately what you need to do if you want to be "spotted". She worked for 18 months on the Evening Leader in north Wales before meeting the violinist Nigel Kennedy, who offered her a job as his PA after a drink. It was then that she began to mix with the big players who would eventually offer her a way into Fleet Street.

"Being a secretary allows you to regularly meet the people who are giving out the jobs. You can earn their respect and get yourself remembered for being efficient and capable. It also allows you to make a huge range of contacts who may come in handy at any given moment," explains Shauna Horgan, vice president of the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services. "In secretarial jobs that involve attending social functions, it may sometimes be appropriate to mention in passing your high-flying future career plans."

Best-selling author Jilly Cooper spent eight years as a secretary before landing the column on the Sunday Times that led to her career as a novelist. Although she claims her secretarial career was "a nightmare because I was so bad," she does admit that it taught her to show herself as a dedicated and hard worker to people who mattered. "It is ridiculous when secretaries won't buy birthday presents for their boss," she says.

Mind you, warns careers adviser Juliette Matthews, nor should you let yourself be taken advantage of or you'll be in danger of never passing Go. "It's a fine line," she admits. "You need to show that you're willing to muck in and do the lowly jobs every now and then but that, in return, you want to be involved in some of the juicier projects. This is particularly important since secretarial work is recognised as being far higher status than it used to be."

Sarah El Doori, of recruitment consultancy Office Angels, agrees: "The key is to show you're pro-active. If you want to be picked out from the crowd, you need to make it clear that you can find solutions to problems - both big and small."

Former PA Anthea Turner claims that she has her secretarial days to thank for her organisational skills. In addition, she believes, it has enabled her to work well with her current PA, Alison Astall, which has made a huge difference to her working life. Perceiving your relationship with your PA as a partnership rather than a power relationship, she says, gives them both a chance to reach their full potential. "What I like about Alison is that she is forthright," said Turner recently. "If she doesn't think something is working, she says so."

Even if you don't get the fame, there's still a hope of getting the fortune. Look no further than Carly Fiorina, once a secretary at the computer company Hewlett Packard, and now its chief executive, earning a reported £50m over three years. Others who have followed in the career trail of Melanie Griffiths in the movie Working Girl - where she moved from PA to principal - include Tina Fotherby, managing director of PR firm The Yes Company, and Ben Hampshire, special effects producer. Both Fotherby, who began in 1979 as a junior secretary on weekly magazines at IPC, and Hampshire, who claims he "could not even type" when he started out as William Hurt's PA, claim total loyalty is essential if you want any kind of high- profile role. Trust is everything, they say, particularly in the media.

"Watch everything and everyone around you like a hawk," adds Richard Smith, manager of a recruitment consultancy who began his career as a clerical worker. "You need to learn as much as possible without actually being taught it. And never assume you have to do the same jobs every day. Take the initiative and think creatively whenever you can." A competitive edge and a fighting instinct won't go amiss either, he adds.

Some secretarial roles, though, - such as those in the legal and medical worlds - have the reputation of hitting the glass ceiling with a thump, leaving no opportunities for high- flyers. "But," says Emma Cummerford, a solicitor from Chesham who began her career as an office junior for a law firm, "although it takes a long time and a lot of hard work to make it in this field, your experience as a legal secretary undoubtedly puts you at an advantage in terms of legal knowledge, jargon and contacts."

Cummerford believes many legal secretaries are put off by the hard slog ahead. Unlike, say, the media, success depends on qualifications rather than talent-spotting. "My degree took me two evenings a week for four years. I then had to leave work to do a one-year full-time college course studying for legal practice, followed by a training contract for two years. But I've come out with a job that is totally secure and extremely fulfilling." Although the prospects are bleaker for medical secretaries who want to become medical practitioners, the British Society of Medical Secretaries is quick to point out that secretaries are increasingly moving into management roles within surgeries and hospitals.

Not surprisingly, recruitment agencies report that graduates are taking up roles as secretaries and PAs faster than ever. "They have realised it's one of the best stepping stones into their chosen career," says Caroline Foote, managing director of recruitment consultants Career Moves. "Many of them - particularly in the media - are seeking top jobs and see this as a way in." They're lucky, she says, because 10 years ago, secretaries required formal training. Now, however, graduates finish their studies and realise they have a good typing speed, impressive knowledge of computer software, admirable communication skills and a good brain - all the things that a modern PA needs. Plus, of course, a generous helping of attitude. Carol Vorderman, eat your heart out.

fields.headline: House work
fields.standfirst:
Sarah Wilkinson is in Notting Hill - not the film but a London estate agency. Nevertheless, image is all, she tells Dolly Dhingra
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sarah Wilkinson is in Notting Hill - not the film but a London estate agency. Nevertheless, image is all.
fields.body:
Madonna lives around the corner, and both Richard Branson and Bill Gates have homes close by - this is London's obscenely trendy Notting Hill Gate, home also to Foxtons estate agents' first branch, established more than 20 years ago. The window is full of beautiful pictures of homes to sell your soul for - and you might need to, with prices ranging from £120,000 for a studio flat to £6m for a mansion.

Inside, a dozen or so young men talk into telephone headsets at a hasty pace that lets customers know that they've got places to go, people to see and hot property to sell. Sales team secretary Sarah Wilkinson, 32, is getting used to the atmosphere, having just completed her three-month probationary period. "I worked at a branch of Rothschilds bank for three years before coming here so I was used to a very corporate environment, very suited, where you have to mind your Ps and Qs. I took voluntary redundancy and was looking for a place that was completely different," she explains.

"I really wanted somewhere a little more dynamic but still a little bit taxing. I want to work hard and still go for a drink with the gang afterwards. I wasn't getting that before - I was the second youngest in the office and here I'm the oldest. I'm older than my two managers, which was a bit of a shock, really," she says.

After leaving school at 16, all of Wilkinson's secretarial skills were learnt on the job - she has an impressive typing speed of 80wpm. "I learnt to type while I was working as a receptionist at a hotel. I picked it up as I went along. I'm naturally quite dexterous," she says. Another secretary at Foxtons' Kensington branch provided the training for this job in an intensive three days.

Wilkinson rarely takes lunch breaks, preferring to get her head down - the greatest challenge in this job, she says, is trying to clear the sheer volume of work. Three months in the job and she can recite the whole estate agent's procedure: "Basically the process of buying and selling a house is very much like a production line. There are very set functions for each stage of the process. It begins with an evaluation and I'll type up the first letter telling a customer how much their property is worth, all about our fees and our marketing policies.

"If they instruct us, we have to get a set of details together which means ordering the floor plans and getting the photographer round there. Pictures are sent to me digitally by email. I collate them and type up the details of the property, then compile a brochure for the client's approval; they have to agree with our terms and conditions and, once everything is approved, the details go in the window. I have to sort out sales memoranda and letters to solicitors and I'll do all the invoicing right up until we receive the cheque," she says, without pausing for breath.

Her office is on the first floor, away from the hubbub of the sales team. "I'm my own person up here. No one is hanging over me. I'm used to having someone looking over my shoulder a bit more, but I'm very much left to my own devices and it helps that I'm very disciplined," she says.

Foxtons has to be very image conscious, with branches in some of the most sought-after locations in London. The image also tends to attract a particular kind of staff, explains Wilkinson. "They have to be the Foxtons personality, which is young, vibrant - they have to have a personality, basically. People who want to work and then go for a glass of wine afterwards. We all work hard and play hard which is exactly how it should be - I'd rather have that then work a little bit and go home bored and miserable. Wouldn't you?"

webTitle: Desktop icons No 26: The paper shredder

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 26: The paper shredder
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Not, of course, a desktop icon at all, unless you work in an office with shamefully few top secret documents in need of destruction. Then you could be content with a piddling shredder which sits alongside the phone and tears your old memos to pieces in the time it would take you to chew and digest them yourself. Clearly this won't do.
fields.body:
Not, of course, a desktop icon at all, unless you work in an office with shamefully few top secret documents in need of destruction. Then you could be content with a piddling shredder which sits alongside the phone and tears your old memos to pieces in the time it would take you to chew and digest them yourself. Clearly this won't do.

No, the paper shredder's raison d'être is to be big, bad and menacing, with the ever-present danger that a stray tie or karma bracelet could be horrifically mangled in its teeth. If it has a high-grade cutting head capable of swallowing the rainforests before they were turned into email printouts, all the better - these days, stuffing documents into a mechanical monster is the only legitimate way to display aggression and other homicidal tendencies in the office.

Those in the know will, of course, look for more technical attributes such as "throat width" and "fpm" (the size of the paper opening and the speed - feet per minute - of the throughput, obviously). These will be the people who, in the mistaken belief that they are Miss Moneypenny, stay late into the night to shred fax cover sheets in a deserted office.

The shredder is not just a weapon of missive destruction. Choose wisely and you will have an instrument capable of shredding paper to the width of "raw fettucine", according to one manufacturer, although it's unlikely that Jamie Oliver would enthuse about the flavour. This has the built-in advantage of being perfect material for packaging fragile objects, although the recipient is unlikely to appreciate your pasta-styled efforts and will instead devote their time to piecing together the strips in the hope of finding confidential information that could bring your company to its knees.

We have lot to thank the paper shredder for. Without it, just think how many important documents could have fallen into the wrong hands. With it, just think how many hands have fallen wrongly into the shredder's jaws.

webTitle: Treasury refuses to drop basic bank account

fields.headline: Treasury refuses to drop basic bank account
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Treasury is warning the high street banks that any support for a new Post Office bank does not let them off the October deadline to provide basic accounts for the "socially excluded".
fields.body:
The Treasury is warning the high street banks that any support for a new Post Office bank does not let them off the October deadline to provide basic accounts for the "socially excluded".

The reminder comes amid confusion about the commitment the government wants from the banks to help tackle the issue of providing financial services facilities to some of the most deprived sectors of the community, already hit by branch closures.

Since the Department of Trade and Industry's announcement last week about the creation of the Universal Bank, offering basic accounts without overdrafts, senior bankers had started to believe that they no longer needed to set up their own version of the accounts through their branches.

But Melanie Johnson, economic secretary to the Treasury, is telling the banks that the October deadline - already brought forward from the end of the year - still stands.

"She is particularly keen to ensure that the socially excluded have basic bank accounts as soon as possible," a Treasury official said, pointing out that most banks already offer such accounts or have promised to do.

An estimated 3.5m people are without basic banking facilities, a factor of particular concern to the government because its plan to channel benefit payments directly into bank accounts by 2003. Lobby groups also point out that, without bank accounts, consumers are deprived of direct debit facilities which can reduce utility bills.

A main plank of the government's policy to tackle finan cial exclusion has been to demand that banks offer basic accounts by October. But the idea to create the Universal Bank had muddied the issue after Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said that if retail banks participated in that scheme it would meet the requirements on social exclusion.

The DTI is hoping the banks will put their financial muscle behind the Universal Bank, which is also part of the government's attempt to help rural post offices survive.

The big banks had already made a commitment to offer basic accounts, from which they make very little profit, by October, albeit reluctantly in some instances.

Some of former building societies, such as Halifax, already offer such accounts and the clearing banks have promised to have their versions ready in time for the deadline.

fields.headline: HSBC cuts mortgage rate
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: HSBC will wade into the mortgage war this morning, cutting its borrowing rate by almost one percentage point as it becomes one of the first big banks to offer a home loan that meets new government requirements.
fields.body:
HSBC will wade into the mortgage war this morning, cutting its borrowing rate by almost one percentage point as it becomes one of the first big banks to offer a home loan that meets new government requirements.

Its government-approved charges access and terms (Cat) mortgage is starting as HSBC introduces a series of "better banking" initiatives. Last week it launched a stakeholder pension and later this week is expected to confirm that all charges for cash machine withdrawals are to be axed.

The moves are made against a backdrop of government concern about the financial services industry, prompted by Don Cruickshank's investigation into competition in the sector.

The mortgage cut will propel HSBC to the top of the "best buy" table of the 10 biggest lenders. The nearest to HSBC's 6.75% standard variable rate is Nationwide building society with 7.74%.

The bank has promised not to allow the standard variable rate to exceed the the Bank of England base rate by more than one point. Customers who borrow more than 90% of the value of their property will pay an extra 0.15 of a point over the standard rate for the first three years.

John Massey, head of mortgages at HSBC, insisted that the move was not just about winning new business because the bank will transfer existing customers to the better rates and terms.

He admitted it was easier for HSBC to make such a move because of its small number of mortgage customers, 300,000, compared with the millions on rivals' books. Also, more than 50% of its home loans are fixed-rate products.

fields.headline: Not out of puff yet
fields.standfirst:
After the death of a woman from asthma, colleagues who smoked face possible prosecution. But can smoking at work ever be stopped? Hilary Whitney reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Last week, a prosecutor in Italy launched an investigation into the death of a bank worker to determine whether her employer and colleagues should be tried for her manslaughter. And their alleged weapon? Cigarettes.
fields.body:
Last week, a prosecutor in Italy launched an investigation into the death of a bank worker to determine whether her employer and colleagues should be tried for her manslaughter. And their alleged weapon? Cigarettes.

Ten months ago, the 35-year-old woman collapsed at her desk in a Milan bank and died of an acute asthma attack. Her family claim that, although the bank was aware that she suffered from the illness - she had been employed under a scheme that gives tax incentives to employers who hire people with physical impairments - she had to work in a badly ventilated room, surrounded by persistent smokers. Her repeated requests to be moved were ignored. The prosecutor must now decide whether those who continued to smoke around her should be charged with her death.

Health and safety legislation in this country has done much to protect the rights of non-smokers, but it is not inconceivable that this might happen in Britain. There are still many workplaces, often small businesses where the boss smokes or where the issue has never been raised, that do not restrict smoking.

However, an increasing number of smoking policies are appearing in the workplace. Quite apart from the health risks associated with smoking - active or passive - many employers are worried about reduced productivity because of smoking breaks, or absenteeism because of ill health. Smoking can also pile on the costs for firms, with extra cleaning and redecoration, special ventilation requirements, separate facilities for smokers and higher fire insurance premiums than for smoking-free premises.

Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) recommends that employers develop a smoking policy in consultation with employees. An employer has a duty to protect staff from harmful substances - and that includes tobacco smoke - but imposing a total smoking ban may create new problems: 28% of adults regularly light up, and that's a lot of potentially demotivated workers.

Ash suggests that a successful policy should include a timetable of changes; support for those trying to quit, a decision on whether there will be a smoking room (and, if so, for how long), plus rules on breaks.

Many workplaces that once had designated smoking areas have now opted for a total ban on lighting up in the building. It hasn't solved the problem: instead, smokers tend to congregate around entrances, and non-smokers resent being left to cover for their colleagues.

Two and a half years ago, when non-smoking staff at Harlow council expressed concern at this, bosses implemented a policy by which smokers must make up the time spent on breaks. All staff work under a flexitime arrangement of 37 hours a week and any employee who leaves the building for a cigarette must indicate this on his or her timesheet.

Welwyn and Hatfield council allow staff to smoke in designated areas outside the building and had planned to ban smoking entirely in April this year. However, research showed that the staff members were not adequately prepared to deal with the new regulations and they will be allowed to continue to smoke in those areas until April 2001, when the policy will be reviewed.

Many employers are getting around the problem by offering support to employees who want to quit - from nicotine patches to hypnosis. More help is on the way in the form of Zyban, a groundbreaking anti-smoking pill, which, it was announced last week, is to be available on NHS prescription.

But what about the people who don't wish to stop smoking, but accept that some restrictions are necessary? The Freedom Organisation for the Right to Enjoy Smoking Tobacco (Forest) points out that employers have a duty to ensure the welfare of all employees, including smokers. It points to alternatives such as better ventilation and air-cleaning systems, a compromise which, though expensive, benefits smokers and non-smokers. And those who think it fair to penalise people for cigarette breaks might like to consider the number of non-smokers in any office who have more coffee breaks and personal phone calls than are strictly necessary.

Smoking is a highly emotive issue - it is easy to demonise those who continued to puff away at the Milan bank - but the future does not look bright for smokers. The Health and Safety Commission will shortly be publishing its code of practice on passive smoking and is urging a complete ban on workplace smoking that could come into operation as early as next year. But there are those who doubt that office smoking can be stubbed out. Employers will not want to lose able people simply because they smoke and, while many will be offering smoke cessation therapy, they will also have to accept that some people, whatever the health risks, simply do not want to stop.

Action on Smoking and Health (Ash), tel: 020 7739 5902; www.ash.org.uk

Freedom Organisation for the Right to Enjoy Smoking Tobacco (Forest), tel: 020 7233 6155; www.forest-on-smoking.org.uk
fields.bodyText: Last week, a prosecutor in Italy launched an investigation into the death of a bank worker to determine whether her employer and colleagues should be tried for her manslaughter. And their alleged weapon? Cigarettes. Ten months ago, the 35-year-old woman collapsed at her desk in a Milan bank and died of an acute asthma attack. Her family claim that, although the bank was aware that she suffered from the illness - she had been employed under a scheme that gives tax incentives to employers who hire people with physical impairments - she had to work in a badly ventilated room, surrounded by persistent smokers. Her repeated requests to be moved were ignored. The prosecutor must now decide whether those who continued to smoke around her should be charged with her death. Health and safety legislation in this country has done much to protect the rights of non-smokers, but it is not inconceivable that this might happen in Britain. There are still many workplaces, often small businesses where the boss smokes or where the issue has never been raised, that do not restrict smoking. However, an increasing number of smoking policies are appearing in the workplace. Quite apart from the health risks associated with smoking - active or passive - many employers are worried about reduced productivity because of smoking breaks, or absenteeism because of ill health. Smoking can also pile on the costs for firms, with extra cleaning and redecoration, special ventilation requirements, separate facilities for smokers and higher fire insurance premiums than for smoking-free premises. Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) recommends that employers develop a smoking policy in consultation with employees. An employer has a duty to protect staff from harmful substances - and that includes tobacco smoke - but imposing a total smoking ban may create new problems: 28% of adults regularly light up, and that's a lot of potentially demotivated workers. Ash suggests that a successful policy should include a timetable of changes; support for those trying to quit, a decision on whether there will be a smoking room (and, if so, for how long), plus rules on breaks. Many workplaces that once had designated smoking areas have now opted for a total ban on lighting up in the building. It hasn't solved the problem: instead, smokers tend to congregate around entrances, and non-smokers resent being left to cover for their colleagues. Two and a half years ago, when non-smoking staff at Harlow council expressed concern at this, bosses implemented a policy by which smokers must make up the time spent on breaks. All staff work under a flexitime arrangement of 37 hours a week and any employee who leaves the building for a cigarette must indicate this on his or her timesheet. Welwyn and Hatfield council allow staff to smoke in designated areas outside the building and had planned to ban smoking entirely in April this year. However, research showed that the staff members were not adequately prepared to deal with the new regulations and they will be allowed to continue to smoke in those areas until April 2001, when the policy will be reviewed. Many employers are getting around the problem by offering support to employees who want to quit - from nicotine patches to hypnosis. More help is on the way in the form of Zyban, a groundbreaking anti-smoking pill, which, it was announced last week, is to be available on NHS prescription. But what about the people who don't wish to stop smoking, but accept that some restrictions are necessary? The Freedom Organisation for the Right to Enjoy Smoking Tobacco (Forest) points out that employers have a duty to ensure the welfare of all employees, including smokers. It points to alternatives such as better ventilation and air-cleaning systems, a compromise which, though expensive, benefits smokers and non-smokers. And those who think it fair to penalise people for cigarette breaks might like to consider the number of non-smokers in any office who have more coffee breaks and personal phone calls than are strictly necessary. Smoking is a highly emotive issue - it is easy to demonise those who continued to puff away at the Milan bank - but the future does not look bright for smokers. The Health and Safety Commission will shortly be publishing its code of practice on passive smoking and is urging a complete ban on workplace smoking that could come into operation as early as next year. But there are those who doubt that office smoking can be stubbed out. Employers will not want to lose able people simply because they smoke and, while many will be offering smoke cessation therapy, they will also have to accept that some people, whatever the health risks, simply do not want to stop. fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: "There are some days when all Tom seems to do is have meetings," says Rula Leicos, PA to Tom Tidy, the finance director of Colliers CRE, a large London-based property company. "Some are one-to-ones, others can include up to 17 people, and as his PA I have to arrange pretty much all of them."
fields.body:
"There are some days when all Tom seems to do is have meetings," says Rula Leicos, PA to Tom Tidy, the finance director of Colliers CRE, a large London-based property company. "Some are one-to-ones, others can include up to 17 people, and as his PA I have to arrange pretty much all of them."

Organising meetings can be a tiresome business: trying to pin down several busy people to attend at the same time is not an easy task, but Leicos believes it's imperative to start early. "There are some meetings that happen on a monthly basis all through the year, and in October I will start to organise those for next year. By that stage everyone should have their 2001 diaries but, hopefully, they'll have hardly any appointments in them - so I'll have a clear run at the dates I want."

Most of the meetings are on a more ad hoc basis, however, although she keeps a tight control on her boss's diary. "I've worked for Tom for five years so I know pretty much all the people he deals with and how long meetings take with each individual. I tend to work quite autonomously when organising meetings: if someone calls I'll check the diary and put the meeting in without referring to Tom. I generally know if he needs preparation time before a meeting, and the location of other offices he has to travel to, and then I write everything down and give it to him to make sure he is fully updated."

As well as preparing meetings in advance, Leicos also insists on being thorough. "I do believe that equipment is only as good as the person who operates it. You might send someone an email or leave a message on their voicemail - and I do use both - but if they don't pick up that message, then you've got a problem. If I don't hear back within an hour from internal people I chase them up, either with a phone call or, if I still can't reach them, I go to their desk to check their availability."

All too often it is attendees from outside the company who prove the most problematic, which is why Leicos believes in speaking to them first. "External people may have to travel some distance and are bound to be less flexible than those within the company. I also try to suggest as many dates as possible, rather than just one or two, as that can make things complicated. I then talk to internal invitees as they're more flexible - if I beg enough I can normally get them to move something if it clashes with a meeting I'm trying to arrange!"

Among her varied responsibilities, Leicos always sorts out the meetings first. "I'm lucky in that my boss gives me a lot of different areas of responsibility - I look after the healthcare system for the firm, season-ticket loans, travel warrants and generally help him out with all sorts. But I'll always sort out his meetings and his diary first. Then he knows where he is, what he's doing and can just get on with his work - which in turn means that I can get on with mine."

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst:
Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: • PART TIME, FULL RIGHTS
fields.body:
 PART TIME, FULL RIGHTS

You may not notice anything different in the office this morning, but 400,000 part-time workers certainly will. New regulations on pay and conditions for part-timers came into force on July 1, obliging employers to offer them pro rata the same hourly rates and holidays as full-time workers. Eighty per cent of part-time workers are women; the regulations now allow those treated badly to seek proper redress at tribunals instead of taking the more complicated step of pursuing a sex discrimination claim.

 TOO LITTLE, TOO YOUNG

Ageism has once again reared its head in the workplace, but these days it's the young who feel that their date of birth is holding them back. A report from the Employers Forum on Age and careers consultancy Sanders & Sidney found that almost half the young people questioned felt they had been discriminated against because of age. More than one in four complained that they are considered too young for certain jobs, and a similar number believed they would have to change employers to gain promotion.

 BACK TO WORK

Do you suffer from back problems? The way you sit at your desk could hold the key. A new booklet, Back in the office, gives simple advice on how to improve your working environment and reduce back strains. The charity BackCare, which produced the booklet, says your first step should be to set your chair so that your forearms are level with your desk. Taking breaks so you change your position every 20 minutes will help, as will using a headset if your job involves a lot of phoning. For a free booklet, call 0800 6521110.

 SHORT BREAKS

The pay's bad, but the holiday's great . . . The sector you work in can determine the time off you spend in sunnier climes, according to research from Select Appointments. Workers in property, construction, banking and financial services are among those with an average annual break of 22 days. Work for a food and drink manufacturer, and you'll enjoy 25 days away from it all, but the luckiest are those in publishing and printing, who get an average 26 days holiday a year.

 NO CONFERRING

A venture launches next Monday in London to help conference organisers create more innovative events. 'Event Lab' is part show, part interactive exhibition, and is organised by ILLICO Events, a new one-stop service for meeting planners. Delegates can hear presentations on conference planning and project management, and sample a range of relevant suppliers, from hotels to conference equipment. Free to conference organisers, you can register by calling 01332 285566.

fields.headline: Prog rock for dullards
fields.standfirst:
Radiohead**
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Radiohead**
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
It is "The Best Band In Britain's" first English show in over 18 months and the couple in front of me are rapt. As the five anonymous men onstage bring yet another complex sonic portrayal of some unspecific angst to a close, the couple applaud happily and fall silent. Next to me, a young man, overcome with excitement, lets out a cautious "Whoo!" The couple spin round, pick out the maker of this inappropriate exclamation and sneer in a silent chorus of disapproval. I mean, who lets these people buy tickets for such an event? If they want to get all unnecessary and make noises, then why don't they go to something crass and tasteless, like a rave or something? The barbarian shrinks back into his seat. That'll teach him.

The couple are not alone. Tonight's audience for what I naively imagined to be An Event - possibly even gig of the year - are so timid, lazy and uninspired by their heroes, you wonder if they're really here at all. It's tempting, then, to blame the punters for this damp squib of an evening. But, frankly, you suspect that Thom Yorke and co have got the audience they deserve.

Radiohead release their fourth album, the follow-up to the critically-acclaimed and massively successful OK Computer, at the beginning of October. It is as yet untitled, but rumours suggest it could be called Kid A. They have been playing their first promotional shows in Europe, and are appearing at the RFH as part of this year's Meltdown festival, at the invitation of Scott Walker, the festival's curator. The five - Thom Yorke, Jonny and Colin Greenwood, Ed O'Brien, Phil Selway - perform in front of a stripped-down set and play a selection split roughly between old and new material. As reviews of the European shows suggested, the new songs continue the prog-rock indulgence - sorry - the freewheeling experiment of OK Computer, but seemingly with more pianos and less guitars.

At this point, it's only fair to say that Radiohead are technically superb tonight. They work so hard to push themselves away from the verse-chorus-verse-chorus thrash norm, that you can hear the effort to innovate in each cut-up beat and scrawled twang. But then, their problem is that you can hear the effort. At times tonight, especially in newies Optimistic and the epic of dirge that is In Limbo, it's like being at an Arts Council-funded workshop entitled How To Make Modern Rock. Each detail is present and correct: funk beats that no one could possibly dance to, guitar effects peddles that do everything short of telling jokes, lots of running from one interestingly programmed keyboard to another. It is very clever. It is very dull.

And then there is Thom. His voice is tremulously beautiful on tonight's gratefully received versions of No Surprises and Fake Plastic Trees, the genuine, soulful ballads of everyday trauma from The Bends, from a time way back when Radiohead didn't feel melody beneath them. Elsewhere, Yorke lapses into self-parody, chucking his trademark wail around until the translation of any lyrical gems becomes some sort of alternative parlour game. His performance consists of the odd headshake, a rubbish bit of sarcasm about Tony Blair, and some misanthropic pantomime grinning for the photographers.

Still, as the couple in front would be sure to tell me, this is the cutting-edge of British rock. I'm sure they won't mind if I leave them to it, and go to something crass and tasteless, like a rave or something.

webTitle: So what do you do all day?

fields.headline: So what do you do all day?
fields.standfirst: Most office jobs are confusing and surreal enough to the person actually doing them. Explaining to friends and family exactly what you do all day can cause problems, says Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Most office jobs are confusing and surreal enough to the person actually doing them. Explaining to friends and family exactly what you do all day can cause problems, says Judi James
fields.body:
One of the most mind-numbing, toe-curling, bone-marrow-curdling phrases any self-respecting business person can hear is: "How was your day, then?" This is always part of the traditional partner greeting rituals and is usually offered without one ounce of apparent interest the minute your briefcase hits the hall linoleum.

The stock reply is: "Ok, thanks". And that should be that. But what often occurs is the first bicker of the evening, along the lines of: "Is that all?" followed by a sulk and the comment: "You never tell me anything." But what is there to tell? Jargon becomes meaningless outside the office and so do the jobs we do themselves.

Most office jobs are confusing and surreal enough to the person actually doing them. Having to explain in plain, layman's terms exactly what you did all day could lead to mental exhaustion bordering on brain seizure. How much easier to work in the police force and regale all with the collars you felt during a day on the beat. Or be a lifeguard and describe each life saved in glorious detail.

Supplying your loved one with a photocopied version of your daily to do list, with each item ticked off would hardly help. And relating tales of all the pithy emails that crossed you screen is hardly going to induce laughter either. Recruitment consultants Office Angels have come up with depressing statistics to back this theory up - 45% of workers say their partners are oblivious to what they do all day. Friends rate worse, with 61% of them suffering from job misunderstanding, while parents - the ones who nagged, cajoled and nurtured you into your chosen career - came out worst, with 72% having virtually no idea of their offspring's gainful employment.

Assumptions are rife. 60% of close family and friends think we are always in meetings and 50% that our jobs are glamorous and involve travel. Most shocking of all 35% even have the temerity to believe that their job is more stressful than ours.

Body language is the biggest give-away. It is the blank expressions on their faces while we are talking, or the non-committal nodding that gives their blind ignorance away.

Clearly we are not using effective communication skills when we explain our jobs to our nearest and dearest. We prattle on regardless, imagining their comments, sympathy and advice to be valid while they are - in reality - unsure whether we go out each day to sell insurance and mortgages, break open safes, or sell ice creams in the park.

The answer is easy. All business people can communicate on the one level. Simply employ that same medium to educate your loved ones. Any family gathering will do: Christmas, holidays, a wedding or even a funeral. Set up the PowerPoint and a flip chart and get stuck in. A quick three-hour presentation on "What I do for a day job" should get the message into their addled little brains for once and for all. If that doesn't impress them, nothing will.

webTitle: The mordant wit and melancholy wisdom of Walter Matthau

fields.headline: The mordant wit and melancholy wisdom of Walter Matthau
fields.trailText: • On health: 'My doctor has given me six months to live (following a heart attack) but when I couldn't pay the bill, he gave me six months more.'
fields.body:
 On health: 'My doctor has given me six months to live (following a heart attack) but when I couldn't pay the bill, he gave me six months more.'

 On guilt: 'The Jews invented guilt and the Irish turned it into an artform.'

 On his childhood: 'I started to read Shakespeare out loud when I was a child. It was an escape. The words themselves were music, opera. They just transported you from the mundane, miserable little existence that you had into a sphere of angelic purity.'

 On working with Jack Lemmon: 'I think it's the yin and yang. Lemmon is the little choir-faced boy, always wondering and innocent. I seem to be the world-weary, sophisticated gruff, dour, con-man.'

 On Lemmon again: 'We bring joy and happiness, delight, love and prosperity. I don't work without him. He doesn't work without me... Well, that's not exactly true - he does work without me but it's lousy stuff and he doesn't get paid very well. When we work together, we do good stuff and get a lot of money.'

 When asked what he was going to do with his Oscar: 'It is a very useful doorstop.'

 After losing a bet on the Yankees in 1958: 'I'd lost $100,000. I wasn't drunk, just petrified. I walked out into the sun feeling like a piece of cardboard.'

 After a Hollywood producer complained about one of his performances: 'Well, it was a crappy part in a crappy movie for a crappy studio with a crappy executive. Thank you and good night.'

 When asked in 1976 what his ambition in life was: 'To stay alive and beat the system so I can keep some of the money I've earned.'

 On his wife: 'I don't think I give her enough security. I think there's a lot of bastard in me. I'll hold a grudge too long.'

 On being an actor: 'I don't look like an actor, I could be anyone from a toilet attendant to a business executive. Most people look at me on the street and say, 'Who the hell is that guy? Was I in the army with him?'

fields.headline: Ten years after
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: We couldn't have had Euro 2000 without Italia 90.
fields.body:
They tell a fable in some Latin countries. It concerns a scorpion who asks an otter to carry him across a river.

At first the otter declines, fearing the scorpion will sting him. The scorpion reassures him, saying that they would both die if he did that. Halfway across, though, the scorpion stings. 'Why?' asks the dying otter, reminding him of his remark that they would both die. 'Because,' replies the scorpion, 'it's in my nature.'

The tale sprang to mind watching Italy in the semi-finals of Euro 2000. They were spiteful, occasionally cynical, bent on destruction of the Dutch rather than any consistent creation of their own. And they defended magnificently. Amid the festival of attacking football that had been the tournament previously, the Italian nature had reasserted itself. Ends and means.

A night earlier, the Portuguese had gone out kicking and screaming at the award of a late but valid penalty against them, brilliantly spotted by the Slovakian linesman. It was another example, though in a different way to the Italians', that for all the new interpretations of rules and fair-play exhortations, the emotional spontaneity of the game still defies attempts to turn it into mere sanitised showbiz.

It was 10 years ago this month that the game changed. After an indisciplined, low-scoring and often ugly World Cup in 1990, Fifa decided that the cloggers and cheats had had their day. Uefa followed suit in Europe, sickened by the premature retirement of the elegant Dutch striker Marco Van Basten after Serie A 's campaign of sniping at his precious ankles.

His demise heralded the most important revision - the outlawing of the tackle from behind. With the more frequent use of the yellow card, and consequent suspensions, for physical crimes and verbal misdemeanours, the game opened up. The rule forbidding goal keepers from picking up back-passes was also instrumental.The World Cups of '94 and '98 were staging points in the progress. Before last Wednesday, Euro 2000 seemed the logical, beautiful conclusion of the process.

Then came semi-finals which proved again how often in sport tension can stiffen sinews and stifle noble intent at the prospect of the prize's proximity. And which proved that the game still has some way to go to achieve its goals of sportsmanship and just reward for the constructive rather than the destructive.

The irony will not be lost that Italia 90 was the setting for the turning point. While the country itself hosted a memorable tournament, healthily besotted as it is with the game seemingly across every strata of society, its football was based on boa-constrictor defence. But having lost a penalty competition to Argentina in the semi-finals then, they will now care little that a decade on they have won one to reach a final.

Besides, there must remain a fascination for, and admiration of, good defenders at work. It is a delight to see an artist like Zinedine Zidane opening up a game; it can be also be absorbing to watch a craftsman like Alessandro Nesta closing one down. Football is not basketball, not simply high-scoring razzmatazz. Its dominant appeal remains in the fact that it is difficult to score, not that it is easy. It is about a contest of wills and contrasts of styles.

Professionals having time to think and opportunities to implement, they will continue to find ways of stretching the laws. While, say, Claudio Gentile's terrible treatment of Diego Maradona in the 1982 World Cup could never happen again - hopefully, thankfully - new practices have emerged despite the clean-up.

There is still too much diving, feigning injury and shirt-pulling - a response that usually invites more leniency than the tackle from behind but can be equally cloying, defensively - going on, for example. And there must soon be a card to differentiate between the minor offences and such sly but dangerous 'tackles' as Gheorghe Hagi so damagingly inflicted on Antonio Conte.

That the tournament has been such a spectacle is due in no small measure to some brave and sympathetic refereeing by fit, vigorous athletes in their own right. It must be a double-edged emotion for Pierlugi Collina to see Italy reach the final. He set the appropriate tone by awarding a shirt-tugging penalty for Holland against the Czech Republic, then continued it by using the yellow card only after an hour of his quarter-final when France and Spain threatened to undermine their best efforts with indiscipline. He would have been good for the final.

Therein lies a lesson for the Premiership. When referees relaxed their approach in the domestic game at the start of this year, players responded like released juvenile delinquents. In Holland and Belgium, they have largely reacted - except perhaps the wilful, self-destructive Yugoslavs and, though more cannily, the Italians - like mature adults to liberalised pub hours.

What else should the English game take from this tournament? The 10-year theory applies. Sir Alf Ramsey once declared Martin Peters to be 10 years ahead of his time. This tournament has shown the national team and the thugs of its following to be 10 years behind, on and off the field. It is time to play catch-up.

It has been noticeable how the best of teams comprise players who are footballers, not just doers of jobs. Francesco Toldo may have been the best goalkeeper of the tournament, but Fabien Barthez has shown himself a starter of play. The French full-backs, too, are links in the smooth transition of defence from attack.

Then the Dutch. Against Italy, rightly sensing that their opponents' attacking ambition would be limited, they chose - admittedly mainly due to injury - midfield players as full-backs in Paul Bosvelt and Giovanni Van Bronckhorst. It was an acknowledgment of an enlightened Ajax system that has youngsters being rotated positionally so that they do not grow up pigeonholed and limited, unlike often in England where the big kid becomes a centre-half. France now show it too. What would have become of Patrick Vieira in this country?

It is also noticeable how the French, everybody's favourite team, resemble what Arsène Wenger is trying to achieve at Arsenal; solid central defenders at ease with the ball, raiding full-backs, midfield shield, a playmaker and swift striker, switching comfortably from 4-5-1 to 4-3-3. Surely there are enough Englishmen to emulate that.

Of the several reasons advanced against Wenger as a potential England coach this past week has been that, more and more, he fills these positions with overseas players. But given the best English ingredients, he could reasonably be expected to recreate the potion. Then, it is pointed out that none of the major footballing nations has ever employed a 'foreign' coach. When will the country wise up to the fact that, in international terms, it is no longer a major footballing nation?

In addition, Wenger has the knack of attracting the best when young and making them better. It is not the number of overseas players that blights the Premiership - financially a soft touch and looking likely to get softer - but the absence of quality in many of them. How sad that it hounds out a young talent like Savo Milosevic with the best yet to come, but welcomes the ageing whose best days are behind them. And what the fate in this tournament of the uninspired Scandinavians so prevalent at home?

Who knows, an appointment such as Wenger might even turn a tide of xenophobia that so curses the worst of the English. Long shot, but worth a try. The lesson for those has been how joyfully, colourfully to support a team without phoney, cowardly machismo.

So what of tonight's final? Most will hope that the French joie de jouer prevails over the Italian spoilers. They have more in common than might be thought, though. For all their individual talents, there is linkage to the French style, almost alien to disparate England. The same applies to Italy's chain of defensive command.

Should the scorpion sting the sleek otter, put it down to football's capacity to show organisation over ingenuity not necessarily to be a dirty concept. The French showed it themselves in the '98 World Cup final against Brazil, after all. And put it down to an uplifting, Euro 2000, warts-and-all, being a staging post in the game's development.

fields.headline: Italy's case for defence
fields.trailText: They're all from Serie A but it's the B's that count for Italy's back four - bottle, belief, brains, backbone, brinkmanship and brotherhood
fields.body:
Let us now praise infamous men, or: eleven reasons why Italy are still standing, and damned well deserve to be.

Bottle

It was in these very pages, only a week ago, that the word 'cowardly' was used to describe this Italy team. Yes, love is blind, whether for England or for Orange, but it need not give rise to invective. Cowardice does not triumph over a host team fresh from scoring six goals in their previous game. Cowardice does not enable a squad to hold scoreless the tournament co-favourites while playing a man down for 90 minutes. It was appalling to hear Barry Davies, Trevor Brooking and Alan Hansen raving on about how Italy not only did not deserve to win, but how their very existence as a national side threatened to destroy the game as we know it. Just who are the cowards, chaps: Toldo? Nesta? Cannavaro? Maldini? Iuliano? Conte? Albertini? For the final, try getting your heads out of the sand and take note of what is actually happening on the field, instead of pretending you're seeing what you wish you could see.

Belief

In themselves. They always thought they'd reach the final, and the force of this collective belief insulated them from the cries of carping critics, who demanded they be a team they are not. All 22 are veterans of Serie A, which means they face maximum pressure every week. It also means they've come to know and respect one another, as players and individuals. Each member of the squad not only believes in himself, but in his team-mates, and no leap of faith is required: only the knowledge acquired through the shared experience of the ferociously rigorous Serie A campaign. They can be likened to the US Marines: the impossible we'll do today; the inconceivable might take a little longer.

Brains

They read the game. They play with intelligence. They know their limitations as a group and they adapt. They adapt also to the ever-changing circumstances of a match with an elegance so subtle it often goes unnoticed. When Herbert Spencer wrote about 'the survival of the fittest' he was not referring to mere physical stamina, but to the Darwinian ability to cope with new challenges and to withstand perils to which others succumb. A surprising number of these Italian players - Toldo, Nesta, Cannavaro, Ferrara, Iuliano, Maldini, Di Livio, Albertini, Conte, Fiore, Zambrotta, Montella, Del Piero, at the least - are also highly intelligent, knowledgeable, and quick-thinking individuals off the pitch. These mental attributes can be seen in their play, collectively and individually, and their decisive advantage over most opponents in this department has remained unsung for far too long, as tinpot jingoists blather on instead about their perceived histronics.

Background

Seven members of the Italy squad come from Juventus, four from Milan, four from Roma, two from Lazio, two from Fiorentina, and one (who happens to be Cannavaro) from Parma. This is Oxford and Cambridge, and Harvard and Princeton. These are the strongest of the clubs in Serie A. They are winners, and the players chosen from among them have winning as their most significant common denominator: the desire to win, the knowledge of how to do so, and the experience of having done so with great consistency. Not an Everton, Middlesbrough, Fenerbahce, Salamanca, Wolfsburg, Nagoya Grampus Eight, or New York-New Jersey Metrostar alumnus to be found.

Backbone

'Their resilience drew gasps of admiration... a remarkable feat of courage and endeavour... Those who expected Italy to crack under pressure do not know their football... awesome, all were giants... more than heroic... generosity of spirit... discipline, organisation and composure... refusing to be overrun...' Those were just a few of the comments in the British press on Friday. One would hope that the BBC biddies might read and learn, instead of continuing to ooze their unctuous inanities. No Italy team had ever won all three first-round matches in a European Championship or World Cup. Eight goals scored, two conceded to date. Not counting the Sweden match, which was really just a friendly, because Italy already were through, they've taken 24 corners and conceded 28. Hardly the mark of a team forever terrified to go forward. And before the semi-final, they had acquired only three yellow cards in four matches, hardly indicative of a team so eager to bring the game into disrepute.

Back four

As in Nesta, Cannavaro, Maldini and Iuliano. One can quibble about formation and say Italy sometimes use three at the back with Maldini in midfield, but the captain has been, is, and always will be first and foremost a defender, and one who personifies backbone, brains and belief in every match. Nesta and Cannavaro, meanwhile, have become the strongest interior defensive pair in the world, with the unfailing ability, shared by their team-mates, to rise to the level the occasion demands. Iuliano, inserted among them, has consistently found ways to make himself useful. This foursome not only shut down the Dutch physically (Patrick Kluivert will be a long time peeling the shadow of Nesta from his back), but psychologically as well. It was the neurotic and brittle co-hosts who lost both their nerve and their verve in the face of Italy's absolute defensive intransigence.

Balance

Responsibilities are distributed among all, and willingly accepted. Del Piero and Totti may often seem to play the role of prima donna, but they don't have to be told twice to get back and defend. With Vieri lost to injury, and having chosen (unwisely, in my opinion) to bypass Roberto Baggio, Zoff found himself without the players who had between them scored seven of Italy's eight goals in the World Cup of two years ago. Just as you can only beat the team you're playing, as Gary Lineker has pointed out, you can only play the cards you're holding in your hand. Without a proven striker of international calibre, without any creativity or even pace in midfield (only the untested Fiore being a possible, sporadic exception) Zoff had no choice but to put the bulk of the weight on the shoulders of his defenders. But is this noxious 'negativity' or merely common sense?

Brinksmanship

The outlandish is commonplace in Italy, hysteria the only rational response to the cruel vicissitudes of fate. Undeniably, Italy have a flair for the dramatic, even if their tactical approach demands the mundane. This causes them to make hard work of easy tasks (see their classic qualifying home and away draws with Belarus), and to become energised and focused only when the high wire on which they're standing starts to tremble, and they see there's no net below. Italy were stronger with 10 men against Holland than with 11, because the 10 felt once again that they had suffered an injustice, and it's the sense of grievance, even more than espresso, that really makes the Italian juices flow.

Brotherhood

They are not simply a team, they are a family. Ron Atkinson has cogently remarked that among the other reasons France are so strong is that, 'they trust each other with the ball'. This Italy team would trust each other with their lives, not to mention their wives. Which side stood as one, each with an arm around the next man's shoulder, during the penalty phase on Thursday? Which side's substitutes were standing at the end of the match, instead of slumping sullenly in solitary fashion, not even wanting to look at one another, much less hug? The desire to love one another is in their genes, and shared tribulation brings it to the fore. This is by now not so much a football side as a combat-hardened infantry platoon, with an esprit de corps the other teams simply never managed to achieve. 'We have only each other to blame,' say the Dutch. While unbeaten Italy go into the final united against adversity, against a world that refuses to take them seriously.

Bloodlines

They all come from thoroughbred stock, but especially for the defenders history has provided an abundance of role model defenders: Burgnich, Facchetti, Gentile, Cabrini, Ferri, Bergomi, Baresi. The best defenders are revered in Italy to a degree that only profligate scorers experience elsewhere. And, over an extended tournament, class will tell. Every player on the Italy team is aware of who has worn the blue jersey before him, and considers his selection to have been the highest honour possible, while with some other squads it was hard to avoid feeling that the tournament seemed like nothing more than than a frustrating delay before a holiday.

Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo

Take away the ten above, and Toldo himself would have been enough to have seen Italy merit a place in this final. If he's not the best goalkeeper in the world, I'd be interested in hearing who's better.
