Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo, Toldo Take away the ten above, and Toldo himself would have been enough to have seen Italy merit a place in this final. If he's not the best goalkeeper in the world, I'd be interested in hearing who's better.

fields.headline: Euro 2000: The diary
fields.trailText: Happy Mondays
fields.body:
Happy Mondays

Among the host of football luminaries tonight at the De Kuip stadium, but largely unnoticed, will be Viktor Ponedelnik.

Viktor who? He's the Russian who scored the winner in the inaugural European Championship final 40 years ago. It was on 12 July 1960 that he headed the decisive goal for the Soviet Union in a 2-1 win over Yugoslavia. Ponedelnik instantly entered Soviet football folklore and he became a similar sort of talismanic figure to Geoff Hurst after 1966.

That was partly because the Soviet Union and Russia, like England, have never won a second international trophy. Plus his surname means Monday, so the headline writers had fun trotting out the inevitable Ponedelnik Zabivayet v Ponedelnik - Monday Scores on Monday.

Sadly only five of the XI who played that day are still alive. 'In the Soviet Union, when you finished playing nobody needed you. You were thrown on the street,' he recalls. 'Many of the top [players] were killed. They started to drink, nobody helped them, teams didn't invite them.'

Happily, Ponedelnik is a success story. Forced to quit at 29 in 1966 with asthma, he became a sports journalist and will be plying his trade this evening.

A load of bollards

The British Embassy in Brussels was taking no chance on the trouble front before Euro 2000. With fear of les hooligans anglais rampant in the Low Countries, our men had some security bollards installed around their HQ.

The idea was to deter any potential ram-raiders, which is a major problem there. Sadly, just before the tournament began, a woman angry about the service she had received from diplomatic staff got so annoyed she drove her car at the embassy, getting through the concrete posts and crashing into the front of the building.

Never mind the bollards, as it were. It turned out that someone had under-estimated the distance between these defenders necessary to avoid a catastrophe. 'Yes, yes, I know - just like the England defence against Portugal and Romania,' sighed one weary diplomat.

Shooting stars

It's written in the stars that France will win tonight - on penalties. Says who? Says Raymond Domenech (left), the French Under-21 coach who is also a part-time astrologer.

Before last week's semi-finals Domenech predicted the outcome of the two big games. France's Howard Wilkinson came over all Mystic Meg as he foresaw the future.

'France-Portugal, that will be 2-1 for us, and I've seen a Wiltord goal like a star flying through the night.' Not quite right - Henry and Zidane bagged the goals - but fairly good for openers.

The second match? 'Italy will eliminate Holland but the stars are hesitating between 1-0 and 2-0.' Again, pretty close to what happened.

And what about ce soir ? 'In the final we will win on penalties. I can't tell you much more as the sky is cloudy in Amsterdam where I am studying the question.' Remember Domenech in your prayers if you take his advice and win a bundle.

Passport to deportation

Was Franz Kafka a Euro 2000 police chief? After the Belgian gendarmes's wrongful arrest of hundreds of England fans, it's a fair question.

It now emerges that about 100 of the English 'troublemakers' detained and deported were fans who, arriving at Charleroi railway station before the Germany game, followed the advice of a notice in the station which advised them to leave their valuables there in a safe deposit box.

Some of those who then went outside only to be asked for their passport tried in vain to protest that they had just left it in the station a few yards behind them for safe-keeping. Result: arrest, detention, famous victory missed and deportation back to England.

Well done the Belgian authorities. Anyone who feels mistreated by police at Euro 2000 can contact the Football Supporters Association on 020 8541 3399 or email details to fsa_euro2000@hotmail.com.

Snorting delivery

What chance Zinedine Zidane lifting the trophy tonight - then becoming a postie?

That's what happened to Berry van Aerle, rock-solid right-back in Holland's victorious 1988 European Championship side. Tonight Van Aerle will watch the game at his home in Helmond, near Eindhoven, and then tomorrow morning he will deliver the mail as usual.

Sadly for him, a 13-year career at PSV Eindhoven that included several Dutch league titles and winning the European Cup a few months before the Orangemen's triumph at Munich's Olympic Stadium did not leave him a rich man, unlike team-mate Ruud Gullit.

Forced to retire aged 31 with knee problems, he now works 15 hours a week for the Dutch Mail. In his prime an attacking full-back, Van Aerle has little respect for the way Italy overcame his countrymen last Thursday. 'If this is the way they play in Italy, the Italian stadiums must be half-empty,' he snorts.

fields.headline: France v Italy: the preview
fields.trailText: The general assumption that Italy's presence will make this a disappointing or overly defensive final may be wide of the mark.
fields.body:
The general assumption that Italy's presence will make this a disappointing or overly defensive final may be wide of the mark.

In all probability France v Holland would have proved a more open game, but Italy have enough tournament experience to realise playing for penalties is unlikely to work twice. Although their 10-man rearguard action against Holland was awesome, they actually only got through to the final because the Dutch missed two penalties in normal time, which practically amounts to progress by default.

Italy cannot rely on that happening again, nor can they afford any more dismissals. To have any chance of beating the French, who incidentally happen to be quite good at penalties, Italy will have to score a goal, preferably an early one, and defend it. They have talented strikers in Filippo Inzaghi, Alessandro del Piero and Francesco Totti, but if they leave them stranded too far upfield against France it will be asking for trouble.

An early goal will also be what France are looking for, since it would force Italy to play. French strikers like Thierry Henry and Nicolas Anelka have the pace to trouble Italy's back line, though as Portugal proved in the semi-final, if you defend fairly deep and limit the space for the quick players to run into, even a supply line like Zinedine Zidane can dry up.

Zidane should still be the key figure in the final, however. He is exactly the sort of player the Dutch could have done with in Amsterdam. Holland's creative players were found wanting in the semi-final, but now is the time for the French to show they have that something extra. Already developing an arrogance to match the Germans' at their height, the French are fond of claiming they are the best team in the world, with good reason. Beating Brazil might have been a shock two years ago, but they could probably do it to order now. Italy will not frighten players like Zidane, Didier Deschamps and Marcel Desailly, and France should be capable of holding their nerve to win.

webTitle: Zizou avoids a spot of bother

fields.headline: Zizou avoids a spot of bother
fields.trailText: From Phil Neville's mistimed tackle against Romania to the double Dutch misses in the semi-final, Euro 2000 has been plotted by penalties. And up till now it's been a gripping story, albeit lacking the nervy melodrama of penalty shoot-outs, with the single exception of the Holland-Italy game.
fields.body:
From Phil Neville's mistimed tackle against Romania to the double Dutch misses in the semi-final, Euro 2000 has been plotted by penalties. And up till now it's been a gripping story, albeit lacking the nervy melodrama of penalty shoot-outs, with the single exception of the Holland-Italy game.

Just as unusually, in rewarding the fouled attacker and booking theatrical divers, the referees have got the penalties absolutely right, something which could not be said of some of the players taking them. So far, the tournament has offered examples of the very worst penalties conceivable (the majority taken by Dutchmen) as well as one or two of the very finest.

Matt Le Tissier, who has scored 48 out of the 49 penalties he's attempted, once said that the definition of the perfect penalty is one that goes in.

That was before Zinedine Zidane's penalty against Portugal in last week's other semi-final. Experts have since speculated that had the veteran Portuguese goalkeeper, Vitor Baia, had access to a stepladder and two dustbin lids he would have still been powerless to prevent a goal.

Everything about Zidane's body-shape said that he would aim for the keeper's left-hand corner. Only medical science can explain why he did not dislocate his knee in turning his foot so radically in the opposite direction at the very last instant, to place the ball at speed in Baia's top right-hand corner.

When you see a penalty like that, or indeed Ionel Ganea's more restrained but no less effective effort against England, the idea of missing from the spot seems to belong to another universe, one inhabited solely by Englishman, Dutchman and Italians.

Those three nations have contrived to go out of major tournaments on penalties no fewer than 12 times in the last decade. So a shoot-out between Holland and Italy was destined to be the unofficial decider for the world's worst penalty-takers.

The two sides took very different approaches to their preparation. The Italians appeared to be inspired by the classic penalties of the modern era.

For example, Francesco Totti's neat little chip was obviously a hommage to Antonin Panenka's brilliantly subversive winning penalty for Czechoslovakia in the 1976 European Nations Cup final shoot-out against West Germany.

Whereas the Dutch clearly spent many hours holed-up with a video of Chris Waddle's and Gareth Southgate's greatest spot-kicks. Give credit to Jaap Stam, he had Waddle's fast-bowler run-up off to a T. However, his execution was all wrong. Waddle screwed his 1990 shot no more than a foot over, but Stam seemed to put a least four or five yards between the ball and the bar.

Frank De Boer was far more successful in emulating Southgate, not once but twice. Both his penalty in the first half of the Italian game and the one in the shoot-out were spectacularly feeble, so tame and close to the keeper that only his sudden death could have enabled them to cross the line.

In large part, I think the reason that the Dutch missed five penalties in the semi-final was due to Francesco Toldo, the giant Italian goalkeeper. He seemed to mesmerise the Dutch players so that they were either drawn, like De Boer, to him as if to Black Hole or they went out of their way, and out of the goal's way, to avoid him - like Patrick Kluivert.

Kluivert's miss from the spot in the second half was the most heart-rending because he hit the post and sent Toldo the wrong way. He knows that had his shot been three inches to the right, he would have been hailed as a dead-eyed hero. And of course people would have said he deliberately aimed for the inside of the post.

What would Zidane do against Toldo? The best thing to do would be to ignore him, to remain undaunted by his 6 ft 5in presence. Had the Dutch been able to do that, we should have experienced a classic final today. As it is, it may well come down to penalties, in which case I fancy Zidane to beat Toldo, with or without a stepladder.

fields.headline: Under-fire BBC face radio battle
fields.trailText: They haven't finished yet. Premier League officials who have already sold three packages of TV rights for a handy £1.645 billion over three years still have more goodies to dispense - at a price.
fields.body:
They haven't finished yet. Premier League officials who have already sold three packages of TV rights for a handy £1.645 billion over three years still have more goodies to dispense - at a price.

The revenue raised so far comes from the sale of 66 live games per season to Sky, 40 pay-per-view games to NTL and highlights to ITV. By the end of the year, they will have nudged considerably nearer the £2bn mark that some analysts predicted they would achieve.

The main remaining money-spinner is the overseas rights, then there are the radio and internet deals, and the League's slice of the action after Sky and NTL have sub-licensed the video-on-demand - a recent introduction whereby you can ask for a specific highlights package - and mobile phone rights.

The worldwide interest in the Premier League has been growing throughout the current four-year contract, which gives way to the new three-year deal after next season. At the last count, 142 countries were paying for coverage of Premiership games and this foreign trade is now worth around £32m a year. Based on these figures, the League can expect to net comfortably in excess of a £100m for the overseas rights from 2001-04.

The radio rights, which are sold nationally, locally and in London, are likely to attract the most competitive bidding. At present they are worth a surprisingly modest £9m or so a year, but the arrival of Kelvin MacKenzie's Talksport may see this number multiplied a few times.

The BBC are still getting over the shock of losing television highlight rights to ITV, effectively putting a halt to Match of the Day , and it would be another sickening blow if Radio 5 Live were to have their association with the Premiership ended.

Greg Dyke, the managing director of the BBC, made few friends at the Premier League when he claimed the Beeb had played a significant role in building the Premiership brand through Match of the Day .

The League reckoned this was pretty high-handed stuff considering they were responsible for putting the programme back on to the nation's screens in 1992 and the BBC then played fast and loose with it by switching it back and forth in the schedules and failing to keep hold of Des Lynam.

Whether this will adversely affect the BBC's hopes of retaining radio rights remains to be seen, but, having asked around, I'm inclined to think it won't. The feeling is that, unlike their television counterparts, 5 Live have unquestionably been a positive influence on building the brand, and MacKenzie will have to be at his most persuasive - not to mention his most munificent - if he is to gain the rights.

But, whatever happens, the Premier League will profit.

The BBC's agreement with the Football Association to show England's competitive home matches will not take effect in time for them to screen this autumn's England-Germany World Cup qualifier, which will be exclusively live on Sky.

The return leg, though, in Germany on 21 September next year will be on both Sky and the BBC because the FA have the rights to that match.

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: Transfer rumours for every Premiership club.
fields.body:
FERGIE: YOU WON'T CATCH US

Alex Ferguson has told Premiership rivals: You could spend £100 million and you still won't catch us. 'This team is capable of holding its own momentum,' says Fergie, 'regardless of what others are doing.'

WENGER EYES UP ZIDANE

Arsene Wenger says he wants Zinedine Zidane - but not for £40m. 'I would love to have him here at Highbury but it is not possible. He's the best in the world in his position: in today's market he'd be worth £40m.'

O'LEARY IN £10M EHIOGU SWOOP

David O'Leary has agreed a £10m Leeds package to rescue unsettled Ugo Ehigou from Aston Villa: he'll offer £5m cash plus Michael Duberry.

Arsenal

Arsenal are new favourites to land Nuno Gomes. 'We don't intend to sell him,' says Benfica's Joao Vale e Azevedo, 'but we couldn't refuse an extraordinary offer.' Arsene Wenger is also watching Deportivo star Flavio da Conceicao as a replacement for Marc Overmars, plus Brazilian duo Edu and Edmilson. 'We might take a gamble on them,' says Wenger, 'but it is far from done.'

Aston Villa

John Gregory will be £4m up by the end of the week - Steve Watson is off to Everton for £2m and Mark Draper will sign for Southampton for £1.5m. Benito Carbone could also go: he's officially a free agent as of last night.

Bradford

Geoffrey Richmond says Newcastle have no chance of signing keeper Matt Clarke - but Clarke isn't so sure. 'I know they're interested,' he says, 'and they're a big club.' The deal would mean Des Hamilton moving in the opposite direction.

Charlton

Peter Varney says Charlton are failing to sign players because rival clubs are asking 'crazy' transfer fees. 'It's common knowledge that Charlton have money to spend,' says Varney. 'When everyone knows how much, they ask for crazy money.'

Chelsea

Mario Stanic says he'll be winning medals at Chelsea next season. 'I've won the Super Cup, Uefa Cup and Italian Cup, but I will win more here.' Mikael Forsell, meanwhile, will choose between Bolton and Palace when he returns from holiday.

Coventry

Coventry are chasing Don Hutchison and Niclas Alexandersson. 'I think we have a chance of signing them,' says Bryan Richardson. 'Certainly over the next 14 days we will start to seem some changes.'

Derby

Man Utd have refused to sell Dan Higginbotham. Jim Smith lodged a £1.5m bid last week, but United want to keep their left-sided options open.

Everton

John Collins will join Fulham this week - he'll be replaced by Tranmere's Alan Mahon. Alessandro Pistone, meanwhile, is still surprised by his move to Goodison: 'I had my ups and downs at Newcastle but I'm still surprised they sold me.'

Ipswich

Ipswich look to have beaten Everton and Wimbledon to the signing of John Scales; George Burley also wants Hibs' £2m-rated midfielder Russell Latapy.

Leeds

Peter Ridsdale has ruled out a big money bid for West Ham's Rio Ferdinand - but could sanction the sale of David Hopkin to Bradford or Man City this week.

Leicester

Peter Taylor wants two new goalkeepers to back-up Tim Flowers - and is set to bid for Everton's Michael Ball. 'I rate Michael and I have enquired about him,' says Taylor. 'But there are others I have also asked about.'

Liverpool

Nick Barmby's demand to join Liverpool has infuriated Everton boss Walter Smith. 'They've made an inquiry and he wants to go. It has become an impossible situation.' Sunderland , meanwhile, have denied bidding for David Thompson.

Manchester City

Stoke's John Rudge has denied that Peter Thorne is set to sign for City: 'It's just rumours.' Joe Royle is likely to move for Coventry's Noel Whelan instead.

Manchester United

Martin Edwards has denied a bid for Lazio's Pavel Nedved: 'We haven't bid for him - we haven't even discussed him.' A move for River Plate's Juan Pablo Sorin is, though, on the cards: Alex Ferguson wants the 24-year-old left-back to replace Dennis Irwin. He could also bid for Peterborough starlet Adam Drury.

Middlesbrough

Chris Sutton will choose this week between Middlesbrough and Celtic . 'Chris isn't swinging towards anyone just yet,' says agent John Viola. 'We'll speak to both'. If Sutton signs, it'll mean the end for Brian Deane - Blackburn are keen.

Newcastle

Bobby Robson is set to complete a shock £8m swoop for Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. Robson has already talked down FC Schalke's £12m asking price, and will meet Mpenza this week to discuss terms. He could also be tempted by Barcelona's decision to sell £3.9m-rated Spain captain Josep Guardiola.

webTitle: It's time for players to pick up the bill

fields.headline: It's time for players to pick up the bill
fields.trailText: You have to wonder what the directors of Newcastle United Football Club could do next to alienate themselves from their fans.
fields.body:
You have to wonder what the directors of Newcastle United Football Club could do next to alienate themselves from their fans. Eat their children, perhaps? After Bordellogate and Shirtgate comes Seatgate.

Lord Chief Justice Woolf's ruling in the club's favour last week will allow the club to move 4,000 supporters out of their regular seats to make way for corporate drinkers. What the judge's decision also did was lumber the six supporters who carried the cause to court with legal costs of £198,000. That, says Jane Duffy, one of the 'Save Our Seats' campaigners, could ruin them.

'When this dispute began, we were told by the club that £100,000 would pay the costs of both sides in the action. We raised £118,000 from fans across the country but now Newcastle want £198,000. We still have £80,000 hanging over our heads.

'I can't believe that the club can justify these costs. It seems to me that the club wants blood and that makes me very, very bitter and angry. We have got to find that money from somewhere and if the worst comes to the worst we shall organise sponsored walks from Land's End to John O'Groats and visit every league club in the country to do it.'

There is an alternative solution. Tap up the players. I'm sure Alan Shearer and his £25,000-a-week mates could find some spare change to help the very people whose support sustains their comfortable lifestyles. Indeed, Shearer, who has retired from international football to concentrate on making his beloved club great again, could probably pick up the tab with a fortnight's wages.

Is this unreasonable? The players would say they do not want to get involved, that it is a matter between the fans and the directors, and that the dispute has run its proper legal course. True. Every bit as true as the observation by Justice Woolf that he had no option but to rule against the supporters, 'however sympathetic one may feel towards them'.

But the law and justice are often miles apart. Will the players be moved to close that gap? The anecdotal evidence is not good.

Shearer lives on the Wynyard Hall estate owned by the former chairman, Sir John Hall, as does Kevin Keegan, the former manager. It is said that when he was going to training, the captain would go around to Keegan's place to get a lift to the ground so as to save on petrol money.

This might be totally unfair on Shearer and the other Newcastle players, of course. They might ring up Jane Duffy this morning and put a cheque in the post. Or the club might even write off the legal costs.

Somehow I think there's a better chance of Mike Tyson becoming a vegetarian.

fields.headline: Clubs' five foreigners limit
fields.trailText: As the final curtain falls on Euro 2000, the most memorable football tournament in a generation, The Observer can reveal how football believes it can finally solve one of its biggest problems - the invasion of foreign players widely blamed for the lack of local youngsters coming through.
fields.body:
As the final curtain falls on Euro 2000, the most memorable football tournament in a generation, The Observer can reveal how football believes it can finally solve one of its biggest problems - the invasion of foreign players widely blamed for the lack of local youngsters coming through.

Under the plan - backed by a European Union 'protocol' binding in law - clubs could be forced to field a minimum of six home-grown players and limit the number of foreigners in any side to just five. Crucially, Uefa, which is behind the scheme, believes the European Union is now ready to give it the power to limit the influx of overseas players in this way without breaking existing EU law.

Uefa and Fifa have been working behind the scenes with the French government to devise a scheme that would let them restrict the number of foreigners allowed to feature in any professional team. Football's rulers believe that - with the French having yesterday assumed the EU presidency until the end of the year - they now have a six-month window of opportunity to push through the change.

Yesterday's Uefa congress stressed any changes were dependent on national governments and associations bringing pressure to bear. But, unknown to the Luxembourg congress, the French-inspired plan is already some way down the line.

Uefa have drafted a protocol, obtained by The Observer , which would allow sports' governing bodies to opt out of the otherwise rigid rules protecting freedom of work movement.

The policy, which Uefa believes the EU is set to endorse to protect the emergence of home grown talent in European leagues, would give Uefa the legal right to 'take appropriate steps to ensure that teams participating in the competitions which they organise are properly representative of the national or regional territory in which these teams are based'.

A Fifa spokesman said: 'The French government is sympathetic to sport in general, and football in particular, and we are working together towards a recognition of sport's special status. 'We are quite upbeat about making progress over the next six months.'

Mari-George Buffet, France's sports minister, will help co-ordinate a political lobbying drive to persuade the EU to back the change, although some countries, notably Denmark, are not keen. The EU already accepts that the 1995 Bosman judgment has burdened football with 'some perverse aspects'.

However, while the move will be welcomed by the Football Association and players' union, the Premier League will resist it. League sources said any EU move to introduce restrictions or quotas would be illegal and could be challenged in the courts. Clubs such as Chelsea, which last season became the first English side to field a team containing no England-born players, are opposed to limits. But Uefa believes that the protocol's 'properly representative' requirement would survive any court challenge because it would legally enshrine sport as a special case in European Law.

It would limit only the number of foreigners a club could field in any game, not how many overseas stars it could keep on its books.

Kate Hoey, the sports minister, greeted Uefa's protocol plan as a way of potentially dealing with the issue but called on Premier League clubs to solve the problem themselves through voluntary quotas.

'If the Premier League clubs and their chairmen had any sense and long-term vision, they could sort this out by controlling the number of foreign players. I doubt they will show such responsibility.'

fields.headline: Fabio's favourites: marking, marking, marking
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: Alessandro Nesta, Fabio Cannavaro and Francesco Toldo - they could only have come from Italy.
fields.body:
These three footballers could only have come from Italy. Alessandro Nesta, Fabio Cannavaro and Francesco Toldo look, think and play quite unlike inhabitants of any other nation.

Toldo was born first, 28 years ago in Padova, the son of a tobacconist. On Thursday, more than 20 people gathered in the family shop to watch the semi-final against Holland on television. They knew their boy should not have been playing. Francesco Toldo was Italy's reserve keeper until Gianluca Buffon broke a hand in Oslo shortly before Euro 2000.

Cannavaro was born in Naples 26 years ago, the son of a semi-professional footballer. From an early age he cultivated an Italian ambition: he wanted to be a defender. Cannavaro has a faint contempt for attackers. They can mess around with the ball, even lose it.

Cannavaro found a role model in another Neapolitan defender, Ciro Ferrara, who is 33 and sits on Italy's bench. 'He was and is my example,' says Cannavaro.

Had Cannavaro been born in England, he would probably never have found employment as a centre-back: he is only 5ft 9in. To compensate, he has built up his upper body and arms. A defender needs his arms, says Cannavaro says, because he has to be always touching his striker, checking where he is. Cannavaro loves these details. He defends by vocation. The most enjoyable thing in football, he says, is marking: 'Marcare, marcare, marcare!' He is a happy man, the only Italian player who is cheerful in defeat.

The man-marker is a peculiarly Italian profession, like gondolier or fashion designer. The post has a long, if not always honourable, history, encompassing legends like Oriali, Bergomi, Collovati and the filthy Claudio Gentile. They would sing in the shower if they shut a striker out of the match, even if their team had lost. They form the stock of role models.

Alessandro Nesta was born 24 years ago in Rome. He grew up in Cinecitta, the film studio suburb, son of a station guard and Lazio supporter named Giuseppe. Aged ten, Alessandro joined Lazio. 'I felt immediately this was a great talent,' says Felice Pulici, who spotted him. 'The way he ran, with his back straight. And a natural gift of playing the ball simply.'

Nesta made his debut at 17, under Dino Zoff, now Italy's coach. As Lazio trained a few weeks later, he saw Paul Gascoigne flying towards him like a fat UFO. Nesta held his leg firm, and unintentionally broke Gascoigne's. On realising this, he cried.

But he progressed. He acquired his lucky shirt number, 13 (Italians think 17 is the unlucky number) and just before Euro 96, helped Italy win the European Under-21 Championship. He was voted player of the tournament.

Aged 21, he made his debut for Italy. A year later, while sidelined with torn knee ligaments, his team-mates voted him club captain. Today he also sits on the Lazio board. Playing alongside Sinisa Mihajlovic, who is cranked into life only for free-kicks, he acts as libero and stopper at once. He senses gaps before they appear. 'He's a good one,' says Marco van Basten in the Dutch magazine Hard Gras .

So gracefully does the Roman move that he is sometimes compared to the great Italian libero Franco Baresi. But Nesta, though a better defender, lacks Baresi's creativity. In 139 league games for Lazio he has scored only once. Nor does he talk much. But after Lazio pipped Juventus to the Italian title last season, he led his home crowd in a rendition of ' Juve, Juve, vaffanculo! ' This is best not translated.

Italy have fielded their first-choice defence in four matches at Euro 2000 (against Sweden, the second team played). In those four matches they have conceded one goal, against Turkey, and that caused national anguish.

Cannavaro, asked to name the best defenders at Euro 2000, replies: 'After myself and Nesta, I think the Frenchman Thuram.'

So dominant have Nesta and Cannavaro been that the Italian fans have copied their hairbands. That is part of a trend of this month: the glorification of defending. Suddenly, it seems, kids no longer want to be Beckham or Alessandro del Piero, but Cannavaro. The new cult, incidentally, will only make Toldo, Nesta and Cannavaro more fearsome. With keepers and defenders, as with fast bowlers, the aura helps.

The way the Italians do it, defending is indeed glorious_'the most important thing in football,' says Cannavaro. And it is beautiful: Cannavaro and Nesta are girls' idols. Contrast these two with, say, Martin Keown and Sol Campbell. The two Italians are more mobile, partly thanks to club gymnastics exercises, and partly because they were chosen for mobility. They stay upright, never lunge: their team-mate, Mark Iuliano, conceded a penalty on Thursday with a horizontal sliding tackle on Edgar Davids that was worthy of an English defender. Nesta and Cannavaro rarely even foul. 'It's marvellous to play a forward out of a match without using rough methods,' says Nesta. 'That gives me the ultimate kick.'

On Thursday Nesta did concede a penalty, pulling at Patrick Kluivert's shirt, but otherwise eliminated the Dutch forward in the prescribed manner. Cannavaro at once shadowed Kluivert, Dennis Bergkamp, and, after Italy were reduced to 10 men, Boudewijn Zenden. Colleagues Paolo Maldini and Iuliano were both occasionally beaten but it is impossible to remember Cannavaro being beaten once.

He also delighted in throwing himself in front of Dutch shots, so that Toldo had little to do given that his team spent 120 minutes defending. 'The Dutch could have played for 24 hours and they would not have been able to score,' Toldo said afterwards. It was an understatement.

On Thursday the keeper stopped three penalties. He said later that he had discussed penalty psychology with Del Piero, Italy's leading penalty expert. 'It's a subtle game of glances and feeling,' was all Toldo would reveal. His technique certainly involves staring at the penalty-taker. The watching Pele was seen gesturing at Toldo, gesturing at his own eye, and laughing.

Afterwards Zoff was asked: 'What do you say to a keeper who saves three penalties for you?'

'Thank you,' said Zoff.

After the Dutch match, the Italian newspaper La Gazzetta dello Sport awarded Cannavaro nine marks out of 10. La Stampa gave Toldo a straight 10. Such marks are unheard of. And Italy has seen good defenders before.

fields.headline: The verdict on Zizou
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: He's the star of Euro 2000, the best player in the world and he's improving all the time. Is Zinedine Zidane the best European footballer since Johan Cruyff?
fields.body:
There is a reason Zinedine Zidane suffers from premature baldness. Genius footballer, generous nature, gentle man, his maker must have thought it only fair to show some evidence of imperfection.

Over the past month no other player from a catchment area that embraces an entire continent has captured the imagination quite like Zidane. He is mesmeric. Watching him dance over the grass leaving a flurry of opponents in his wake has been, in the words of the man from L'Equipe , like falling in love. Nobody says it quite like the French.

And at the moment, in footballing terms, nobody does it quite like the French. They are a more majestic sight now than when they won the World Cup, and the most important reason for this improvement is that their maestro, Zidane, is playing out of his skin.

Already a member of the pantheon of European masters tonight he is on the brink of something unique. Nowadays you might spot him shouting at Deschamps or Djorkaeff for a misplaced pass. He has even publicly disagreed with one or two of Lemerre's tactical decisions. At 28 and at his peak he is more comfortable as a leader. He has learned to accept it and can express himself more freely. In his own subtle way he has become a driving force. His rapport with the younger players in the squad is developing all the time.

Those who persist in making comparisons between him and Platini point to one fundamental difference. Zidane is not a prolific goalscorer (15 in 56 games, as opposed to Platini's 41 in 72). His critics suggest a player with such elevated status should have been able to make the difference for Juventus when they inexplicably squandered this season's title.

In his defence, one of the reasons he does not score so regularly is that he has such an extraordinary talent for creating goals for others. In Euro 2000 he has made more of those devastating slalom dribbles than Marc Overmars and more decisive crosses than Luis Figo. Besides, as Lemerre points out, his game is still evolving: 'There is so much more to come from Zidane. He can improve still further. He's phenomenal, on his way to becoming a monument of French football like Platini or Kopa.'

The affiliation between Platini and Zidane goes back to the moment Zizou celebrated his 12th birthday with the honour of being ballboy at the Vélodrome when France met Portugal in the 1984 European Championship. He was watching his country in the flesh for the first time, enchanted as Platini plundered a dramatic winner to take France to the final. Fourteen years on the roles were reversed. Platini was on the sidelines, captivated by the sight of the rightful successor to his distinguished No 10 shirt scoring to win the World Cup.

Goals might be the one string to Zidane's bow which could do with fine tuning (although his return of two, at key moments, during Euro 2000 is not bad). Otherwise he has never played so well. Tournament by international tournament he has raised the standards and so have France. Zidane's first cap came as Les Bleus were restructuring after a kamikaze failure to qualify for USA 94. By the time Euro 96 came around he was already billed as the fulcrum. But he arrived in England tired and sore, having played more than 60 games and torn a muscle in a car accident. Neither he nor his team made the heart soar.

Memories of France 98 will be forever intertwined with Zizou's two fine headed goals against Brazil. Victory was everything, but the competition wasn't a free-flowing breeze for team or talisman. People forget their hero was sent off for stamping on a Saudi Arabian and forced to miss two games. Without him, France disposed of South Africa but could only squeeze past Paraguay with a golden goal.

He returned to face Italy in the quarter-final, and at a critical time manager Aime Jacquet gave him a crucial pep talk. 'Zizou, the French team is not you, and you don't represent the French team. Think hard about those words,' he warned, before adding, poignantly, 'But it's you who can make us win.'

In Euro 2000 France, and their conductor, have reached a higher plane. Compared to the World Cup there is more poetry in his performances. More absolute control. More of those tricks where he rolls his studs over the ball to keep possession. He is hard to dispossess not because of body strength, but crafty close control. It's like moving a ball of wool an inch to the left and watching a kitten paw at the vacated space. The manager who took him to Juventus, Marcello Lippi, described it as his skill for making complicated things easy.

But the point about Zidane's brilliance is, not only is he a joy to the eye, he is also ruthlessly efficient. Lemerre no doubt likes to see him wow the crowd with a clever turn, but he loves to see him slice open the opposition's defence with a devastating pinpoint pass.

If Italy have the legs to continue damming more fluid opponents with their wall of resistance Zidane will be the man expected to fashion the breakthrough. Playing regularly in Serie A means he is not overawed by the smothering cloak of an Italian defence. Psychologically, he knows he can rise above that and impose his skills. He is particularly pleased it is Dino Zoff's prudent team who stand between him and his country's double dream.

France are 90 minutes (please no more unbearable golden goals or penalty shoot-outs) from sporting immortality. This would make them not just a great French side, or a great modern side, but one of the great football teams of all time, inspired by one of the great players. Over to you, Zizou.

fields.headline: The best since the Seventies
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: From Zidane to Zahovic this championship buzzed with superb goals, glory and moments to savour.
fields.body:
Holland are famous for never winning a World Cup but crediting themselves with a couple of moral victories for playing the best football. They are entitled to look back on Euro 2000 in the same way. The tournament will no longer end in a giant orange party, but, largely thanks to the hosts, it deserves to be remembered as one of the great football-fests. Even France's Emmanuel Petit has said: 'This tournament is stronger than the World Cup two years ago.'

Images of Italy prevailing in the orangeness of the Amsterdam ArenA, of Portugal's despair at that golden-goal penalty, and of Zinedine Zidane transcending anything seen in Europe since Johan Cruyff will linger long in the memory. There were good teams, there were bad teams, but there were very few bad games.

Even the occasional stinker like England v Germany was only depressing for its poverty of talent and imagination, and not for the petty indiscipline and mean-spirited negativity which disfigured earlier tournaments. Euro 2000 was confirmation that rule changes have got the game into good shape for the next century. There were heroes aplenty, from Zidane to Zlatko Zahovic, and no real villains. And that includes Italy.

There can be little doubt that Holland were the true hosts. The Belgians have never added much to the gaiety of nations, and here both their fans and their football were flat, functional and quickly forgotten. Dutch fans and players, on the other hand, seemed to be competing with each other in a friendly fight to see who could be the more vibrant. In the final analysis, given that Rotterdam this evening is still likely to be a fairly orange experience even though the dream ending has been shattered by Italian reality, the fans probably won.

It was certainly revealing to be in the Grand Place in Brussels, the square which earlier in the tournament had witnessed the water cannon versus En-ger-land contest, on the day of the Portugal-France semi-final. Portuguese fans, wandering the streets in flags and face paint, were slightly outnumbered by French supporters who had noisily taken over a few bars and pavement cafes. By far the biggest presence, however, was that of the Dutch in their regulation orange.

'I am sorry, I am embarrassed to be Dutch,' an Amsterdam waitress whispered as a battered orange bus full of supporters in matching orange bowler hats brought traffic to a standstill outside her cafe before the second semi-final. At that point it was rather more acutely embarrassing to be English. Just as a German banner at the France-Portugal match had pointedly alerted the German FA to the fact that this was how football should be played, the boisterous but never less than courteous Dutch could be held up as an example to the obnoxious element among England followers. 'That,' the message might read, 'is how you support a national team.'

There are those who will claim it is a pity such colourful and committed support did not get the final it deserved, or, more contentiously, that Holland's positive attacking play was effectively mugged by football's dark forces in the Amsterdam ArenA. But this simply will not do. Complaining of cynicism in Italian defending is like objecting to the heat in the Tropics. Rules have been re-framed over the last decade to discourage teams from skulking in their own half and stifling play, but Italy were severely penalised against Holland for the bits of their game which were unduly uncompromising.

They effectively had to play 90 minutes with 10 men and conceded two penalties in normal time. One cannot advance a moral case for a team which managed to miss five penalties in a semi-final, and neither can one dismiss Italy as anti-football when they defended an adverse situation so heroically. Despite Italy's numerical disad vantage they actually had three attacking forwards on the field late in the game in Alessandro Del Piero, Marco Delvecchio and Francesco Totti, so it is hardly even the case that they simply got men behind the ball.

Dino Zoff's side may not win many friends playing like that, but very few defences could surrender so much possession and territory and still prevent a goal. The idea that every team should play fantasy football is just that, fantasy.

You can only measure the brilliance of attacking sides like France and Brazil against teams who don't give away goals for the asking. Holland 6 Yugoslavia 1 was entertaining, but Italy 0 Holland 0 was instructive. Football needs its light and dark, chiaroscuro as they call it in the country which gave us catenaccio . It will be interesting, to say the least, so see whether France's attacking reputation emerges intact after today's final.

One goal is all it might take to undo Italy, and Holland were unlucky to the extent that Dennis Bergkamp hit a post early in the game and Francesco Toldo made a couple of vital stops, but by the end, hindered in no small way by Frank Rijkaard's mystifying substitutions, the clockwork orange machine had wound down to the extent that it was harmlessly spinning in ever-decreasing circles.

So if France prevail it will be a victory for attacking football but if the game goes Italy's way, it will still be a victory for football. France v Holland would inevitably have been a disappointment anyway, just as France v Portugal did not produce the feast everyone was expecting. It is also worth asking whether Holland were ever all they were cracked up to be, since their most impressive performances in this tournament were against a weak Danish side, a France B team and a shambles from Yugoslavia. Against a full-strength and capable Czech team they needed a lucky late goal to secure victory, and against resolute Italy they ran out of ideas.

France should do better, even if their own semi-final suggested they might struggle against an organised defence. Their key advantages are pace and movement, and the player to push open the door is Zidane. If he takes the ball standing still, as he did too often against Portugal, he will impress with his balance and close control but ultimately play into Italy's hands. If he can take the ball at pace, forcing defenders to commit themselves and using his sublime distribution to get France on the move, the favourites should prosper.

Either way, one hopes the tournament breaks a recent sequence and gets the final it deserves, since there is no doubt it has been the most enjoyable, skilful and memorable meeting of nations since the early Seventies. Here are a few reasons why.

FOOTBALL

Not quite Brazil in 1970 perhaps, but some truly fabulous passing, movement and finishing from those such as Portugal, France, Spain and Holland.

PLAYERS

Zinedine Zidane, Didier Deschamps, Laurent Blanc, Edgar Davids, Patrick Kluivert, Fabio Cannavaro, Francesco Toldo, Luis Figo, Nuno Gomes, Alfonso, Pavel Nedved, Dorinel Munteanu, David Beckham, Arif Erdem, Savo Milosevic, Zlatko Zahovic.

MATCHES

Who can forget England v Portugal, Yugoslavia v Slovenia or Yugoslavia v Spain? It could be argued the competition was devoid of drama or upset in its early stages, with no real shocks in the group stage and every quarter-final going to form, but the two semi-finals certainly corrected that impression. Portugal's reaction in the aftermath of the golden-goal penalty awarded against Abel Xavier might have been unseemly, but there was no denying the raw passion of the moment. No wonder Uefa are considering scrapping the golden-goal period already. It did not seem possible the Amsterdam semi could rival the Brussels one, but it did, and it produced an upset into the bargain. Italy winning by playing like the old Italy should not really count as an upset, but no one expected them to reach the final and perhaps they would not have done so had the Dutch managed a slightly better penalty ratio than one from six attempts.

STADIUMS

Holland's stadiums are state-of-the-art, Belgium's less so, but all are people-friendly arenas situated conveniently close to town or city centres. All were accessible by tram, train, bus or on foot with very few problems. For the Amsterdam semi-final on Thursday we left our city-centre hotel at 4.15pm for a 6pm kick-off, parked outside the ground for a fiver 15 minutes later, and were able to drive away easily within 45 minutes of the final whistle. Try doing that at Wembley.

THE FANS

Stadiums were mostly full for matches, even Norway v Slovenia attracted a decent crowd and generated a jolly atmosphere. Audiences were probably the most colourful ever, thanks to Holland's orange order, and inside stadiums there was very little trouble. It is obviously true that some alleged England supporters misbehaved in Brussels, as did some Belgians, some Turks and some policemen, but more or less the same thing will be going on in Benidorm all summer without making the news bulletins. Boorish English behaviour does not begin on the cross-channel ferry or at the commencement of a football tournament. Its existence and tolerance at home is the unwritten story every time the government or Uefa wring their hands over the latest shaming example of non-assimilation with more civilised cultures. Real football fans are fed up of this particular social problem. The England supporters who got into games behaved impeccably, even those who found themselves in the Romanian end at Charleroi.

REFEREEING

There was no blizzard of red and yellow cards, no inflexible directive from the governing body, and few important players missed vital matches for disciplinary reasons. Officials were mostly unobtrusive and refereeing was simply not an issue in the way it has tended to be at recent tournaments. That is not to say there were no controversial decisions, but from the dismissal in the second semi to the outstanding spot and brave standing of his ground by Igor Sramka of Slovakia in the first, most were correct. Of the ones that were not, such as Alpay Ozalan's rather harsh dismissal in the Turkey-Portugal quarter-final, diving or play-acting were usually to blame. Referees are getting better at spotting obvious dives like Alan Shearer's against Germany, but they have a growing problem with fouled players who exaggerate injuries to get opponents dismissed. Uefa should consider retrospective video evidence and mandatory suspensions for unsportsmanlike behaviour.

HISTORY

All great tournaments need to change the status quo to an extent, to leave the world a slightly different place. Post-Euro 2000 the hotspots on the European map are all Iberian or Mediterranean. Germany, England, all of Scandinavia and even Holland, to some extent, are woolly mammoths wandering the frozen north. At least Holland played football in their tournament. What game England, Germany, and the others were playing is anybody's guess.

THE GRAND GESTURE.

Erich Ribbeck jumped before he was pushed, Frank Rijkaard and the estimable Humbert Coelho quit immediately after their semi-finals. Odd to think that the coaches of Holland and Portugal have gone but Kevin Keegan - 'I don't see any reason to offer to resign, I think we can be optimistic for the future' - is still in charge of England. Apparently the FA have been shocked by the amount of criticism their coach has come in for, which just shows what a dear old bunch of complacent little-Englanders the denizens of Lancaster Gate still are. But don't worry, Euro 2000 will be over by tonight and another Premiership season is just around the corner.

So if France prevail it will be a victory for attacking football but if the game goes Italy's way, it will still be a victory for football. France v Holland would inevitably have been a disappointment anyway, just as France v Portugal did not produce the feast everyone was expecting. It is also worth asking whether Holland were ever all they were cracked up to be, since their most impressive performances in this tournament were against a weak Danish side, a France B team and a shambles from Yugoslavia. Against a full-strength and capable Czech team they needed a lucky late goal to secure victory, and against resolute Italy they ran out of ideas. France should do better, even if their own semi-final suggested they might struggle against an organised defence. Their key advantages are pace and movement, and the player to push open the door is Zidane. If he takes the ball standing still, as he did too often against Portugal, he will impress with his balance and close control but ultimately play into Italy's hands. If he can take the ball at pace, forcing defenders to commit themselves and using his sublime distribution to get France on the move, the favourites should prosper. Either way, one hopes the tournament breaks a recent sequence and gets the final it deserves, since there is no doubt it has been the most enjoyable, skilful and memorable meeting of nations since the early Seventies. Here are a few reasons why. FOOTBALL Not quite Brazil in 1970 perhaps, but some truly fabulous passing, movement and finishing from those such as Portugal, France, Spain and Holland. PLAYERS Zinedine Zidane, Didier Deschamps, Laurent Blanc, Edgar Davids, Patrick Kluivert, Fabio Cannavaro, Francesco Toldo, Luis Figo, Nuno Gomes, Alfonso, Pavel Nedved, Dorinel Munteanu, David Beckham, Arif Erdem, Savo Milosevic, Zlatko Zahovic. MATCHES Who can forget England v Portugal, Yugoslavia v Slovenia or Yugoslavia v Spain? It could be argued the competition was devoid of drama or upset in its early stages, with no real shocks in the group stage and every quarter-final going to form, but the two semi-finals certainly corrected that impression. Portugal's reaction in the aftermath of the golden-goal penalty awarded against Abel Xavier might have been unseemly, but there was no denying the raw passion of the moment. No wonder Uefa are considering scrapping the golden-goal period already. It did not seem possible the Amsterdam semi could rival the Brussels one, but it did, and it produced an upset into the bargain. Italy winning by playing like the old Italy should not really count as an upset, but no one expected them to reach the final and perhaps they would not have done so had the Dutch managed a slightly better penalty ratio than one from six attempts. STADIUMS Holland's stadiums are state-of-the-art, Belgium's less so, but all are people-friendly arenas situated conveniently close to town or city centres. All were accessible by tram, train, bus or on foot with very few problems. For the Amsterdam semi-final on Thursday we left our city-centre hotel at 4.15pm for a 6pm kick-off, parked outside the ground for a fiver 15 minutes later, and were able to drive away easily within 45 minutes of the final whistle. Try doing that at Wembley. THE FANS Stadiums were mostly full for matches, even Norway v Slovenia attracted a decent crowd and generated a jolly atmosphere. Audiences were probably the most colourful ever, thanks to Holland's orange order, and inside stadiums there was very little trouble. It is obviously true that some alleged England supporters misbehaved in Brussels, as did some Belgians, some Turks and some policemen, but more or less the same thing will be going on in Benidorm all summer without making the news bulletins. Boorish English behaviour does not begin on the cross-channel ferry or at the commencement of a football tournament. Its existence and tolerance at home is the unwritten story every time the government or Uefa wring their hands over the latest shaming example of non-assimilation with more civilised cultures. Real football fans are fed up of this particular social problem. The England supporters who got into games behaved impeccably, even those who found themselves in the Romanian end at Charleroi. REFEREEING There was no blizzard of red and yellow cards, no inflexible directive from the governing body, and few important players missed vital matches for disciplinary reasons. Officials were mostly unobtrusive and refereeing was simply not an issue in the way it has tended to be at recent tournaments. That is not to say there were no controversial decisions, but from the dismissal in the second semi to the outstanding spot and brave standing of his ground by Igor Sramka of Slovakia in the first, most were correct. Of the ones that were not, such as Alpay Ozalan's rather harsh dismissal in the Turkey-Portugal quarter-final, diving or play-acting were usually to blame. Referees are getting better at spotting obvious dives like Alan Shearer's against Germany, but they have a growing problem with fouled players who exaggerate injuries to get opponents dismissed. Uefa should consider retrospective video evidence and mandatory suspensions for unsportsmanlike behaviour. HISTORY All great tournaments need to change the status quo to an extent, to leave the world a slightly different place. Post-Euro 2000 the hotspots on the European map are all Iberian or Mediterranean. Germany, England, all of Scandinavia and even Holland, to some extent, are woolly mammoths wandering the frozen north. At least Holland played football in their tournament. What game England, Germany, and the others were playing is anybody's guess. THE GRAND GESTURE. Erich Ribbeck jumped before he was pushed, Frank Rijkaard and the estimable Humbert Coelho quit immediately after their semi-finals. Odd to think that the coaches of Holland and Portugal have gone but Kevin Keegan - 'I don't see any reason to offer to resign, I think we can be optimistic for the future' - is still in charge of England. Apparently the FA have been shocked by the amount of criticism their coach has come in for, which just shows what a dear old bunch of complacent little-Englanders the denizens of Lancaster Gate still are. But don't worry, Euro 2000 will be over by tonight and another Premiership season is just around the corner.

fields.headline: France 2 - 1 Italy
fields.trailText:
Teams:
France: Barthez, Lizarazu, Blanc, Desailly, Thuram, Deschamps, Vieira, Zidane, Dugarry, Djorkaeff, Henry.
Subs: Anelka, Candela, Karembeu, Lama, Leboeuf, Micoud, Petit, Pires, Rame, Trezeguet, Wiltord.
Italy: Toldo, Pessotto, Cannavaro, Nesta, Iuliano, Maldini, Albertini, Di Biagio, Fiore, Totti, Delvecchio.
Subs: Abbiati, Antonioli, Ferrara, Negro, Di Livio, Inzaghi, Del Piero, Ambrosini, Montella.
Referee: Anders Frisk (Sweden)
fields.body:
Teams:
France: Barthez, Lizarazu, Blanc, Desailly, Thuram, Deschamps, Vieira, Zidane, Dugarry, Djorkaeff, Henry.
Subs: Anelka, Candela, Karembeu, Lama, Leboeuf, Micoud, Petit, Pires, Rame, Trezeguet, Wiltord. Italy: Toldo, Pessotto, Cannavaro, Nesta, Iuliano, Maldini, Albertini, Di Biagio, Fiore, Totti, Delvecchio.
Subs: Abbiati, Antonioli, Ferrara, Negro, Di Livio, Inzaghi, Del Piero, Ambrosini, Montella. Referee: Anders Frisk (Sweden)

1 Italy kick off. Within five seconds, the French send their first long ball to Thierry Henry. Within thirty seconds, the second long ball sets Henry free. He dumps Fabio Cannavaro and chips a low ball to the far post where Maldini beats Zidane to the ball.

2 Italy try to get a little snow on it too, and Marco Delvecchio nearly profits before an onrushing Barthez intercepts.

4 Italian corner, conceded by Desailly. The ball is played short, then across to the right flank, but the eventual cross meets the hands of Barthez.

5 Henry, already looking lively, hits the outside of Francesco Toldo's left-hand post with the keeper left bewildered.

7 Great play by Italy. Pessotto finds Fiore on the right flank. The Udinese man accelerates away from Lizarazu and places a great cross onto the head of Marco Delvecchio, but Barthez saves.

8 Now it's the turn of the French to attack in this exhilarating opening to the game. Dugarry turns Cannavaro on the edge of the box and digs out a cross that finds Youri Djorkaeff. Djorkaeff takes the ball down on his chest wonderfully, but is crowded off the ball before he can shoot.

15 Free-kick for Italy is taken by Demetrio Albertini, who ambitiously aims to curl the ball over Barthez from 30 yards. Not too surprisingly, he fails.

18 The initially hectic pace of the game has slowed now, with the Italians sitting deeper and the French happily keeping possession in midfield.

19 As an example of the way the game is currently going, Didier Deschamps is France's best attacking option as they congregate around the Italian box. The water carrier has a fiersome crack, but it flys a couple of feet over the bar.

21 Another attack for the French fails to truly trouble the Italian defence. Christophe Dugarry shows some nice touches to find some space on the edge of the box, but his shot is immediately charged down by Alessandro Nesta. Not an unfamiliar sight.

23 Dugarry's persistence wins the French a corner. Djorkaeff takes it, and Desailly meets it, but the ball is slowed by a defender's body and trickles just wide of goal.

26 Henry, who seems to be sharing the left flank with Dugarry, mystifies Cannavaro with two step-overs in quick succession. The French forward then falls over, but referee Frisk sees no foul.

29 A swift move across the box by the French almost lets in Henry. But Nesta is there, simply standing in Henry's path and refusing to let him turn.

30 Henry on the ball again, this time embarking on a seemingly optimistic run at the Italian back seven. He leaves two for dead however and the third, Luigi Di Biagio, brings him down from behind. Yellow card, the first of the game.

34 The last few, otherwise ordinary, minutes have been pepped up by the first signs of a tasty feud between Marcel Desailly and Delvecchio. Only pushing and name calling so far, but we live in hope.

38 A half-chance, at last. Henry again finds space on the left, dragging Nesta wide with him. He then cuts inside and then produces a shot which turns into a good pass to Djorkaeff on the six yard line. Djorkaeff turns and toe-pokes the ball, but Toldo gets down and saves.

39 France lose the ball deep in the Italian half, and Italy break quickly, with Albertini passing long to Delvecchio who lays the ball back to Totti who scuffs a shot wide. Not too dangerous, but a reminder to the French all the same.

41 Another fiery run from Henry leaves Cannavaro shaking like a chandelier. Another rash challenge ensues, as does another yellow card.

43 Paolo Maldini gets clear on the left wings and rushes into the box. His cross only reaches Desailly, but his clearance nearly falls at the feet of Delvecchio. Fortunately for the Chelsea man, Djorkaeff has tracked back and clears.

46 Half-time.

45 France kick-off.

46 Zinedine Zidane makes his first potent contribution of the game. Gathering the ball in the business end of the field he gallops away from Albertini and slips a delicious ball inbetween Nesta and Cannavaro for Henry to run onto. Run onto it he does, beating Nesta to the ball, but his partner Cannavaro stands firm and gets a touch just before Henry can shoot.

49 Henry creates the clearest opening of the game so far. The Arsenal striker again gets the ball on the left, beats Iuliano, then Cannavaro before crossing low across the goalmouth, beating opponents and teammates alike.

52 Italian substitution: Alessandro Del Piero for Stefano Fiore. The golden boy makes his way off the bench once more. Will he make the difference this time?

53 Perhaps by the process of osmosis, Del Piero's arrival inspires Italy's best attack of the match. Paolo Maldini, marauding down the left wing,. gets the bal from Albertini and crosses dangerously into the box. The ball eludes everyone again, but goes out for a corner.

55 GOAL! France 0 - 1 Italy It's magic! A touch of skill from Totti, the second decent cross of the game from Pessotto and a crisp left-foot finish from Delvecchio. Suddenly the outsiders have the lead. If only they were any good at defending...

56 French substitution - Sylvain Wiltord for Christophe Dugarry. France go for it straightaway. Dugarry's had a good game, but the World Champions need goals.

59 They almost needed another too, after a fast Italian break finds Del Piero in space. The £60,000-a-week star has only Barthez to beat, but finishes woefully, dragging the ball wide of the far post.

61 Zidane, now sitting much further forward, picks a pass that only he can, discombobulating two defenders and finding Sylvain Wiltord. The Bordeaux striker advances on goal from a narrow angle. He shoots, when passing to Djorkaeff would have made better sense, and Toldo's long legs clear.

65 Italian substitution - Massimo Ambrosini for Luigi Di Biagio. Things get even tighter in the Italian midfield.

68 Zidane takes a free-kick 10 yards outside the Italian area. The ball finds Henry in the six-yard box. His touch is immaculate, but so is Toldo's anticicpation and the keeper gets down to the striker's quick shot.

69 Another dangerous break from the Italians. Totti is the initiator (the Roma man looking more comfortable in a deeper midfield role), picking out Delvecchio with a 30-yard pass. Delvecchio receives the ball, but the attentions of Laurent Blanc leads him to strike wide.

74 Totti again instigates a valuable period of possession for the Italians, getting the ball in midfield finding Delvecchio and charging up the field in time to receive a return pass. He then slips the ball to Del Piero on the edge of the box, but the golden boy slips over. Maybe Zoff had it right all along.

75 French substitution: David Trezeguet for Youri Djorkaeff. That's three French strikers on the field and Zidane..

79 Zidane gets the ball in the Italian box, he skins Paolo Maldini twice, but is brought to a halt by an excellent challenge from... er... Allessandro Del Piero. So that's why he's come on then.

83 At this stage of the game, even the reluctant Lilian Thuram is getting forward. He beats Maldini too and produces a fabulous cross from the touchline. But no-one is there to meet it for France, and not for the first time.

84 The ball springs to the other end immediately. Totti finds Pessotto who picks out Ambrosini, who slyly slides the ball left into Del Piero's path. It's a similar position to the one he missed from a few minutes ago, and this time his first-time shot cannons off Barthez's legs.

85 Italian substitution: Vincenzo Montella for Marco Delvecchio
French substitution: Robert Pires for Bixente Lizarazu.

89 More French pressure, and more Italian interceptions. The world champions don't look like finding a way through, but they've got four minutes of injury time in which to do it.

93 GOAL! France 1 - 1 Italy Would you believe it. One minute left and again France gain possession on the left hand side of the Italian box. Wiltord beats Cannavaro and once more a shot aims for the far post. This time however the shot finds its target, eluding Toldo's massive reach and nestling insde the net. Game on again, and what a time to do it.

94 Full-time brings extra time. Alessandro del Piero, how are you feeling?

1 Italy kick off.

2 Zidane finds Henry in that left-wing position with Trezeguet advancing into the box too, but the striker neither crosses nor shoots and an opportunity is wasted.

4 More French pressure results in a long-range shot from Robert Pires that Toldo can't quite handle. He recovers quickly however, and gets a boot in the face from Trezeguet for his trouble.

8 Del Piero gets the ball with his back to goal. He controls, spins, and... shoots miles over again.

9 This time it's the French who break quickly and Ambrosini is forced to bring down Wiltord. Zidane steps up for the free-kick, in a similar position to the one he scored from against Spain, and misses.

11 A nice cross from Pires is met by an acrobatic volley from Zidane which deflects off Maldini for a corner.

12 GOLDEN GOAL! FRANCE 2 - 1 ITALY Pires makes the opening, beating two men, dinking the ball over Pessotto's outstretched leg and tearing into the area. Nesta goes to cover, but Pires surprises him and instead of crossing pulls the ball back. David Trezeguet, waiting in the six-yard box, takes one step back from his marker and smashes the ball with his left foot into the roof of the net. France are European champions, and what a way to do it.

fields.headline: We'll meet a hen...
fields.standfirst: Nick Park's latest feat of clay is a hand-crafted gem. Movies like this are as rare as, well, hens' teeth
fields.trailText: Philip French: The film flags slightly from time to time, but for most of the way it is prodigally and prodigiously inventive, both visually and verbally
fields.body:
Most aspects of the cinema have been the subject of books by scholars or buffs in the past 30 years. But possibly the oddest is Cluck!, a wondrously erudite, tongue-in-cheek study of chickens on the screen, written in 1980 by Jon-Stephen Fink and Mieke van der Linden. The authors' rating system of chicken-stars went from one (Elementary Incident, e.g. Patton) to four (Awesome Consequence, e.g. The Gold Rush, Freaks), and if they are preparing a new edition they will have little hesitation in putting Chicken Run into the top category.

This fine family entertainment is the first feature-length film from Aardman, the animation studio based in Bristol that has been dazzling us for 20 years with its feats of clay. This one is co-directed by Peter Lord, co-founder of Aardman, and Nick Park, the creator of Wallace and Gromit and winner of Oscars for Creature Comforts, The Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave, which opened nearly five years ago and was loosely inspired by Brief Encounter.

Chicken Run is a very close parody of the prisoner-of-war camp genre, especially The Great Escape. In this case, however, the PoWs are Plasticine chickens and the camp is a farm in Yorkshire surrounded by barbed wire, policed by vicious guard dogs and run by the ferocious Mrs Tweedy (Miranda Richardson) whose jack-booted resemblance to Irma Grise of Belsen infamy is slightly mitigated by her dim husband who looks like Wallace's black-sheep brother. In contrast to the not dissimilar Babe, there are no decent humans here.

The camp's escape officer is Ginger (voiced by Julia Sawalha in the manner of her imperturbable Saffie in Absolutely Fabulous) and the movie begins with a lively montage of ingenious escape attempts. Between each of them Ginger is thrown into the coal-bin cooler where, like Steve McQueen in The Great Escape, she bounces a baseball. The movie takes on a darker shade when a hen is executed by Mrs Tweedy for failing to lay eggs (we see the shadow of the falling axe), and it threatens to become positively black when the Tweedies decide to switch from producing eggs to manufacturing chicken pies, thus turning the farm into an extermination camp.

But Park and his associates know that while swans can be tragic, hens can only be comic. So they endeavour to make us care about their poultry, but avoid easy pathos and seek to keep sentimentality at bay.

This isn't an allegory in the tradition of The Parliament of Fowls or Animal Farm, and there are no uplifting, heartrending songs in the Disney manner. The only musical interlude is a jive session the hens have with Rocky, a flying Rhode Island rooster from the States (Mel Gibson) who has escaped from a circus and landed in the camp. Rocky provides a foil for Fowler (Benjamin Whitrow), the ageing cock-of-the-walk nostalgically obsessed with his days in the RAF, and some love interest for Ginger.

More important, Ginger gets him to start a flying school for a mass escape by air. This hilariously disastrous enterprise is observed by a pair of black-marketeer rats (Timothy Spall, Phil Daniels) who mock the hens' antics with lines such as 'Birds of a feather flop together' and 'Poultry in motion'. In fact, except for refraining from references to getting laid, there is not a single chicken joke or pun that goes unused, and I now even feel bad about writing 'e.g.'.

Flying the coop using your own wings would have been the inspirational way out, but the Aardman people wisely reject it. Instead they opt for a flying machine of the sort built in Colditz and run up by the stranded survivors in Flight of the Phoenix. This gives Park the chance to create another eccentric contraption of a Heath-Robinson or Roland Emmett sort.

Stalag Luft III would have had trouble containing inmates who could transform a string of fairylights into a flarepath and use the ratchets of a deck-chair to create a take-off ramp. Naturally Mac, the camp's resident engineer, is, like Star Trek 's Scotty, from north of the border.

The film flags slightly from time to time, but for most of the way it is prodigally and prodigiously inventive, both visually and verbally. For me, coming to Chicken Run after such smoothly brilliant computer-generated Hollywood films as Toy Story, Antz and A Bug's Life was like sitting down to a home-cooked Sunday dinner of beef, Yorkshire pudding and home-grown potatoes after weeks of beautifully packaged meals from the microwave.

We know that every second of the film involves hours of painstaking physical work moving and adjusting the figures and sets. But even if you didn't know about the laborious process of clay animation, you would recognise the virtuosity and sense something lovingly hand-crafted in Chicken Run.
fields.bodyText: Most aspects of the cinema have been the subject of books by scholars or buffs in the past 30 years. But possibly the oddest is Cluck!, a wondrously erudite, tongue-in-cheek study of chickens on the screen, written in 1980 by Jon-Stephen Fink and Mieke van der Linden. The authors' rating system of chicken-stars went from one (Elementary Incident, e.g. Patton) to four (Awesome Consequence, e.g. The Gold Rush, Freaks), and if they are preparing a new edition they will have little hesitation in putting Chicken Run into the top category. This fine family entertainment is the first feature-length film from Aardman, the animation studio based in Bristol that has been dazzling us for 20 years with its feats of clay. This one is co-directed by Peter Lord, co-founder of Aardman, and Nick Park, the creator of Wallace and Gromit and winner of Oscars for Creature Comforts, The Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave, which opened nearly five years ago and was loosely inspired by Brief Encounter. Chicken Run is a very close parody of the prisoner-of-war camp genre, especially The Great Escape. In this case, however, the PoWs are Plasticine chickens and the camp is a farm in Yorkshire surrounded by barbed wire, policed by vicious guard dogs and run by the ferocious Mrs Tweedy (Miranda Richardson) whose jack-booted resemblance to Irma Grise of Belsen infamy is slightly mitigated by her dim husband who looks like Wallace's black-sheep brother. In contrast to the not dissimilar Babe, there are no decent humans here. The camp's escape officer is Ginger (voiced by Julia Sawalha in the manner of her imperturbable Saffie in Absolutely Fabulous) and the movie begins with a lively montage of ingenious escape attempts. Between each of them Ginger is thrown into the coal-bin cooler where, like Steve McQueen in The Great Escape, she bounces a baseball. The movie takes on a darker shade when a hen is executed by Mrs Tweedy for failing to lay eggs (we see the shadow of the falling axe), and it threatens to become positively black when the Tweedies decide to switch from producing eggs to manufacturing chicken pies, thus turning the farm into an extermination camp. But Park and his associates know that while swans can be tragic, hens can only be comic. So they endeavour to make us care about their poultry, but avoid easy pathos and seek to keep sentimentality at bay. This isn't an allegory in the tradition of The Parliament of Fowls or Animal Farm, and there are no uplifting, heartrending songs in the Disney manner. The only musical interlude is a jive session the hens have with Rocky, a flying Rhode Island rooster from the States (Mel Gibson) who has escaped from a circus and landed in the camp. Rocky provides a foil for Fowler (Benjamin Whitrow), the ageing cock-of-the-walk nostalgically obsessed with his days in the RAF, and some love interest for Ginger. More important, Ginger gets him to start a flying school for a mass escape by air. This hilariously disastrous enterprise is observed by a pair of black-marketeer rats (Timothy Spall, Phil Daniels) who mock the hens' antics with lines such as 'Birds of a feather flop together' and 'Poultry in motion'. In fact, except for refraining from references to getting laid, there is not a single chicken joke or pun that goes unused, and I now even feel bad about writing 'e.g.'. Flying the coop using your own wings would have been the inspirational way out, but the Aardman people wisely reject it. Instead they opt for a flying machine of the sort built in Colditz and run up by the stranded survivors in Flight of the Phoenix. This gives Park the chance to create another eccentric contraption of a Heath-Robinson or Roland Emmett sort. Stalag Luft III would have had trouble containing inmates who could transform a string of fairylights into a flarepath and use the ratchets of a deck-chair to create a take-off ramp. Naturally Mac, the camp's resident engineer, is, like Star Trek 's Scotty, from north of the border. The film flags slightly from time to time, but for most of the way it is prodigally and prodigiously inventive, both visually and verbally. For me, coming to Chicken Run after such smoothly brilliant computer-generated Hollywood films as Toy Story, Antz and A Bug's Life was like sitting down to a home-cooked Sunday dinner of beef, Yorkshire pudding and home-grown potatoes after weeks of beautifully packaged meals from the microwave. We know that every second of the film involves hours of painstaking physical work moving and adjusting the figures and sets.
