fields.headline: Old but still fresh
fields.trailText: A fabulous result for England and well deserved after Friday's heroics. But the team will be more than aware that West Indies will come right back at them and that in Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh they still have two exceptional bowlers.
fields.body:
A fabulous result for England and well deserved after Friday's heroics. But the team will be more than aware that West Indies will come right back at them and that in Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh they still have two exceptional bowlers.

People might say that Andrew Caddick looks to be a different player in this Test from the one who played at Edgbaston, but that is because he was bowling on a track ideally suited to his style. The surface at Lord's for this game was the same as it was for the match against Zimbabwe, and in those conditions Caddick has few equals. I also favour a surface that looks like wet straw that has been dried out. This keeps the ball in good nick and encourages swing.

At Edgbaston, the pitch was abrasive and we were guilty of not adapting to the conditions. Walsh and Ambrose realised immediately what was required and adapted accord ingly. They both pitched the ball back of a length and used the cracks in the pitch. By taking this approach, they managed to produce deliveries that kept low and pinned the batsmen on the back foot. Whether it hits the pads or the poles, the batters are in trouble.

They also altered the way the ball came out of the hand. On a Lord's-type surface, they bowl seam-up and on a length. This means that the ball kisses the deck and the pitch does the work. Up in Birmingham, they put a lot more energy on the ball and this could be seen on the replays. This means that the ball stays in contact with the pitch a fraction longer and therefore has more of a chance to do something. It's very similar to a golfer pitching on to a hard green. With plenty of energy on the ball, a player gets a lot of bite and the ball grips and stays put.

Having that ability is a huge advantage on the baked clay conditions we encountered in Birmingham.

West Indies' back-up bowlers, Reon King and Franklyn Rose, are both quicker than Walsh and Ambrose but not nearly so consistent. They bowl the odd 'four' ball and this takes the pressure off the batsmen. The big two keep you thinking the whole time and give very little away. It takes massive concentration to keep them out.

They are both masters of English conditions, having played county cricket and, combined with their experience of having played all over the world in varying conditions, they rarely come across something they haven't seen before.

Their longevity another thing to marvel at. I believe the secret to this is how loose they are. Their actions are fluid and require remarkably little effort, which therefore doesn't take much out of them. A lot of bowlers put 100 per cent into every delivery and sooner or later that will take its toll.

I don't know Curtly very well but Courtney is a total gentleman off the pitch. Yet, as we saw yesterday, when he steps across the rope that killer instinct takes over. I know his partner in crime is just the same and that is what makes them a class apart.

With plenty of energy on the ball, a player gets a lot of bite and the ball grips and stays put. Having that ability is a huge advantage on the baked clay conditions we encountered in Birmingham. West Indies' back-up bowlers, Reon King and Franklyn Rose, are both quicker than Walsh and Ambrose but not nearly so consistent. They bowl the odd 'four' ball and this takes the pressure off the batsmen. The big two keep you thinking the whole time and give very little away. It takes massive concentration to keep them out. They are both masters of English conditions, having played county cricket and, combined with their experience of having played all over the world in varying conditions, they rarely come across something they haven't seen before. Their longevity another thing to marvel at. I believe the secret to this is how loose they are. Their actions are fluid and require remarkably little effort, which therefore doesn't take much out of them. A lot of bowlers put 100 per cent into every delivery and sooner or later that will take its toll. I don't know Curtly very well but Courtney is a total gentleman off the pitch. Yet, as we saw yesterday, when he steps across the rope that killer instinct takes over. I know his partner in crime is just the same and that is what makes them a class apart.

webTitle: Hampshire in need of a miracle

fields.headline: Hampshire in need of a miracle
fields.trailText: There can have been few more worrisome starts to a season in the 116-year history of Northlands Road. The immediate prognosis is not encouraging either, and the move to smart new surrounds at West End probably cannot come soon enough. Anything for a change of outlook.
fields.body:
There can have been few more worrisome starts to a season in the 116-year history of Northlands Road. The immediate prognosis is not encouraging either, and the move to smart new surrounds at West End probably cannot come soon enough. Anything for a change of outlook.

Surrey, led by Mark Butcher's first 100 this term, an undefeated 116, piled on the agony yesterday, setting Hampshire a daunting 393 for victory in five sessions, a target never remotely within their compass.

Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq then took eight wickets and Hampshire, despite Giles White's steadfast 73 and Adrian Aymes's undefeated 43, need a minor miracle to avert another heavy defeat.

The champions were 298 in credit overnight and Adam Hollioake, the captain, soon locked horns with an old adversary, Shane Warne. Little love is lost between the pair since the Australian bowled him for a duck in the Oval Test three years ago though Hollioake made his point in the first innings here.

Warne eventually had him stumped by yards then gave Ali Brown and Ben Hollioake short shrift to raise his championship tally to 36 wickets at 19 apiece. He has not exactly covered himself in glory off the field, however, by stubbing fags out near the rope and launching loud public tirades about the umpiring.

Jimmy Cook is confronted by the exacting challenge of resurrecting the county's batting. A convivial forum was held before play where 100 members aired their views on the current parlous state of affairs. How a line-up that gleaned more batting points than anyone last season can suddenly experience such a paucity in output is hard to fathom, and the fact that it coincides with Cook's arrival is even more perplexing.

The South African, though, commands enormous respect and traces the problem to early season. 'We played a surfeit of games away from home where seamer-friendly pitches are produced to negate Warne. Confidence suffered and we've become tentative. Hard practice, a positive outlook, and minor technical adjustments are the antidote.'

Cook has also highlighted a shortfall in their one-day game, a missing ability to work it around and take short singles. 'Basically, we haven't translated our game plan in both formats to the middle and hit the bad ball,' he said. They need to do so quickly.

fields.headline: Glory boys are sold short
fields.trailText: A fantastic finish and a great result, but how much longer will we tolerate three-day Test matches? It happened at Edgbaston and yesterday's premature end at Lord's was threatened only by fading light.
fields.body:
A fantastic finish and a great result, but how much longer will we tolerate three-day Test matches? It happened at Edgbaston and yesterday's premature end at Lord's was threatened only by fading light.

I lay much of the blame on the Lord's wicket. The strip looked very poor to me, with uneven bounce which made it very difficult for the batsmen. After 21 wickets fell on Friday, I wonder if the pitch-inspectors will be called in. In my judgment they should be, and if this Test was being played at any venue other than headquarters, that would be a formality. We all know the commercial clout wielded by Lord's Tests, but the pitch has not been at all good.

Even the Roses match finished early yesterday. Pitches all over the country seem to be deteriorating and if we want to produce top- class batsmen and bowlers then we need top-class pitches for them to perform on. It's not the first time Lord's has been suspect because I remember Raymond Illingworth bitterly complaining about this wicket when he captained England.

All of which puts Michael Vaughan's performance yesterday into context. His was a superb, mature innings in the most trying circumstances. I remember saying last year that Vaughan should be given a go and some of the more mediocre players of my own generation snorted at my opinion, suggesting I was simply backing another Yorkshireman. Not so - and perhaps those critics might think again. I suggest Vaughan will now get the run he deserves - certainly that his innings yesterday deserved.

Remember, this was his debut at Lord's in a Test. There was a lot riding on his performance and conditions were not in his favour. Credit must go to Michael Atherton for the way he assisted, coaxed and cajoled Vaughan in the afternoon session. I'm sure Atherton must have done quite a lot of talking; a lot of reassuring. Vaughan responded and the stand set up England. They took their chance even if there was a wobble, but comeback boy Dominic Cork and Darren Gough batted well and sensibly to see us home.

Having said that, West Indies disappointed me. They appeared negative, refusing to crowd the bat, and several early chances went through the slip cordon - where just two men were stationed. Vaughan had a couple sneak through there, Atherton escaped once and Hick could have been out within a few balls of arriving at the crease. I think West Indies had enough runs to warrant a real attack early on.

If Vaughan deserves credit with the bat, praise goes to Andy Caddick with the ball. He bowled beautifully on Friday but his performance underlines why I believe the central contracts system is not necessarily a good thing.

Caddick, like myself when I played, is a rhythm bowler. He needs to play, to bowl, to stay in the groove. It might also explain why questions are being asked about the discrepancy between his first- innings performances in Tests, which are ordinary, compared to very good returns in second innings. He needs to bowl, needs to work himself into a rhythm, but how can he do that when he is withdrawn from county cricket by Team England? Not all bowlers are the same. Some need to rest and can slot back into action. My old pal Brian Statham was like that - he didn't need constant action. I fancy Caddick might be better served away from the seclusion and bending his back between Tests.

His performance also demonstrated what a good bowler Caddick is when he pitches the ball on a decent length. He can often look ordinary when he gets frustrated and bowls some two feet short. Not so on Friday.

fields.headline: England bounce back
fields.trailText: 'Who writes your scripts?' a bemused Graham Gooch once asked Ian Botham after a miraculous return to Test cricket. I never discovered the precise answer but I can tell you it's the same bloke used by Dominic Cork.
fields.body:
'Who writes your scripts?' a bemused Graham Gooch once asked Ian Botham after a miraculous return to Test cricket. I never discovered the precise answer but I can tell you it's the same bloke used by Dominic Cork.

In the gloaming at Lord's in front of an enthralled, nail-biting capacity crowd Cork led England to victory by two wickets in the most pulsating finish to a Lord's Test since the 1963 match against the West Indies.

Joining forces with Darren Gough with 28 runs required and two wickets remaining the Derbyshire captain, almost short-circuiting on adrenalin, guided England home. His assault on the hapless Franklyn Rose was breathtaking on a surface where batsmen had been tormented since Thursday tea time. There was a clip for two, then a spectacular pulled six into the grandstand. Next he deposited the wilting Rose over mid-on. Suddenly England sensed they could win again.

Now Cork and Gough, admirably calm and correct in a crisis, opted for singles, often scrambled singles. Despite the Herculean efforts of Courtney Walsh, who took six wickets and his old partner Curtly Ambrose, they took England to their target at 7.03pm - another watershed for English cricket? Who knows? Two leg byes tied the game; then Cork calmly guided the ball down to the Tavern and the celebrations could begin.

This is a game that tantalises, teases and tortures. I guess that's why we watch it. On Friday it sped thrillingly towards its climax. But yesterday we were denied a swift conclusion. It was always going to be agonising and indeed the progress of a match that had suddenly captured the public's imagination (Euro 2000 - what's that? Tim who?) was at times painfully slow; at others painfully frenetic. It was brilliant cricket.

Dank cloud cover and flecks of drizzle kept the groundstaff on the alert. Just 43 minutes of play were possible in the morning; Curtly Ambrose reeled off maidens. If England were to defeat the West Indies it was going to take an awful long time. And to prevent their season from disintegrating they had to win.

But after Friday no-one with any sense was making any predictions except the usual one: so much depends on Atherton. It was soon clear that when the England opener woke yesterday he was excited rather than intimidated by the prospect, the hallmark of a proper Test player. Of course he played and missed at Ambrose but there was no mistaking his resolve.

You could not say the same about Mark Ramprakash. After avoiding a pair by deflecting Walsh wide of gully in the first over of the day, he fell in the fifth without adding to his score. As he attempted to force a shortish ball from Walsh , the ball ricocheted off the inside edge on to his stumps. The bat was crooked as he looked for the ball and he left an agonisingly discon solate figure. His record at Lord's where he plays his county cricket is baffling, 81 runs from 11 innings.

During that first 40 minutes batting looked impossible. Ambrose yielded one run in six overs , a push to mid-on for a single from the 27th ball Atherton had received. Amb-rose passed the outside edge, the inside edge and gradually those knowing smiles gave way to exasperation.

At the other end Walsh was as testing but occasionally offered something to hit. Just before the interruption Atherton punched him square for four, then hooked him to square leg. There were roars of relief from a capacity crowd.

After an extended interval there was little respite especially for Vaughan. He might have been lbw to Walsh; there was a concerted appeal for a caught behind two balls later. Ambrose beat him time and time again. All this before he had scored. Eventually he stroked a straight drive for three from his 29th ball. What torment. Yet throughout Vaughan had given the appearance of calm, that he knew what he was trying to do. This calmness under siege - he had some practise in Johannesburg in the winter - is his greatest asset.

Then imperceptibly the runs started to come. Inevitably this coincided with the removal of Ambrose from the attack; his first thirteen overs cost thirteen runs and four of those were from the luckiest of inside edges from the bat of Vaughan. Obviously England were determined to be aggressive against the support bowlers, to prey on their inexperience. This worked. Vaughan immediately clipped Rose through the onside; Atherton unveiled a handsome cover drive. This pair stole the odd quick single and England were on the move.

Both King and Rose bowled some serious deliveries but they were not mesmeric; there was always the hope of runs and Vaughan took them adroitly. The match was slipping away from the West Indies - England were now 95-1 after 36 overs - so Jimmy Adams had to turn to Walsh again.

Walsh delivered. It was not a spectacular ball, just short of a length outside off stump, but Vaughan nibbled and Jacobs took a straightforward catch. Vaughan's 41 represented untold riches by England's recent standards and has booked his place for the Old Trafford Test. He rarely takes the breath away but he thrives on the occasion. At the moment that's enough.

How would Graeme Hick react to such a taut situation? His second ball from Walsh brought great encouragement to England. He cracked it to the cover boundary off the back foot. His third shaved his off stump. He tried to remain positive but after tea he drove away from his body and presented Lara at first slip with a regulation catch.

At the other end Atherton had been imperturbable, but he was promptly lbw to Walsh after 212 minutes of service. 120-4. Alec Stewart's inclination was to put everyone out their delicious misery swiftly. Not possible against Walsh but when Rose dropped short he twice pulled him imperiously to the mid-wicket boundary.

But Walsh jagged a ball back down the slope and up went umpire Venkat's finger. Three balls later it was in the air again, less justifiably as he gave Craig White caught behind off the inside edge - or his thigh. 140-6. By now Knight was calmed. It had been reported that there was 'no major fracture' of the finger damaged in the field on Friday. It may be broken which would explain why he was unable to attempt forcing strokes.

Knight soon departed edging Rose to the keeper. Ambrose returned from the Pavilion End and at 160 Caddick was patently lbw. Most thought it was all over for England. Dominic Cork most certainly didn't.

webTitle: Cork is as good as his word

fields.headline: Cork is as good as his word
fields.trailText: We can sympathise with Ed Giddins at The Observer - he was jettisoned swiftly by the selectors after two moderate performances - but on balance it is a little tricky to quibble with the decision of the selectors to reinstate Dominic Cork for this astonishing Lord's Test match.
fields.body:
We can sympathise with Ed Giddins at The Observer - he was jettisoned swiftly by the selectors after two moderate performances - but on balance it is a little tricky to quibble with the decision of the selectors to reinstate Dominic Cork for this astonishing Lord's Test match.

When I spoke to Cork a month ago he assured me that he was still chirpy on the field, but that he had matured and that he was ready to return to the Test fold. Well, they always say that. But he was clearly doing more than spinning a line. Self-evidently Cork was ready to come back. He talked of the frustration of knowing that you're good enough, yet being sidelined and the need to seize the chance when it came. We can safely say he's done that as well.

Even before he picked up his bat late yesterday afternoon he had had a brilliant match. By the time he placed it back in his cricket bag he had had an unforgettable one. 'I'm more disciplined now, but still aggressive,' he said. This combination of qualities was the hallmark of Cork's performance with the ball in this match, with the bat he was just inspirational.

His contribution here initially called to mind his remarkable Test debut against the West Indies at Lord's five years ago --7 for 43 and all that. In that match he started as England's first change support bowler, consigned to bowling into the wind or at the wrong end. He ended it as England's number-one strike bowler.

In this game he has not leapfrogged England's other pacemen. Darren Gough in the first innings, Andy Caddick in the second have ensured that they remain in possession of the new ball for the foreseeable future, but his contribution has been immense.

His performance on the first day when the West Indies appeared to be en route to 400 was overshadowed by his stunning innings, but nonetheless it was vital.

For the first three hours of the match the ball declined to swing; batting seemed a gentle occupation. Cork did something about that. For even though the speedster, often a disingenuous device, told us that he was the slowest of England's pace attack, it was Cork who first decided to hit the wicket. This means banging the ball into the pitch hard, rather than bowling pretty away-swingers. Cork can not only swing the ball but he can also bowl skidding bouncers and short balls that discomfort the batsmen.

Cork, rather than Gough or Caddick, had the wit to change tack on day one. Campbell was bounced and was out hooking; Hinds was surprised by several short balls; Jacobs was also out hooking and Cork was commendably quick to bounce Ambrose. Then, as the wickets started to tumble, the ball could be spied swinging and batting was thereafter a struggle for everyone.

Throughout the match Cork offered no easy runs. He hasn't asked the ball to swing too much by pitching on the right-hander's leg stump in pursuit of the miracle ball. In the second innings when the ball was swinging and Caddick was running riot at the other end, he tried nothing too ambitious. When I spoke to Cork a month ago he assured me that he was still chirpy on the field, but that he had matured and that he was ready to return to the Test fold. Well, they always say that. But he was clearly doing more than spinning a line. Self-evidently Cork was ready to come back. He talked of the frustration of knowing that you're good enough, yet being sidelined and the need to seize the chance when it came. We can safely say he's done that as well. Even before he picked up his bat late yesterday afternoon he had had a brilliant match. By the time he placed it back in his cricket bag he had had an unforgettable one. 'I'm more disciplined now, but still aggressive,' he said. This combination of qualities was the hallmark of Cork's performance with the ball in this match, with the bat he was just inspirational. His contribution here initially called to mind his remarkable Test debut against the West Indies at Lord's five years ago --7 for 43 and all that. In that match he started as England's first change support bowler, consigned to bowling into the wind or at the wrong end. He ended it as England's number-one strike bowler. webTitle: Cronje signs up with Max Clifford

fields.headline: Cronje signs up with Max Clifford
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje, South Africa's disgraced cricket captain, is to engage Britain's top PR man Max Clifford to help rebuild his life in the wake of the damaging evidence presented to the King Commission into match- fixing. Cronje is expected to fly to Britain later this month to plot his media campaign.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje, South Africa's disgraced cricket captain, is to engage Britain's top PR man Max Clifford to help rebuild his life in the wake of the damaging evidence presented to the King Commission into match- fixing. Cronje is expected to fly to Britain later this month to plot his media campaign.

The move comes a week after Clifford told The Observer that Cronje - if managed properly - could limit the personal damage and commercially exploit his story in the wake of match-fixing allegations that have torn apart international cricket. A friend of Cronje told The Observer last night: 'Hansie was made aware of the Observer article and decided to get in touch with Max Clifford. He feels he is in the best possible hands and it's not only about money. He's desperate to make the best out of an awful situation.

'Max will represent him wordwide in dealings with TV, radio and the press. Hansie knows he has let down himself, his family and his country. He now has to get on with the rest of his life. Max Clifford has shown it's possible to be viewed in a different light if people are presented properly in the media.'

Cronje has admitted taking money and gifts from bookmakers while denying actually fixing the results of games. Last week, before the commission was adjourned, a bookie's go-between admitted making 180 calls to Cronje during the three-nation one- day competition between South Africa, England and Zimbabwe last winter.

Clifford is not afraid of a tough PR challenge - he even represented fallen American footballer turned Hollywood actor OJ Simpson. Conversely, his 20-year relationship with Muhammad Ali helped present the world's best-loved sporting profile. Clifford was not available for comment last night but told The Observer last week that Cronje could make as much as £500,000 from deals involving books, newspapers and TV interviews.

One of Cronje's supporters - who has also benefited from Clifford's media savvy - is Geoff Boycott, who turned to Clifford during the damaging court case with former lover Margaret Moore.

Boycott said: 'I can't defend what Hansie has done but I like the guy and his actions seem completely out of character. What has happened to him hasn't just affected his cricket career, it's turned his life upside down. I've not been through anything like Cronje but I had a major problem and Max helped me through it and out the other side.'

fields.headline: Depleted Yorkshire falter
fields.trailText: One would be hard-pushed to say that there was an outpouring of emotion around Old Trafford as the home side completed a hat-trick of Roses match victories - their first such sequence this century. The spectators were too thinly scattered for that, following morning rain, and the outcome too predictable. But never mind the rose: this single result has great significance for the 2000 championship. Lancashire surge to within two points of Yorkshire, who have suddenly shown frailty.
fields.body:
One would be hard-pushed to say that there was an outpouring of emotion around Old Trafford as the home side completed a hat-trick of Roses match victories - their first such sequence this century. The spectators were too thinly scattered for that, following morning rain, and the outcome too predictable. But never mind the rose: this single result has great significance for the 2000 championship. Lancashire surge to within two points of Yorkshire, who have suddenly shown frailty.

Yorkshire had given four players to England. But those four represented little of the batting stability that had given the leaders four wins - and no losses - in six games. To capitalise on their pace bowling, Yorkshire's mission had been to occupy the crease and let the runs accumulate. With Darren Lehmann showing the lead, they had done that every time.

But here on a dry pitch they struggled against the spinners. Earlier, in different conditions, they had managed (just) against Hampshire's Shane Warne - but here the left-arm spin of Gary Keedy saw Yorkshire's middle order struggling desperately. In the first innings, a base of 125 for two became 164 all out. In the second, 64 for one became 101 for seven. It was fairly clear there would be no reviving the White Rose when they resumed, just 25 in credit, after an early lunch.

The off-spinner, Gary Yates, soon gave way to Keedy. But of Chris Schofield, the leg-spinner with an England contract, strangely little was seen. He bowled 10 overs in the match to Keedy's 47. A disappointing introduction to Test cricket seems to have knocked him back a bit.

At any rate, Yorkshire had already lost two of their last three wickets before Keedy bowled the day's third over. Consecutive short balls from Mike Smethurst had done the trick, one hooked by Chris Silverwood down fine leg's throat, the other gloved by Ryan Sidebottom. Thereafter, young Paul Hutchinson was impressively composed, for a No 11, against both pace and spin, and it was James Middlebrook - also playing well to this point - who was last out edging a drive.

Lancashire's gathering of the required 47 was illuminated by a classic John Crawley cover drive - and also by a ball later in the same over which, inexplicably left alone, removed Crawley's off-bail. The deed was completed with a Neil Fairbrother six.

Needing consolation, Yorkshire supporters may enjoy a statistic unearthed during the static morning. The Yorkshire four who not only played but also bowled at Lord's - Gough, Hoggard, White and Vaughan - appear to be the first from the county since Bowes, Verity, Mitchell and Barber at Leeds in 1935. Few counties, excluding Surrey in the Fifties, can match that.

fields.headline: Angled bat scores heavily
fields.trailText: Every batting record in the game is in jeopardy, claims the Australian who has put a new angle on the bat.
fields.body:
Every batting record in the game is in jeopardy, claims the Australian who has put a new angle on the bat.

Indeed, Len Richardson says that new records are already being set in Sydney grade cricket, with triple hundreds being scored even in junior games.

There is some confirmation in Kent where, at the Halls club in Dartford, Australian Matthew Wagstaff has scored heavily and introduced the Sommers Angle Drive bat to younger players. 'It does make a difference,' says a club official.

Richardson, a former Sheffield Shield player, made his discovery playing with his son in the back garden. When the bat handle half-broke he realised that the new angle was advantageous. It helped to keep the hands ahead of the blade and the ball on the ground instead of in the air - especially on the drive.

For a drive carrying 20 metres, says Richardson, this converts to half a metre of elevation - the difference between a knee-high catch and the ball being on the ground. Edges into the slips also go lower.

The off-set principle is common in golf putters. But to get over cricket's 'tradition barrier' he needs to get a Test player to use the Angle Drive. In a commercial world that will cost a lot of dollars; and a high-profile player will be nervous at risking such a dramatic change. 'I believe in this idea,' says one English bat maker, 'but it's only chance may be to start with youngsters and grow from there.

The ball is arguably an even more influential item than the bat, and bowlers are always complaining about it. The latest gripe is that some balls are going soft quite quickly, and the company that currently supplies all of the first-game, Dukes, would like to be able to examine such balls - cutting them in half to see if there has been a breakdown in the moulded cork-and-latex centre.

'But we haven't had one back yet,' says a Dukes spokesman. 'Counties are supposed to send back any problem balls, but they can't be bothered. Each ball in a box is in its own small plastic bag with a manufacturing reference number on it, but they take them out of the bags and mix them all around, so that isn't very helpful either.'

Doesn't sound like a very professional game, does it?

webTitle: Midnight's children come out to party

fields.headline: Midnight's children come out to party
fields.standfirst: Radio 1 DJ  Rajesh Mirchandani  wanders off the Mayan tourist trail and discovers the simple delight of a small town letting its hair down at carnival time
fields.trailText: Radio 1 DJ Rajesh Mirchandani wanders off the Mayan tourist trail and discovers the simple delight of a small town letting its hair down at carnival time.
fields.body:
Sometimes the simplest things are the most memorable. Four delicious days of rising with the sun, swimming naked in translucent waters; three nights in a wooden shack on the beach with no electricity, running water or lavatories (it was the sea or the bushes): this was Tulum, the hippy hang out on Mexico's Caribbean coast, the Mayan resort of good karma, where the ancient ruins on the clifftop mark the place the ley lines supposedly cross. It was a fantastic time, but by the end of it our bodies were so caked in layers of salt, sand, suntan lotion and after-sun cream that we thought we'd never be clean again. And it was making us irritable. We needed to move on.

Two hours ride inland on an air-conditioned coach brought us to the dusty village of Coba and the five-star splendour of Villas Archaeologicas. (Such is the prerogative of the budget traveller with healthy plastic back-up. Mind you, at £40 a night, it was hardly a splurge).

The name conjured up an image of faded colonial grandeur. I imagined a rambling Spanish mansion, with cool interiors and peeling plaster. Maybe an overgrown courtyard with a mucky pool, with dark green fronds lapping at dark green water.

In fact, it was a thoroughly modern 40-room Club Med hotel, luxurious yet slightly characterless in a white and terracotta Seventies style. The aesthetics were not uppermost in our minds, though. What we cared about was a shower, a shave and a lavatory.

The guidebook told us Coba was a little-visited place, and the hotel was nearly empty. A group of eight Europeans checked in after us, but the only other guests we saw were a French couple, who constantly played Travel Scrabble and a family of American evangelists. After lunch we watched the evangelist father lead the three gleaming children in Bible study in the restaurant. The hotel is not a reason in itself to come to Coba. People come to see the ruins of the ancient city of the same name, which spread out through the rainforest for about 50 square miles. The entire site is a national park. The road into the village leads to a crocodile-infested lake, then skirts round it to the park entrance and heads off into the rainforest to somewhere bigger, grander.

The buildings in Coba are mainly low-rise concrete. On one side are grubby tourist shops and restaurants. With few customers the waiters spend their days sweeping the spotless floors and watching Mexican soap operas. On the other side are mainly houses, a tortilleria (where we saw a whole family pounding, kneading, rolling and slapping thin circles of dough on to a conveyor belt into the oven) and a concrete basketball court, where the town's teenagers were hanging out.

The heat is so relentless that it seems as though everything is done at half speed. Even shooting a few hoops is apparently done in slow motion.

In the lake lazed a single crocodile: none of the thrashing about I had hoped for, with a tourist or a small animal in its jaws; rather it snoozed languidly in the shallows, seemingly aching for shade.

The crocodiles may seem uninterested, but the dogs are even more listless. When you walk by they stand in the middle of the road staring at you. But they don't bark and run up to you like most dogs. Instead the mangy mutts just yawn and pad lazily away, glassy-eyed, bored. The children, on the other hand, are the most animated I have ever seen. And the place is overrun with them - scrawny, grinning bundles of energy, laughing and chasing you down the road. The dogs are like rats. This place could be where the Pied Piper stopped and set up home. That the children and the dogs are tiny and undernourished is a sure sign that the trickle-down effects of the Mexican eco nomic miracle or the direct benefits of tourism haven't reached the townspeople. It made us feel slightly awkward, knowing that little of the money we spent in the hotel would stay in Coba.

However, such thoughts were far off as we ate dinner by the pool and got slowly drunk. Around us the Bible family were giving thanks for each tortilla, the French couple were running out of Scrabble letters (how many points for 'ennui'?) and the tour group were playing drinking games with tequila, creme de menthe and cheap white wine.

We wandered out of that sanitised environment in search of a bit of air and walked straight into Coba's carnival. Some Mexican towns celebrate the week before Lent in good Catholic tradition, with parades, dances and concerts. Here, everyone gets involved. Excited children were parading through town, dressed in colourful home-made costumes: ballet dancers, ancient Egyptians, Mayan chiefs, even a rabbit. There were six or seven makeshift floats, decorated bicycles and carts mainly pushed along by adults or the bigger children. Like some toothless reptile the parade lumbered through the dark ness, lurching out of the shadows into the startling buzz of a street lamp or the headlights of an accompanying car. One float was a warrior's chariot, with Termenator [sic] written on the side in pen. On another, a brown and yellow tower resembled a giraffe's head, leaning sadly to one side. A cart covered in blue and gold painted cardboard was a royal landau. In it sat the carnival king and queen, he holding a cardboard sceptre and she with a silver foil key to the town. A single mangy pony pulled the cart. So, this really was a one-horse town.

Yes, it was low-key and childish. Yes, it was cheap and makeshift, but the point is that it was something real and alive. It belonged to the town. Unlike the ruined city which is the only Coba that visitors want to know about, unlike our fancy hotel which took from the town but gave little back, this parade was on the town's own terms.

The children were loving it, their round faces shining, mouths wide open, coughing with laughter. The adults were dressed in their finest clothes, proud of their collective efforts and, best of all, we were part of it. It wasn't put on for our benefit, they got nothing from us being there, but they were so friendly towards us that we felt welcome immediately. The children squealed with delight as we took photographs and called out 'ola' one after the other, as though one of them doing it gave courage to the next.

I spoke - if that's how you can describe my faltering juxtaposition of Spanish words - to some of them and they told me what everyone around them was called. I asked when that night's dance started and they told me nine o'clock.

'Pero es muy tarde!' I joked, and when I said they would have to be in bed by then they laughed even more.

The parade ended in the car park, where it had begun, and I smugly thought of the other guests in the hotel: they had no idea what was going on just a few yards from where they were tucking into dessert. They probably weren't interested - most of them were on a one-night stopover as part of an organised archaeological tour, and would be conserv ing their energies for the next day's exploring. Don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to preach. It's fine to admire majestic ruins, but why not also celebrate something full of life which is happening around the corner?

Much later, we went to the 'park' where the town dance was taking place. It was a concrete circle with four concrete paths radiating outwards. A mediocre band played something between mariachi and calypso on a small wooden stage. Disco lights throbbed out of time. About a dozen young couples danced, just as lazily as they went about their daily business, the girls dressed in frills and the boys in smart trousers and shirts. In the shadows around the dancefloor were more people, mainly older. Some were seated at tables drinking and talking, perhaps remembering dances past. Others were just lurking, unsure how to join in. The smaller children - whose enthusiasm and excitement had driven the parade earlier - had gone to bed and had taken their energy with them. The town had worn itself out. There was no more fun to be had.

We got up early the next morning, before the sun was on the lake and headed to the national park. We hired bikes and cycled round the thousand-year-old ruins. They were awe-inspiring. We climbed the main pyramid, Nohoch Mul, which, at 120ft, is the tallest Mayan structure in the the Yucatan peninsula. The top rises elegantly above the rainforest canopy. From up there we could see the lake glinting in the morning sun, the town lying sleepily under a low cloud of dust and the road snaking off into the distance. A few hours later we were there, on a bus heading through the jungle to somewhere bigger, livelier.

The imperious majesty of ancient Coba, dead but not forgotten, was what we imagined before we came; what we took with us was the humanity of a Coba forgotten but not dead, its people existing in the shadow of their predecessors, sluggishly beating out a life under the sun with a sad and gentle grace.

Sometimes the simplest things are the most memorable.

The heat is so relentless that it seems as though everything is done at half speed. Even shooting a few hoops is apparently done in slow motion. In the lake lazed a single crocodile: none of the thrashing about I had hoped for, with a tourist or a small animal in its jaws; rather it snoozed languidly in the shallows, seemingly aching for shade. The crocodiles may seem uninterested, but the dogs are even more listless. When you walk by they stand in the middle of the road staring at you. But they don't bark and run up to you like most dogs. Instead the mangy mutts just yawn and pad lazily away, glassy-eyed, bored. The children, on the other hand, are the most animated I have ever seen. And the place is overrun with them - scrawny, grinning bundles of energy, laughing and chasing you down the road. The dogs are like rats. This place could be where the Pied Piper stopped and set up home. That the children and the dogs are tiny and undernourished is a sure sign that the trickle-down effects of the Mexican eco nomic miracle or the direct benefits of tourism haven't reached the townspeople. It made us feel slightly awkward, knowing that little of the money we spent in the hotel would stay in Coba. However, such thoughts were far off as we ate dinner by the pool and got slowly drunk. Around us the Bible family were giving thanks for each tortilla, the French couple were running out of Scrabble letters (how many points for 'ennui'?) and the tour group were playing drinking games with tequila, creme de menthe and cheap white wine. We wandered out of that sanitised environment in search of a bit of air and walked straight into Coba's carnival. Some Mexican towns celebrate the week before Lent in good Catholic tradition, with parades, dances and concerts. Here, everyone gets involved. Excited children were parading through town, dressed in colourful home-made costumes: ballet dancers, ancient Egyptians, Mayan chiefs, even a rabbit. There were six or seven makeshift floats, decorated bicycles and carts mainly pushed along by adults or the bigger children. Like some toothless reptile the parade lumbered through the dark ness, lurching out of the shadows into the startling buzz of a street lamp or the headlights of an accompanying car. One float was a warrior's chariot, with Termenator [sic] written on the side in pen. On another, a brown and yellow tower resembled a giraffe's head, leaning sadly to one side. A cart covered in blue and gold painted cardboard was a royal landau. In it sat the carnival king and queen, he holding a cardboard sceptre and she with a silver foil key to the town. A single mangy pony pulled the cart. So, this really was a one-horse town. Yes, it was low-key and childish. Yes, it was cheap and makeshift, but the point is that it was something real and alive. It belonged to the town. Unlike the ruined city which is the only Coba that visitors want to know about, unlike our fancy hotel which took from the town but gave little back, this parade was on the town's own terms. The children were loving it, their round faces shining, mouths wide open, coughing with laughter. The adults were dressed in their finest clothes, proud of their collective efforts and, best of all, we were part of it. It wasn't put on for our benefit, they got nothing from us being there, but they were so friendly towards us that we felt welcome immediately. The children squealed with delight as we took photographs and called out 'ola' one after the other, as though one of them doing it gave courage to the next. I spoke - if that's how you can describe my faltering juxtaposition of Spanish words - to some of them and they told me what everyone around them was called. I asked when that night's dance started and they told me nine o'clock. 'Pero es muy tarde!' I joked, and when I said they would have to be in bed by then they laughed even more. The parade ended in the car park, where it had begun, and I smugly thought of the other guests in the hotel: they had no idea what was going on just a few yards from where they were tucking into dessert. They probably weren't interested - most of them were on a one-night stopover as part of an organised archaeological tour, and would be conserv ing their energies for the next day's exploring. Don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to preach. It's fine to admire majestic ruins, but why not also celebrate something full of life which is happening around the corner? Much later, we went to the 'park' where the town dance was taking place. It was a concrete circle with four concrete paths radiating outwards. A mediocre band played something between mariachi and calypso on a small wooden stage. Disco lights throbbed out of time. About a dozen young couples danced, just as lazily as they went about their daily business, the girls dressed in frills and the boys in smart trousers and shirts. In the shadows around the dancefloor were more people, mainly older. Some were seated at tables drinking and talking, perhaps remembering dances past. Others were just lurking, unsure how to join in. The smaller children - whose enthusiasm and excitement had driven the parade earlier - had gone to bed and had taken their energy with them. The town had worn itself out. There was no more fun to be had. We got up early the next morning, before the sun was on the lake and headed to the national park. We hired bikes and cycled round the thousand-year-old ruins. They were awe-inspiring. We climbed the main pyramid, Nohoch Mul, which, at 120ft, is the tallest Mayan structure in the the Yucatan peninsula. The top rises elegantly above the rainforest canopy. From up there we could see the lake glinting in the morning sun, the town lying sleepily under a low cloud of dust and the road snaking off into the distance. A few hours later we were there, on a bus heading through the jungle to somewhere bigger, livelier. The imperious majesty of ancient Coba, dead but not forgotten, was what we imagined before we came; what we took with us was the humanity of a Coba forgotten but not dead, its people existing in the shadow of their predecessors, sluggishly beating out a life under the sun with a sad and gentle grace. Sometimes the simplest things are the most memorable.

fields.headline: Walking on Asia's wild side
fields.standfirst: Joanna Walters finds fear, ghosts and corruption lurking amid the beauty in the Cambodian capital and fear for the future
fields.trailText: Joanna Walters finds fear, ghosts and corruption lurking amid the beauty in the Cambodian capital and fear for the future
fields.body:
There are many exotic spots in the world where old pop stars come, musically, to die. However, Phnom Penh, the filthy, crazy, frightening, beautiful capital of Cambodia, is not usually one of them.

And yet it is here, overlooking the mighty Mekong River in a bar with ceiling fans shifting the sticky night air that we find... well, who exactly? His name is Duncan Kilburn and he owns the bar. Cambodian women in long silk dresses are serving beer to sweaty expats and the odd backpacker who's swerved off the trail between Thailand and Vietnam. Most people between 25 and 50 will have heard of his band, the Psychedelic Furs. Ah yes. Part of the quintessential, new wave British sound of the early Eighties.

Kilburn played saxophone. Twenty years on, the balding, frayed 44-year-old has washed up in Phnom Penh of all places. He admits who he is and agrees to tell his story - and talk about Cambodia.

It is midnight. There are lizards on the wall and Lancashire hotpot on the menu. Prostitutes are loitering outside and beggars, maimed by the millions of mines strewn across this shattered land, crouch on the potholed pavement.

Kilburn is strumming the guitar and singing or, more accurately, strangling Lou Reed's 'Walk on the Wild Side'. It is an appropriate number because Phnom Penh(pronounced P'nom Pen) is generally described as the Wild East, the final frontier of lawlessness in Asia.

The city no longer goes to sleep to the sound of Pol Pot's death squads murdering innocent citizens and personal quarrels are less likely to be settled by hand grenade than they were a few years ago. But the peace is fragile; poverty and corruption are the norm. The atmosphere is edgy. It is a toss-up whether residents are more likely to be run over by a petty official's limo, bought with siphoned foreign aid, or mugged by a bloke with an AK-47.

And all this within a few yards of the glittering royal palace and ancient temples - surrounded by squalor but magnificent enough to remind you how far this once-powerful civilisation has fallen.

Every moped-taxi driver has a tale about how half his family were wiped out in the mid-Seventies when the Khmer Rouge emptied Phnom Penh in two weeks. They herded everyone off to the 'killing fields' to engage in a catastrophic experiment in collectivism and despotism that left about two million people dead - a fifth of the population of Cambodia.

It was at about this time that Kilburn and a few mates formed The Furs in distant London. The band burned briefly but brightly and was big enough to be supported by U2. While Pol Pot rampaged, Kilburn was half a planet away, touring New York and mingling with Iggy Pop and David Bowie at the height of the Furs' success.

Vietnam invaded Cambodia and ended Pol Pot's dictatorship in 1980. Alcohol, stress and drug-tinged scandal put an acrimonious end to the Psychedelic Furs in 1982.

Kilburn has not seen his band-mates since. After the split, he reverted to his day job of computer programmer. He was posted to Hong Kong, where he slipped into conventionalism and eventually became an entrepreneur. He opened a bar called the Globe, then ventured forth, seeking untapped markets. This led him to Cambodia, where he opened his bar and restaurant, also called the Globe. He is convinced the prospect of political stability will bring tourists and investors flocking and make his fortune.

So it is that on a mosquito-filled night in Phnom Penh towards the end of the rainy season, Kilburn is to be found giving one of his regular little gigs. He follows the Lou Reed number with one of his own, The Furs' 'Femme Fatale'. Appropriate again, given Cambodia's stomach-churning sex industry. A 10-minute moped ride from the Globe will find you in a flesh market thinly disguised as a disco. It's all here in Phnom Penh, but with a little less neon than Bangkok. Man wants 10-year-old boy for sex? Just pay a few extra dollars to the shoeshine waifs who flit around the pavement cafes.

Back at the Globe, Kilburn puts down his guitar and wanders on to the balcony to observe this unhinged capital.

'The number one law in Cambodia is there is no law,' he says. 'This feels like the last Asian outpost of anarchy.'

He points to the dusty, potholed road below, the only thing between the Globe and the vast, palm-lined Mekong River gliding by on its way from Tibet to Vietnam and the South China Sea. 'Look around and what do you see?' he asks. Answer: A sleek Toyota coupé with smoked windows and no markings cruising along a battered scrap of street.

'People driving smart cars with no number plates,' he says. 'This is one of the poorest countries on earth, with no economic structure to speak of. Where do you think those come from?' Misused aid, diverted into the pockets of government cronies.

Sure, there's been an official crackdown on the trade in surplus arms. It is apparently no longer so easy to buy grenades, automatic guns and rocket launchers in a market for little more than the price of bananas. And the octogenarian 'ganja grannies', who used to sell cannabis on open stalls have had to become more clandestine. Cambodia has seen off the Khmer Rouge and the vulnerable regime is struggling for respectability.But not an awful lot has changed beneath the surface.

'You can buy heroin in the drugstore, and there is a big under-age sex trade,' says Kilburn. When I arrived in 1997 you could buy a hand grenade for $5 [£3], and ordinary folk carried guns. If you are caught with such things now they will put you in prison... at least until you find $10 to buy your way out.'

Corruption is, he says, a fact of life. He won't go into details, but he and his wife and young son were forced to flee to Malaysia and lie low for a while in 1998. Five men had burst into the Globe and held machine guns to his wife's head in some unspecified, mafia-type property dispute involving an ex-Minister with enormous underworld power.

Only temporarily deterred, the family came back. Kilburn is now exploring new opportunities for business on Cambodia's unspoilt coastline, and inland at the ramshackle temple ruins around spectacular Angkor Wat - one of the seven wonders of the world.

He never made a fortune from the Furs, although he still receives modest royalty cheques, including one for £200 the week before from sales of the band's best-known album, Pretty in Pink . His hope that Cambodia will join the tourist trail in the new millennium is by no means guaranteed, however. Much of the country was out of bounds to foreigners until recently, except to mine-clearance experts.

Even now diplomatic staff are warning their expat citizens, off the record, that the shaky peace could blow apart with the impending show trials of two of the late Pol Pot's henchmen. Thousands of former Khmer Rouge have been brought out of exile on the Thai border, given amnesty and absorbed into the Cambodian establishment in the past few years. But a few ringleaders, who failed to remain inconspicuous, will face the music. As one expat said sagely: 'Never be the last to be caught.'

Due in the dock soon are ruthless commander Ta Mok, 'The Butcher', and torture master 'Deuch' of the infamous Tuol Sleng detention centre, now a desolate museum, with row after row of soul-chilling photographs of the old regime's victims - before and after torture.

Even Prime Minister Hun Sen, ex-Khmer Rouge, defector to Vietnam and now a moderate, though autocratic, leader, is caught up in allegations that his wife was involved in the murder of a beautiful Cambodian actress, reportedly Hun Sen's mistress.

To cap it all, one of the most stabilising factors in Cambodia today, the arch-survivor and political chameleon King Norodom Sihanouk, who has been in and out of government for more than 40 years, threatens to shatter the jittery calm by dying and pro voking a power struggle. He lies frail with cancer in the royal palace. Meanwhile, around the corner, another of Phnom Penh's bizarre residents sits in the legendary Foreign Correspondents' Club waiting for Sihanouk's epochal death so that he can write the final chapter of his history of modern Cambodia.

Al Rockoff is the renowned American war photographer best remembered in recent times via his big-screen alter ego John Malkovich, who portrayed him in the movie The Killing Fields . Rockoff was the photographer who tried, but failed, to fake a passport for Dith Pran, the Cambodian assistant of New York Times journalist Sydney Schanberg, when the Khmer Rouge took Phnom Penh. The real Rockoff apparently returns to Phnom Pehn regularly. Fans say he needs to research his book, local cynics scoff that he is a sad has-been, still wallowing in atrocious/glorious war memories.

One FCC regular says: 'He'll bend your ear about his Khmer Rouge days if he's in the mood, has a few beers or a busty blonde for an audience. But don't ask him about the Killing Fields film - he says it's inaccurate.'

Rockoff certainly looks the stereotypical, cantankerous veteran of Camodia's gory/glory years. The craggy, aloof face; the long, Tolkienesque beard and straggly hair; the khaki flak jacket and battered camera bag.

He glances up with a suspicious scowl.

The Observer : 'Mr Rockoff? Would you mind having a chat with The Observer ?'

He would, mind, apparently. 'I'm a very private person. I'm just a photographer and I'm here taking pictures, not doing some journalism lark,' he growls.

The Observer : 'Just interested to hear your view of what is likely to happen in Cambodia...'

There is a moment when it looks as though he may use his camcorder as a cosh. Pause, sneer: 'I'm not a tour guide.'

He's obviously not in the mood for talking of 'his Khmer Rouge days'. Fine. Forget it. There are many places where old war horses come, photographically, to die. Phnom Penh is definitely one of them.

Travel file

Joanna Walters travelled to Cambodia via Vietnam. She flew to Bangkok with EVA Air of Taiwan, which flies from Heathrow three times a week and offers a London-Bangkok return fare from £462 (excluding tax). She went from Bangkok to Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, with Thai Airways, £213 return. Her bus ride from Ho Chi Minh City to Phnom Penh cost £10 return. She stayed in guest houses costing a maximum of £6 a night (en suite).

For direct travel from the UK to Cambodia: Thai Airways is offering flights from £670 return in July, flying London to Phnom Penh via Bangkok. Royal Air Cambodge flies from Bangkok to Siem Reap , the base village for visiting Angkor Wat and its temples. Bangkok-Siem Reap return fares start at £195 this summer.

For package holidays, consult a travel agent or the Association of Independent Tour Operators (020 8607 9080). Operators with Cambodia packages include Asian Journeys. Tailor-made packages start from £1,500 with flights and three-star accommodation (01604 234855).

Guerba has 'The Road to Angkor', a seven-day tour. Get yourself to Ho Chi Minh City or Phnom Penh and pick up the tour: it costs £335 for accommodation and guides (01373 826611). Explore Worldwide has a Vietnam and Cambodia three-week trip in September for £1,575 inclusive. Visas and inoculations required.

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: The Micronesia states reported 672 cases of cholera and six deaths between the first week of May and 7 June. Outbreaks commonly occur in overcrowded communities with poor sanitation and lack of safe water. Travellers should take particular care with food and water. If drinking water is not from a known safe source then it is best avoided or made safe by boiling or purifying. Cooked food should be served piping hot, and raw or undercooked meat, seafood and unpasteurised dairy products avoided. Raw fruit and vegetables should be peeled or cooked before consumption. Remember, peel it, boil it, cook it or forget it! Cholera immunisation is not available in the UK and not recommended as a means of protection.

fields.standfirst: Venus Beauty | A Walk on the Moon | Le Beau Serge | The Searchers
fields.trailText: Venus Beauty | A Walk on the Moon | Le Beau Serge | The Searchers
fields.body:
Venus Beauty
(1998, 15, Tartan, VHS/Retail, rental)

Written and directed by Tonie Marshall, this witty, touching adult movie is one of the best French pictures of the last few years. The beguiling Nathalie Baye plays Angèle, a 40-year-old divorcée, one of three assistants in a small Parisian beauty parlour, the Vénus Beauté salon, that pampers the faces and bodies of its mainly female patrons and hears their confessions. This comforting, pastel-coloured place that helps fight off the ravages of time is a haven from the harsh world outside, where the tough, promiscuous Angèle goes from one bad relationship to another. Avoiding easy cynicism, the film has a warm, honest, realistic approach to life and relationships. It's excellently performed by Baye, Bulle Ogier (the salon's soignée manager) and others, and among various guest appearances there's a charming contribution by the director's mother, the great Micheline Presle.

A Walk on the Moon
(1999, 15, Paramount, VHS/Rental)

Produced by Dustin Hoffman, this fine directorial debut by actor Tony Goldwyn is set at a modest Jewish holiday resort in the Catskills where the mother, wife (Diane Lane), 14-year-daughter (Anna Paquin) and seven-year-old son of hard-working, frustrated New York television repair man (Liev Schreiber) are spending the summer of 1969. This is the year of the Apollo 11 moon landing and Woodstock, the time of the Vietnam War and its counterculture, and these events impinge on the family's life in funny, revealing and sometimes painful ways. Rarely contrived, only occasionally glib, this small gem of a movie is accurate in its evocation of the recent past and honest in its confronation of potentially tragic crises.

Le Beau Serge
(1959, 12, Second Sight, VHS/Retail)

With this milestone debut (largely financed by his wife), the 27-year-old Cahiers du Cinéma critic Claude Chabrol launched the French New Wave, and he immediately followed it with a companion piece Les Cousins , also released this week. In the first a Parisian student (Jean-Claude Brialy) returns to a bleak, acutely observed village to save a distressed, alcoholic boyhood friend (Gérard Blain). In the second - an erotic, highly mannered version of the town-mouse, country-mouse story - decent provincial lad Blain comes to study in Paris and falls under the baleful influence of Brialy, his sophisticated cousin. Both movies are photographed in black-and-white by Henri Decaë, a key New Wave figure who shot the first films of Louis Malle and François Truffaut.

The Searchers
(1956, PG, Warner, DVD/Retail)

On DVD at last in the appropriately named Timeless Classics series, John Ford's initially derided Western is as towering as the buttes and mesas of Monument Valley that provide its setting. As the embittered Civil War veteran searching for his niece, kidnapped by the Indians, John Wayne gives his greatest performance and the movie has influenced people as different as Buddy Holly and Martin Scorsese.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today
fields.body:
 Dodge the flying fish and get chased by affable bears at the Hat Fair day-long picnic, which will feature street theatre, commedia dell'arte performers and circus tricksters. Oram's Arbour, Winchester. Phone 01962 849841. Free. From midday.

 Eat yourself silly in the beautiful surroundings of Wrest Park Gardens, Silsoe, Bedfordshire. Among the huge fountains will be a host of specialist suppliers of gourmet food and experts who will give talks and demonstrations throughout the day. Entertainment for children. Adults £4, Children £2.50. Phone 01525 860152.

 Watch a procession of African chiefs and queens as part of the Durbar, a traditional time of celebration and communication for African peoples, shared for the first time with Londoners on Tooting Common. Music features visiting artists. Free. 12 - 7. Phone 020 7720 2202.

 Welsh artists wrestle with their national identity and produce some interesting work along the way, including two portraits of Dylan Thomas and dramatic representations of the Industrial Revolution, in Painting the Dragon at the National Museum and Gallery, Cardiff. 10am - 5pm. Free. Phone 029 2039 7951.

 Hear what some of the one million children living in Scotland have to say about their families, friends and communities in Listen! A Million Children's Voices in Scotland at the Museum of Scotland, Edinburgh. The display is presented by Save the Children to mark children's living history at the turn of the millennium. Noon - 5pm. Adults £3, children free. Phone 0131 247 4219.

 Learn how to write with quill pens on parchment and wax tablets while listening to a musical extravaganza tracing the development of music and song from early Latin chant to the Middle Ages at Orford Castle, Suffolk. Noon - 5pm. Adults £3.50, children £1.80. Phone 01394 450472.

 Remind yourself what Australia was all about long before the Olympics hype in Australia Dreaming, an exhibition of contemporary Aboriginal art at The Commonwealth Institute, Kensington, London. 10am - 5pm. Free. Phone 020 7603 4535.

 Try to beat a world record at Dance Day 2000 at G-Mex, Manchester. Wayne Sleep will teach a tap routine to as many people as want to join in to try to beat the current record of 6,776 people. 9am - 4pm. £5 fee goes to dance charity. Phone 0161 832 9000.

 Rode Bird Gardens, near Bath, will welcome a flock of a different kind today as members of the Parrot Society UK descend on the 17-acre garden to swap tips and answer the public's queries. The gardens' usual inhabitants are currently to be seen feeding babies and laying eggs. 10am - 5pm. Adults, £5.70, kids £3.20. Phone 01373 830326.

 Bring the Cogitating Numbskull to life in Terry Gilliam's Devious Devices show at Summerlee Heritage Park's Ironworks Gallery, Coatbridge. The Monty Python animator invited leading artists to create mechanical automata that can be operated by the viewer. 10am - 5pm. Free. Phone 01236 431261.

webTitle: Just a dash of erotica, please

fields.headline: Just a dash of erotica, please
fields.standfirst: Sandra Deeble samples a writing course with D.M. Thomas in the role of a dualist priest
fields.trailText: Sandra Deeble samples a writing course with D.M. Thomas in the role of a dualist priest
fields.body:
It was too good to resist: D.M. Thomas top of the bill on a creative writing course in south-west France. As a teenager, certain passages of The White Hotel became as familiar to me as bits of The Railway Children had been when I was a child, so the thought of spending a week with this man in La Roane was, to say the least, intriguing.

I was there, along with about 20 others, for D.M.'s course with high hopes of being stimulated into writing lyrically, or even erotically, to relax, to flex my muscles holistically, and to pick up a smattering of local history: namely stories about the antics of the Cathars, the Crusaders and the troubadours.

Our first lesson didn't disappoint. Ingeniously, and with the polish of the most experienced corporate facilitator, in order to introduce us to Catharism, D.M. 'Call me Don' Thomas took on the mantle of a twelfth-century Cathar priest. Oh behave. I don't mean he actually put on a costume, although he probably would have got dressed up had the robes been available. No, he just did everything in the manner of one, to get us into the swing of things.

Not that it was particularly swinging, mind you. The Cathars believed in the dualism of good and evil. And, following the original teachings of Mazdaism, rejected all things material. This meant a life of non-violence, no punishment, no carnal pleasures, and strict vegetarianism.

It was held over Easter at La Roane, a new 'alternative' holiday centre near the village of Saint Antonin Noble Val, about one hour's drive north-east of Toulouse, set up by Nigel Shamash - founder of the holistic haven, Cortijo Romero, in Spain. At Easter and during August, Stella West-Harling and Luan Fitzgerald-Moore, of the Ashburton Centre in Devon, run their own holidays there.

Like the Ashburton Centre, which runs courses in organic vegetarian cookery, the meals at La Roane were nearly always vegetarian and delicious. Breakfasts were a good mix of virtuously healthy fruit salad, cereal and yoghurt with a coffee and pain au chocolat chaser. Lunch started with a delicious soup, and dinners ended with the most pleasing puddings, including some old Anglo-French favourites: chocolate mousse and banoffee pie. Local wine flowed. All meals were help-yourself style, and volunteers were welcomed to lay the tables and help with clearing up. When it came to accommodation, sharing was mandatory.

Mornings started with optional Yoga and T'ai Chi, in what was known as the 'meditation room' in the barn, at a civilised 8.30. There was a Shiatsu class after breakfast, followed by a more 'getting started'-style creative writing class run by Victoria Field, a writer and freelance arts consultant, who had recently married D.M. Thomas. At Easter, the weather hadn't quite got there, albeit for a couple of hot days when some of our party gathered around the pool on sun loungers with the languid ease of time-share veterans. Nevertheless, there were many opportunities to find a quiet spot - in a hammock, on a swing, or just in a patch of daisies - to muse, stare into space and scribble. When it rained, we huddled around a wood burner, ate creme eggs and tried our hand at albas, sestinas and villanelles, inspired by the trobadors and trobairitz, but also seeking help from the likes of Ezra Pound and Pushkin. (And, when D.M. Thomas started to recite Pushkin in Russian - if you remember the scene from A Fish Called Wanda - I was Jamie Lee Curtis to his John Cleese).

Day trips were undertaken in a convoy of cars to enjoy the hilltop bastide towns: which were once, long ago, the mini-medieval Milton Keyneses and Stevenages of the South West, in that they were new builds for Cathars who had lost their homes after a long battle against Simon de Montfort's crusaders. There is a whole bastide trail to enjoy at your leisure: we only had time to visit Penne, Bruniquel, Castelnau de Montmiral and Cordes. These are all swoony, wisteria-clad, shuttered, cobbled wonders.

Improvements at La Roane are under way. with Nigel Shamash transforming the cowshed into a sauna, and a treehouse is being created to provide genuinely alternative accommodation. In August, Victoria Field is returning, and next year, Hanif Kureishi and Hugo Williams are on the programme.

 Sandra Deeble travelled to La Roane with Air France (0845 084 5111). A week at Easter or during August costs £425 (twin sharing) including courses, full board and day trips. Booking through The Ashburton Centre: 01364 652 784

fields.headline: Travel News
fields.trailText: Open House for the summer
fields.body:
Open House for the summer

The Palace of Westminster is opening its doors to tour groups this summer. This will be the first time that visitors have had access to the chambers of the Houses of Parliament: previously members of the public have had to seek the sponsorship of their MP to attend the visitor's gallery. The tours, led by London Blue Badge guides, are an experiment for the duration of Parliament's summer recess.

Visitors will be able to walk through both chambers and Westminster Palace, but not Big Ben. 'It is quite a complicated route because the Palace was not designed for large groups of people,' said visitor manager, Michael McDonald. 'On a normal day,' he continued, 'we get about 1,000 visitors when the House is in session, but we think this figure could double.'

However visitors will not enjoy the privileges of either peers or MPs. 'It is a long-standing rule that unelected members of the public are forbidden to sit on the benches,' said McDonald. Tourists will also miss the Mace, which only appears on the House of Commons' table when Parliament is in session.

If the trial is a success there are plans to continue the tours next year. The Palace will be open from 7 August until 16 September and tickets are only available in advance from Ticketmaster (020 7344 9966) and may not be bought on the day. A charge of £3.50 covers the guide's fee, and tickets are on sale now.

Climb every European mountain

A British mountaineer sets off on 11 July for the final stage of a world record-breaking attempt to climb the highest peak in each European country in the shortest period of time.

Rod Baber, 29, will be tackling the final three peaks on his hit-list, having already conquered the highest mountains in 44 European countries.

Baber is scheduled to complete his attempt in a total time of just two-and-a-half years: the current record stands at eight years. However, the remaining peaks will provide some of his most difficult challenges. He will be guided up Mount Daravica in Kosovo to avoid land-mines, and will also have an armed guard on Mount Ararat in Turkey, while Mount Shkara in Georgia has only ever been climbed twice before.

Baber has already scaled , among others, Mount Olympus in Greece, Mont Blanc in France, the UK's Ben Nevis, the treacherous Hvanndalshnukar in Iceland and the slightly flatter Vaalserberg in the Netherlands. He has also climbed Castelgandolfo in the Vatican City.

To follow Baber's progress into the Guinness Book of Records log onto the website of his sponsor, AltaVista.

The address is www.altavista.co.uk and it will soon feature a link to the AltaVista Europe 47 Challenge homepage.

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: Barcelona, Everyman City Guides, £9.99
fields.trailText: Barcelona, Everyman City Guides
fields.body: Shiny on the outside, glossy on the inside, and divided thematically, this slim guide is a time-efficient way to navigate the city. Its rapid fire approach, however, is at odds with a relaxed city such as Barcelona, whose smaller pleasures and grander sights exist to be savoured. The attractive Eixample area, for example, is dismissed as 'monotonous' and the extraordinary Fundacio Joan Miro merits little more than a footnote. The authors bring detail and warmth to the attractions that do make it , however. A fine weekend guide.

webTitle: The fiesta never stops in Galway Bay

fields.headline: The fiesta never stops in Galway Bay
fields.standfirst: Robert Yates on the 'art for fun's sake' festival
fields.trailText: Robert Yates on the 'art for fun's sake' festival.
fields.body:
'You've got what ?' This was the most polite response to the news that yes, I - Englishman and Gaelic Games ignoramus - had got hold of tickets to the biggest Gaelic football match in years, a derby final between the neighbouring counties of Mayo and Galway. 'And I thought,' added my green-eyed drinking buddy, 'that you were meant to be in town covering the arts ?'

Indeed, but my, ahem, elastic approach to what qualifies as 'arts' is, I argued, merely in keeping with the spirit of the Galway Arts Festival: all-inclusive, accessible and always open to suggestion. As a festival ambition, this is not unique - in fact, contemporary arts festivals fall over themselves to state their commitment to both 'the street' and 'high art'. The difference is that in Galway - now a summer fixture, this year it runs from 18 to 30 July - the ambition is realised.

You do find yourself moving from a pub session - or singalong - to a play from the Reunion Islands; or from a 'street encounter' with a French troupe all dressed as 12ft John Majors (maybe, like Jerry Lewis, Major has found cult status in France) to a season of Irish-American movies. The Film Fleadh runs concurrently with the Arts Festival and Galway, now home to the Irish Film Board, is becoming a sharp player on the film circuit. Last year local boy made good Gab-riel Byrne was the guest of honour, and it was typical of the festival that the centrepiece of the Byrne season should be a free public interview at the town hall.

Galway City is booming, as locals will tell you. It has a healthy self-image - go-ahead and young (with a large student population, thanks to University College Galway). You wouldn't say all signs of the new prosperity look good - not many of the developments on the outskirts would trouble architectural awards. But the body of the town, centred on Shop and Quay Streets, retains the feel of a handsome, large village - one with a disproportionate amount of places to eat and drink. On a July weekend, as one alfresco jamboree merges into another, the two streets become one large drinking gallery.

Galway in the summer sees its function as amusement - and why not? The arts festival kicks off a trio of annual events; it's followed by the Galway races in August - just about the best place to lose both your money and innocence, is the local consensus - and the Oyster Festival in September. (If you're in Galway any other time and fancy oysters, try Moran's at Kilcolgan, just south of the city.) At the arts festival, you get the feeling that entertainers are as much there to amuse themselves as to fulfil a contract. So playwright Martin McDonagh hangs out for the craic , Gabriel Byrne, wanders around, exciting the teens, and 'friends of the festival', the Undertones, much-missed purveyors of power pop, give an impromptu session in a pub.

As for the football game, it was a pleasure and education - and came complete with an artistic finale. At the end, the triumphant Mayo captain, hoisted on the shoulders of teammates and fans - I thought this sort of thing only happened in comic strips? - launched into a highly purple speech, which ran through the hundred and one virtues of the famous county of Mayo ('skill, resolution, best-looking girls' etc.) I, by now a committed fan of Galway, was not so pleased, until my gracious hosts reminded me that the best way to forget was to throw a party. (Makes more sense than that old English, post-match sport of throwing a chair.)

That night, the annual Macnas Parade - a a torch-lit fiesta, dominated by ghostly figures whose business it was to eat children - took over Galway's centre. The afternoon's game was forgotten, and the kids were eventually returned - whether their revelling parents wanted them or not.
