On a July weekend, as one alfresco jamboree merges into another, the two streets become one large drinking gallery. Galway in the summer sees its function as amusement - and why not? The arts festival kicks off a trio of annual events; it's followed by the Galway races in August - just about the best place to lose both your money and innocence, is the local consensus - and the Oyster Festival in September. (If you're in Galway any other time and fancy oysters, try Moran's at Kilcolgan, just south of the city.) At the arts festival, you get the feeling that entertainers are as much there to amuse themselves as to fulfil a contract. So playwright Martin McDonagh hangs out for the craic , Gabriel Byrne, wanders around, exciting the teens, and 'friends of the festival', the Undertones, much-missed purveyors of power pop, give an impromptu session in a pub. As for the football game, it was a pleasure and education - and came complete with an artistic finale. At the end, the triumphant Mayo captain, hoisted on the shoulders of teammates and fans - I thought this sort of thing only happened in comic strips? - launched into a highly purple speech, which ran through the hundred and one virtues of the famous county of Mayo ('skill, resolution, best-looking girls' etc.) I, by now a committed fan of Galway, was not so pleased, until my gracious hosts reminded me that the best way to forget was to throw a party. (Makes more sense than that old English, post-match sport of throwing a chair.) That night, the annual Macnas Parade - a a torch-lit fiesta, dominated by ghostly figures whose business it was to eat children - took over Galway's centre. The afternoon's game was forgotten, and the kids were eventually returned - whether their revelling parents wanted them or not.

fields.headline: Waves where Britannia still rules
fields.standfirst: Proud naval traditions live on at Dartmouth, but  Vic Marks  finds it can be a haven for landlubbers too
fields.trailText: Proud naval traditions live on at Dartmouth, but Vic Marks finds it can be a haven for landlubbers too.
fields.body:
Those naval boffins of old were not that stupid. They didn't set up their training college at Grimsby or Hartlepool, but on the idyllic south coast of Devon at Dartmouth. There the commanders, if not the busy young officers, could luxuriate above a picturesque little harbour and a wide estuary that carves through the gentle rolling hills of the South Hams.

Dartmouth has always been a cosy haven for seafaring folk. It remains the home of the last naval training college in the country; just up the river, at Totnes, Pete Goss has constructed his elegant monster of a catamaran and it is still the base for Britain's largest fleet of crab fishermen. And of course it is a magnet for the increasing band of well-to-dos for whom yachting is serious fun.

Not surprising, then, that the best way to view Dartmouth is from a boat, which was my intention, but it was wet and windy so the chance to take to a dinghy was spurned.

I soon realised that there was plenty of scope for sailing without going out on a stony-grey sea. The estuary opens out three miles up the river at Dittisham, a wonderful rich man's playground with moorings for hundreds of yachts. They are overlooked by lush woodland, some of which hides the old home of Agatha Christie, Greenway Mansions. But this is more Swallows and Amazons territory than An Appointment with Death . There I could pretend to be a yachtie while waiting on the pontoon to be put-putted out to a 30-footer for a sundowner.

For landlubbers, Dartmouth still has something. For walkers there is easy access to coastal paths. From Dartmouth Castle, which stands proudly at the head of the estuary, there is a simple circular walk out to Blackstone Point (no more than four or five miles). Within a couple of minutes you are among grazing sheep, down leafy, overgrown, trouser-drenching lanes with access to a secluded little beach. For an even gentler stroll there are the gardens of Coleton Fishacre , which is across the river beyond Kingswear. The house was built by the D'Oyly Carte family in the Twenties and is now a National Trust property. Its garden doubles as a maze, so high are the rhododendrons that separate the pathways.

Dartmouth still craves the well-off seeking respite from the cities. There are many upmarket shops with inevitable names such as D'art Gallery, shops selling fashionable sailing gear that few actually sail in, another dealing exclusively in Simon Drew greetings cards, plus many craft and pot shops. A good base is The Little Admiral Hotel, tucked away and recently refurbished.

There are plenty of good restaurants. Hooked is one of them and the only dedicated fish restaurant in the town. It is excellent and the proprietor, Mark Coxon, admits: 'Oh yes, we welcome the Dinkies [Double Income, No Kids] here.' But the visitors are not all Dinkies. Many strolled around the little harbour enjoying pasties.

Overlooking the town is the naval college, still a major source of work. It gives guided tours and hosts conferences. The grandiose 1905 red-brick building is an eye-opener to non-public school visitors, with its high chapel, quarter deck (a great hall) and Senior Gunroom (a dining room). There is also a good museum.

The guide reveals the lawn where Prince Philip first met his future bride, who was then 14. More interesting to me was the fact that the college was open to tourists, as well as to officers from almost every navy in the world. They all pay, you see. It isn't only farmers who have had to diversify in the West Country.

Fact file

The Little Admiral Hotel, (01803 832572).

Single room £45-£60, double £80-£120.

Hooked , Higher Street (01803 832022).

Royal Naval College tours from 6 August (01803 834 224).

Coleton Fishacre (01803 752 466). Open daily. Entry £4.70

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText:
On the right track

A train journey through the Rockies that allows you to get off and sleep in stationary bed could be just the thing for those in two minds about the idea of a long train holiday. Safari Canada has arranged nine night trips from Calgary to Vancouver that include two days' travel on the luxury Rocky Mountaineer train from Banff to Vancouver. The scenery and its wildlife, including eagles and black bears, can be viewed through the train's glass observation dome. After spending the day on the train, you stay in a hotel in Kamloops. The rest of the trip includes three nights in the resort of Whistler, two in Calgary and two in Banff to sample the hot springs and lakes. The price tag of £2,100 includes scheduled flights, three-star hotels, train meals and four days' car hire in Calgary and Banff. Under-12s travel half price. Call 020 7740 1221.

Viva Verdi!

Next year will see the centenary of the death of the Italian composer Giuseppe Verdi, writes Stephen Pritchard. Travel for the Arts has prepared a year-long selection of tours taking in some of the most important commemorative events both in Verdi's homeland and in the world's great opera houses, including New York, Vienna and Munich. A guest lecturer will accompany each tour, which includes tickets to world-class performances. For details call 020 7483 4466.

Heidi and seek

Holidays in Swiss farm chalets can give parents the option of children's entertainment that doesn't revolve around bouncy castles and face painting. Inntravel is offering trips to the Lake Lucerne region with accommodation in apartments on farms. The farm owners are happy to let children play at being Heidi by helping with milking or other activities. . The farmhouses are all in the mountain village of Sorenberg, making them ideal bases for walking tours of the area. Suggested routes are clearly marked and are designed to be easy; most are liberally dotted with cafes. Each apartment is self-catering which is an advantage in expensive Switzerland. The trips are self-drive and crossing is by hovercraft from Dover to Calais or Folkestone to Boulogne. The price for two adults and three children, including accommodation and crossing, is from £524. Call 01653 629010.

webTitle: A top hotel boss reveals all

fields.headline: A top hotel boss reveals all
fields.standfirst:
Parrot Cay, Turks & Caicos Islands
Michel Neutelings, Managing Director
fields.trailText:
Parrot Cay, Turks & Caicos Islands

Michel Neutelings, Managing Director
fields.body:
Any famous guests?
Many of our guests are Presidents and chief executives of companies - we have many people from the Forbes billionaires' list. We're also popular with Hollywood stars, fashion designers and pop stars: Paul McCartney is a regular. They come for the privacy: there is nothing on the island but the hotel.

That sounds like a wonderful place to work.
It is very nice, but the isolation can be difficult. Everything has to come from the States, such as construction materials and food, although the seafood is local. I have 146 members of staff, of 14 nationalities, and we sometimes get together for a party, otherwise they'd go crazy. They have their computers for email and we organise events for them. We have a deal with Club Med on another island, where they can go to have a break.

Any unusual requests?
Once, when we were fully booked, a famous American film star was desperate to stay. He went to the far end of the island and pitched a tent for himself and insisted on living there, so we gave him butler service and put up a four-poster bed for him. The butler would cook his food and light his fire.

What do your guests like doing?
They just come here to relax. We have a huge pool and a holistic spa called Shambala. Yoga is very big now - every class is full. We also do Balinese massage and Thai massage, which is more stretchy. If guests really want to go out we can organise a boat to a secluded beach which they are guaranteed to have to themselves. Other islands are nature reserves: Little Water Cay has 30,000 rock iguanas and another has pink flamingoes. Deep-sea fishing for marlin and tuna is popular as is boon-fishing, a sort of flyfishing in the mangroves.

We have two restaurants and a great head barman called Rupert. He spent 26 years at the Waldorf Astoria in New York, but much prefers it out here. He has created his own special cocktails, the Caicos Sunset, and the Parrot Cay Mama, but the exact recipes are secret, of course.

And how do you relax?
On my day off I love to scuba-dive in unexplored spots on the reefs, but I haven't found any wrecks yet. In the 1720s the island used to be a pirate hideaway for two female Irish pirates and Calico Jack, hence the name. They say there is hidden gold, but I think the only treasure is the island itself.

 Parrot Cay: 00 1 649 946 7788

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Travel insurance probably comes quite low on your list of priorities when it comes to arranging your summer holiday.
fields.body:
Travel insurance probably comes quite low on your list of priorities when it comes to arranging your summer holiday.

Most people take the easy option and accept the policy pressed on them by their travel agent. But consumer surveys have shown that travel agents know so little about the insurance they are selling that customers can end up buying inappropriate cover. A survey by Mori for Direct Line showed that 55 per cent of holidaymakers who took part in higher-risk sports such as scuba-diving and water-skiing had no idea whether they were covered against injury or death.

By shopping around on the internet, you will not only pay less for your insurance, you will also be able to check that the policy provides the right level of cover for your holiday activities. Do make sure you check the terms and conditions to prevent unpleasant shocks if you have to claim. The People's Choice annual policy, for example, includes an exclusion for people who have claimed on a travel policy in the last five years.

Your first port of call should be a broker-operated site that collects premium quotes from a range of travel insurers, such as Screentrade. This site gives access to single trip and annual multi trip policies from several travel insurance companies, and provides details of the best five on screen at any one time - a sensible move as the cheapest policy will not always suit your needs.

Other broker sites include NatWest Insurance Services, which offers online customers a 15 per cent discount compared with prices offered over the phone, and MoneyExtra. The MoneyExtra site suffers from a programming fault, which means that if you have obtained one quote and want to change the details to see what effect this has on cost, you have to go right back to the homepage and fill in your application details from scratch. The company says it is working on the problem.

You could also check some of the direct insurers' sites, such as Direct Line and Columbus. PolicyDirect claims to offer the fastest instant travel quote on the internet. Its annual multi trip policy is fairly cheap, too, at £48.96 for a single adult and £78.34 for a family, but its structure may not suit all. Cover is limited to 60 days a year, including up to 10 days' winter sports, up to 25 days' worldwide travel and the remainder in Europe. For a list of links to travel insurers, visit www.find.co.uk.

The following companies offer more specialised travel services:

 The Travel Insurance Club offers specialist insurance for backpackers between the ages of 16 and 35. Worldwide cover, including winter sports but excluding baggage, costs £175 for a year. If you want to include £1,000 cover for baggage, you will have to pay £270.

 Travel Insurance Agency can sell you insurance cover even after you have started travelling. All you need to do is go to the nearest internet cafe and contact the firm's website at www.travelinsurers.com Policies cost about 10 per cent more than the price you would have paid prior to commencing your journey - from £11.97 for five days in Europe to £363.98 for 12 months' travel around the world.

 Sports Cover Direct provides insurance for a vast range of sporting activities that many insurers refuse to cover, from potholing to paragliding. You can tailor the insurance policy to your needs, ensuring that the cost is kept as low as possible.

 Club Direct sells reduced- rate policies for single parent families. One adult taking unlimited children for a two-week holiday in Europe would pay £27.90 for full cover. The equivalent price for a two-parent family would be £49.90. Full details of the single- parent poli cies will be added to Club Direct's website later this month. In the meantime, call 0800 074 4556.

webTitle: English fascists to join loyalists at Drumcree

fields.headline: English fascists to join loyalists at Drumcree
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Royal Ulster Constabulary has refused to ban up to 20 members of the neo-Nazi group Combat 18 from travelling to the Drumcree stand-off in Northern Ireland this week.
fields.body:
The Royal Ulster Constabulary has refused to ban up to 20 members of the neo-Nazi group Combat 18 from travelling to the Drumcree stand-off in Northern Ireland this week.

The English fascists - from Bolton, Burnley and Preston - are staying with members of the outlawed Loyalist Volunteer Force in Co Armagh during the height of the Protestant marching season.

During their last trip to Mid Ulster, Combat 18 attacked Chinese families in Portadown and openly supported loyalist terrorism. The organisation, which hero-worships Hitler, has praised convicted London nail-bomber David Copeland and called for an end to all loyalist ceasefires.

The Observer has established that the neo-Nazis will be staying with LVF members on Portadown's Corcrain and Brownstown estates from 7 July. A number of Combat 18 members have also been promised accommodation in nearby Tandragee.

The trip marks the healing of a rift between the groups. Combat 18 opposed the LVF ceasefire and, for a period, supported the Orange Volunteers-Red Hand Defenders movement which killed Lurgan solicitor Rosemary Nelson.

However, contact between Combat 18 and the LVF was maintained through a young loyalist in Portadown who has recently become a born-again Christian. 'Ordained' by convicted loyalist murderer Pastor Kenny McClinton, this man still holds white supremacist views.

A senior RUC officer told The Observer : 'Banning this crowd would just give them credibility which they don't deserve. They could easily slip into Northern Ireland via Dublin if we did ban them.'

One of Combat 18's chief supporters in Northern Ireland is Shaun Leighton, a convicted loyalist terrorist from Ballymoney in Co Antrim. Leighton has written for Combat 18 publications and websites. He has also maintained contact with Steve Sergeant who helped recruit David Copeland into the fascist splinter group, the National Socialist Movement.

Sergeant's brother, Charlie, worked for Special Branch as an informant passing intelligence to the Metropolitan Police about loyalist terrorists' activities in southern England. Charlie Sergeant also had links with the largest loyalist terrorist group, the Ulster Defence Association, and convicted gun-runner James Portinari. Sergeant is now serving life for the murder of fellow Combat 18 member Stephen Castle. Castle was an ally of Bill Browning, a former British soldier who served in Northern Ireland and is now thought to lead Combat 18.

Mainstream loyalist leaders in Belfast remain suspicious of linking up with British fascists because they suspect many of them are working for the security services.

Brendan MacCionnaith, spokesman for the Garvaghy Road Residents Coalition, was arrested yesterday after disturbances between nationalist demonstrators and the RUC.

fields.headline: Race for Yorkshire Post
fields.standfirst: Byers faces big competition policy test as Trinity Mirror prepares to join battle with Gannett, says  Emily Bell
fields.trailText: Byers faces big competition policy test as Trinity Mirror prepares to join battle with Gannett, says Emily Bell
fields.body:
'The last Barbie Doll on the shelf' is an unlikely way to describe the solid Yorkshire Post, but it's a neat metaphor for its owner, Regional Independent Media. In the regional press, where more than 60 per cent of titles have one way or another changed ownership in the last five years, RIM is the last prize in the shop, and three companies have now joined the chase to buy its publisher.

The acquisitive and vast American publisher Gannett lodged an application to purchase it with the Department of Trade and Industry last Wednesday. Two days later Johnston Press said it had done the same, and a similar statement will be made in the next two days by Trinity Mirror. With the three newspaper groups all besieging Trade Secretary Stephen Byers' in-tray with their requests, only the regional division of the Daily Mail and General Trust, Northcliffe Newspapers, has been spared the battle. It already has competing regional titles.

With the communications white paper due in the autumn, the Government has a headache deciding whether to allow the consolidation bandwagon to roll through the regional press - particularly as local papers, like local TV franchises, are incredibly important to many of its own backbenchers.

With the five remaining players in the regional newspaper market seemingly poised to shrink to four - and one of them a US operation - the regional press has evolved a long way from the locally-based groups, often family-owned, enterprises of the past.

'You've got to expect, even at this stage, that a player of Gannett's size, which has already bought both Newsquest and Newscom Groups, will either look for a further purchase or for an exit, even if it buys RIM too,' says one media analyst. 'All these companies see regional newspapers as a means of generating online profits from existing cash cows.'

It is an outcome very few would have predicted when Candover, the venture capitalists, paid what at the time seemed a punishingly high price of £360m for the papers owned by United News and Media when it decided to sell out of the stodgy regionals market in 1998.

Much to the surprise perhaps of established media companies such as Pearson and Emap, which also took a strategic and early exit from the regional press, the value of these newspaper assets has soared as the industry consolidated and the number of groups available to purchase dropped.

RIM is said to harbour private expectations that the company could be worth as much as £650m if it went ahead with a planned stock market flotation. This is probably a bit over-optimistic with the group's most recent annual profits of just £23m . But somewhere in the three-way bidding, the price of the papers could still reach a respectable figure of between £500m and £550m.

Candover, which owns 51 per cent of the company, seems to have played a very canny game. It started out from being in a position, two years ago, where most industry observers thought it had hideously overpaid for its stake. Biding its time while independent press groups have been snapped up, it has made RIM far more attractive because it is the last available asset.

But while most people think of their local paper as the repository for such vital information as the timing of the next church fete and the availability of second-hand three-piece suites, their place in the new economy is making the industry's consolidation look financially very attractive.

'We gather and store information digitally - we just distribute it via paper. In the future that may change', says RIM chief executive Chris Oakley, 'Our internet revenues are around £2m a year now. In five years I'm sure the majority of our revenues will still come from newspapers, but the proportion will gradually change. It is possible to foresee a time when online revenues will outweigh paper revenues.'

This is a surprise coming amid the cratering of confidence, particularly in content-driven internet businesses, but Oakley believes that the mix of proprietary local information and advertising coupled with newspaper brands means that estab lished newspaper companies can be confidence in their online investment strategies eventually paying dividends.

'Those established companies who are looking at online as a way of extending their brands and improving distribution are on to a winner; spending a fortune to establish new brands probably won't make a success of it.'

But in gathering these vast tracts of digital information and increasingly pushing editorial functions away from local towns and into regional centres, is the industry serving its shareholders better, but letting down its readership?

Hardly surprisingly, Oakley thinks not: 'I would say that there has been a vast improvement in most of the local and regional press over the past 15 years, largely due to the consolidation process. The quality of production is higher, the centralisation of business has allowed us, for the first time, to compete for advertising on a national level and the editorial is at least as good, or in some cases better, than it was.'

The Government is un likely to bail out the local newspaper office as a dying craft. But there will inevitably be questions about Gannett's domination of the British as well as the American local newspaper market.

Which of the three rivals will end up taking RIM is anybody's guess. But in the scramble for Newscom, Johnston Press ran Gannett closest in what some considered to be a bidding war where the price rose too steeply for others in the industry.

Trinity Mirror has consolidated its position by becoming a major owner of national as well as regional newspapers by purchasing Mirror Group Newspapers. The split between the two is half-and-half. The company sees the tabloid market as a natural fit, and looks at the regional titles in terms of the migra tion towards online delivery. of content.

It is unlikely that any of the other regional players will follow its lead - 'unless Gannett wants to buy the Express, which it could without really noticing,' quipped one industry executive.

What happens next is in the hands of Stephen Byers. If, in the long term, the Government relaxes its attitude that no regional group should operate a monopoly in one area - driven by both the expansion of the internet and the proliferation of local licences diluting the power of the local news barons - it will be a green light for another turn of the merger mill.

However, this seems highly unlikely as the unfolding battle for RIM is likely to test the boundaries of competition policy to the limit.

webTitle: When what comes down must go up...

fields.headline: When what comes down must go up...
fields.trailText: The impression that the new economy is somewhat distressed is, I am sure, only temporary and normal buoyant service will be received imminently. Perhaps even as early as this week when we find out just how many more people are packing mobile phones than was the case a year ago - and the answer, predictably, is about 250 per cent more. Sales figures from the major operators will show that for the first time more than half the British population has a mobile phone.
fields.body:
The impression that the new economy is somewhat distressed is, I am sure, only temporary and normal buoyant service will be received imminently. Perhaps even as early as this week when we find out just how many more people are packing mobile phones than was the case a year ago - and the answer, predictably, is about 250 per cent more. Sales figures from the major operators will show that for the first time more than half the British population has a mobile phone.

And there is little to persuade us that this market is peaking. Hans '300 per cent' Snook has, as has been well documented in this column, predicted we will have mobile devices for every day of the week. So what then are we to make of another mobile guru, Kurt Hellstroem of Ericsson, telling us that the mobile future is not as rosy as we might have thought, largely because the cost of investing in the third generation mobile licences would cripple a number of companies and end an era of freebie heaven for the mobile consumer.

Looking at the market today it is hard to believe that as recently as two years ago you had to pay up to £50 a month just to carry a phone around with you. Now the tariffs and cost of handsets have tumbled, and the talk is that talk will not just be cheap, it will be free as we use our 'wireless devices' for all manner of entertainments.

One of the great advantages of the mobile sales forces has been that the future technology they are so effusive about is so narrowly available. Wap phones are, I believe, handed out occasionally to 'opinion formers', but scarcely available for the public to buy. Which is just as well because they are the worst piece of interim technology one is ever likely to encounter. They are a scientist's solution to information portability which is hardly much further on than pager technology. It is, of course, 'interactive' but it is also utterly laborious and therefore not for the weak of thumb or myopic.

So in some ways Hellstroem's warning that 3G costs will backfire badly comes as no surprise. Take, for example a crude comparison with pay-TV. Three years of Premier League live matches has just cost BSkyB £1.2 billion, but it already has, say, more than 5 million subscribers for its sports services Most are prepared to pay £30 or more a month for their coverage. This would seem to be the most compelling content available in the country.

If stretched over 20 years at today's prices, BSkyB would have paid £2bn more for its football than Vodafone will have paid for a 3G licence.

But Vodafone has not yet even thought about how much it will have to pay for content to fill its hungry network. Sky TV pays nothing for a licence, and has written off a mere £400m against the development of its digital infrastructure. Yet it is not quite in profit. On the phone side the figures do not stack up.

This inevitably means that somewhere in the value chain the consumer will have to pay more to make the mobile proposition work. This will certainly happen in 20 years - not least because mobile phone technology could well form the core of, for instance, portable digital TV operating systems.

But over the next five years the payback looks unlikely, despite the rising number of mobile customers. What will happen is that the stragglers will fall quite quickly to the two or three larger companies which will eventually recoup their investment. No one would suggest that Vodafone is going to buckle under the cost of its licence obligation. But what will inevitably happen to consumer prices is that, having been artificially suppressed, they will rise rapidly. It's as certain as a Dutchman missing a penalty.

Just as insurers cut premiums when the online and phone innovators entered the market, only to put them up once things had settled, so it will be with phones. It relates to the basic law of new economy, gravity-defying businesses - what comes down, must go up.

webTitle: Are we really a nation of yobs?

fields.headline: Are we really a nation of yobs?
fields.standfirst:
Stuart Millar, on patrol with the police, finds little support for Labour's latest crime initiative.
Crime: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Stuart Millar, on patrol with the police, finds little support for Labour's latest crime initiative.
fields.body:
You could almost have set your watch by it. Barely 25 minutes after Southend's pubs started calling time on Friday's shift of revellers, the first shout came over the police radio: youths were reported trying to break into a shop. Squads of lads had had just enough time to swill down the remains of their fizzy Carlsbergs, wipe the dribbles off the front of their carefully untucked shirts and stagger off along the seafront in search of drunken sustenance. Now it was time for lager-fuelled high jinks.

The Ford Mondeo driven by PC Mick Taylor reached the shop, a half-mile from the town centre, in a couple of minutes, joining three other patrol cars which had raced to the scene. The four lads in question, all in their early twenties, were not only still there, but very drunk and unhappy with the sudden and dramatic attention. For a moment it looked as if though things would turn ugly, but after a few minutes of quiet questioning from Taylor, the tension was replaced by joking as it became clear that the youths had not been trying to burgle the unlikely target of an 'everything for £1' shop.

'We were just waiting on our pizza and we started having a larking-around fight,' explained Neil, the mouthiest of the group. 'We were rolling about making a racket, and we maybe banged into the shop doors a couple of times. Then, the next thing we are surrounded by four cop cars.'

It was the sort of minor incident played out in every town centre in Britain every Friday and Saturday night. In this case, it ended with matey handshakes all round before the lads were left to their pizza. But if Tony Blair has his way, the likes of Neil and his mates could find themselves being marched off to the cash machine at the nearest bank for money to pay a £100 on-the-spot fine for their loutish behaviour.

In a speech to 1,000 students in the German town of Tübingen last week, the Prime Minister announced this latest idea to crack down on the tide of anti-social behaviour, usually drink-related, which causes 'offence and misery in too many towns and cities on too many Friday and Saturday nights'.

'A thug,' he said, 'might think twice about kicking in your gate, throwing traffic cones around your street or hurling abuse into the night sky if he thought he might get picked up by the police, taken to a cashpoint and asked to pay an on-the-spot fine.'

Blair believes it is perverse that hard-pushed front line police officers should have the power to fine people who park illegally, but can deal with loutish drunks only through a 'long, expensive process through the police station, courts and beyond'.

If the idea was meant to be the answer to the Government's sensitivities on law and order, it immediately backfired. Senior police officers and lawyers were puzzled about why he chose to drop what is being widely dismissed as a gimmick into a highbrow speech on community ethics and the value of religious faith in modern society. The most obvious theory is that Blair is desperate to be seen to be taking the initiative on law and order ahead of the publication on 18 July of new crime figures which are expected to be bad.

While burglary and car crime will show another fall, violence against the person is expected to show a double-figure increase. The political logic is simple: behind the twitching curtains of suburban Britain, the feeling is that yobbery is on the march, unchecked by a lily-livered Government. So what better, or cheaper, way to reclaim the law and order initiative agenda than by tossing the tabloids the juicy bone of summary justice?

It is not difficult to understand Ministers' reluctance to unleash more gloomy results on a public which already suspects that new Labour is starting to lose its grip on crime. The Government was startled by the row over rural crime sparked by the case of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer convicted of the murder of a 16-year-old intruder. Then came the ugly antics of England football hooligans in Belgium for Euro 2000.

Blair's choice of Germany to air his plan shows how keen he is to re-establish his Government's damaged reputation with the British public and of his European partners.

The reality on the ground is more complicated, and adds weight to complaints that he is pandering to little more than an unsubstantiated fear of thuggery stalking the country.

No separate figures are available for loutish behaviour, whether caused by drink or not, so it is impossible to tell the scale of the problem.

The one area which Blair seems to have in mind, and for which statistics are available, is criminal damage. Yet even there, the evidence runs against his argument. The last crime figures, released last October, show a 3.2 per cent fall for this offence.

Only 11 per cent of the 879,600 incidents in the 12 months up to March 1999 involved damage to objects such as bus shelters and telephone kiosks.

But it is places such as Southend that are the true test. The Essex resort is famous for two things: its pier and its louts. With more than 400 licenced premises attracting a heady mix of locals and day-trippers every weekend, trouble is likely any weekend.

'We have pubs chucking out from 11pm and the clubs going through until 2am,' said Inspector Howard Laverack, the officer in charge of Friday's night shift. 'That means we get problems with people having too much to drink or being under the influence of drugs, which can affect their behaviour. Some Friday and Saturday nights can be bloody horrendous.'

Even here, however, Blair can count on little support. 'I can see where he's coming from,' said Laverack. 'But I can't see how we could give an on-the spot fine to somebody misbehaving because they are drunk or on drugs, or both, because they are impossible to deal with, especially if they offer violence.

It not just police who are unimpressed. Friday night in Southend was quiet, but the atmosphere was still tense. Trouble never seemed far away, especially when the clubs started emptying drink- and often drug-filled customers into the street.

Lee Phypes, head doorman at Papillon's bar on the seafront for eight years, expects trouble every weekend. A few weeks ago, a drunk came at him with an ashtray and on a few memorable occasions in the past, huge mass fights have erupted between members of drunken coach parties.

Even he sees little point in giving police the new power. 'It would be a waste of time. We deal with the stuff that happens inside, they deal with it when it's outside. They would never use fines because it would be more hassle.'

Papillon's punters agreed. 'You get trouble down here quite a lot,' said Paul Horwood, 18, who was in town for a night out with three mates from east London.

'Some people come looking for trouble but usually they're just pissed up, and they are not going to be thinking about fines or anything.'

A little before 2am and PC Taylor and his partner, Gary Watts, have made their third tour round the near-deserted town centre streets. As they cruised past Tots, a gleaming, neon-spangled nightclub above the seafront, a drunken young woman spotted the car and unleashed a loud barrage of abuse. The officers shook their heads and drove on.

'That's a classic example of why this idea won't work,' said Taylor. 'We could have stopped her but that could have been like sending up a rocket so what would be the point of trying to fine her? We already have the powers we need, it just comes down to practical policing and how we use our judgment.'

Watts agreed: 'If you asked the British public what they wanted the police to sort out first, I would say burglary was a bigger priority.'

Just then, another emergency call came over the radio. A member of the public had reported seeing a handgun in a black Jaguar driven by four young men on the seafront. As the officers joined the operation to stop it, Taylor remarked wryly: 'Now that's a bit more serious than somebody chucking a traffic cone around and shouting.'

Even he sees little point in giving police the new power. 'It would be a waste of time. We deal with the stuff that happens inside, they deal with it when it's outside. They would never use fines because it would be more hassle.' Papillon's punters agreed. 'You get trouble down here quite a lot,' said Paul Horwood, 18, who was in town for a night out with three mates from east London. 'Some people come looking for trouble but usually they're just pissed up, and they are not going to be thinking about fines or anything.' A little before 2am and PC Taylor and his partner, Gary Watts, have made their third tour round the near-deserted town centre streets. As they cruised past Tots, a gleaming, neon-spangled nightclub above the seafront, a drunken young woman spotted the car and unleashed a loud barrage of abuse. The officers shook their heads and drove on. 'That's a classic example of why this idea won't work,' said Taylor. 'We could have stopped her but that could have been like sending up a rocket so what would be the point of trying to fine her? We already have the powers we need, it just comes down to practical policing and how we use our judgment.' Watts agreed: 'If you asked the British public what they wanted the police to sort out first, I would say burglary was a bigger priority.' Just then, another emergency call came over the radio. A member of the public had reported seeing a handgun in a black Jaguar driven by four young men on the seafront. As the officers joined the operation to stop it, Taylor remarked wryly: 'Now that's a bit more serious than somebody chucking a traffic cone around and shouting.' stuart.millar@observer.co.uk

webTitle: It's now OK to be gay, but what's next?

fields.headline: It's now OK to be gay, but what's next?
fields.trailText: Yesterday's lesbian and gay pride celebrations mark the thirtieth anniversary of the formation of the London Gay Liberation Front. GLF made history. It was the beginning of the modern movement for lesbian and gay human rights.
fields.body:
Yesterday's lesbian and gay pride celebrations mark the thirtieth anniversary of the formation of the London Gay Liberation Front. GLF made history. It was the beginning of the modern movement for lesbian and gay human rights.

For the first time ever, lesbians and gays stopped hiding their sexuality and suffering in silence. Inspired by GLF, thousands came out and marched with pride for gay liberation. Spurning the defensive, apologetic pleas for tolerance voiced by earlier homosexual law reformers, GLF demanded a gay-positive and sex-affirmative society, where everyone could love whoever they wanted without guilt, fear or discrimination.

Given the recent strides made by the gay community, it is easy to forget how bad things were in 1970. Gay people were sacked from their jobs, arrested for kissing in the street, denied custody of their children, and refused service in pubs. Films stereotyped homosexuals as limp-wristed figures of ridicule, and gays were only mentioned on the news if they were mass murderers, spies or child abusers. Queer bashing was rife, but ignored by the police. There were no openly gay public figures or sympathetic gay characters on television, and no gay help-lines for those in need. No wonder there was so much self-loathing, depression, alcoholism and suicide.

Many gay people, ashamed and wishing they were straight, went to doctors to be 'cured'; others were sentenced by the courts to undergo 'treatment'. The medical profession classified homosexuality as an 'illness'. Leading psychologists advocated electric-shock aversion therapy to turn gay people straight. The consequences were tragic: most ended up sexually and emotionally disturbed.

It was these cruelties that motivated me to join GLF. Defying the bigotry which insisted that gay was mad, sad and very, very bad GLF declared 'Gay Is Good!'. Back then, even liberal-minded heterosexuals mostly supported gay people out of 'sympathy' and 'pity'. Many were aghast when GLF proclaimed: '2-4-6-8! Gay is just as good as straight!' Those words were empowering to gays everywhere, but they frightened the life out of smug, arrogant heterosexuals.

While politicians, priests and police viewed homosexuality as a social problem, we argued that the real problem was homophobia. GLF demanded that gay-haters justify their bigotry.

Now gay people are more visible than ever before and public attitudes are moving towards greater acceptance. Positive gay images and characters abound on television. Politicians and entertainers are openly gay. The police are serious, at last, about tackling homophobic hate crimes. Gayness is no longer a sickness.

But when it comes to law reform, the gains are derisory. Apart from ending the ban on gays in the armed forces and easing the immigration restrictions on foreign same-sex partners, nothing has changed in three decades. The discriminatory age of consent will be equalised, but not yet. While Section 28 has gone in Scotland, repeal in England and Wales may take much longer. There has been no progress at all on reforming the laws governing sexual offences, partnerships and protection against discrimination.

Homophobia is enshrined in the criminal code, where gay sex is insultingly defined as a 'gross indecency' and an 'unnatural offence'. The same 'gross indecency' law that convicted Oscar Wilde in 1895 remains on the statute book. Every year it is used to arrest more than 500 men for consensual homosexual acts. This law applies only to gay sex.

There is still no legal recognition of same-sex partnerships. They do not exist in law. Unlike both married and cohabiting heterosexual couples, homosexual lovers have no rights at all, not even acknowledgement as next-of-kin.

This means that when one partner dies, the surviving partner has no legal right to inherit their property or pension. Employers can sack someone from their job because they are gay. There is no statutory redress comparable to the way women, black people and the disabled are protected against discrimination. The Labour Government has - much to the dismay of the gay community - three times vetoed parliamentary amendments that have attempted to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation.

Although progress towards legal equality is shamefully slow, homophobic discrimination is doomed. It is then that the gay community will face an unexpected challenge.

Gay identity is largely a defence against homophobia. Faced with victimisation, we have to defend our right to be gay and create our own institutions to fill the void created by an uncaring society. But when legal equality and social acceptance have been won, will there be any need for a separate gay identity and community? If one sexuality is not deemed superior or more valid than the other, the raison d'etre for distinguishing between gay and straight disappears.

This is the ultimate paradox. Gay liberation creates the conditions for the dissolution of gay (and straight) consciousness. The more successfully we assert our human rights as gay people, the sooner the differences between homo and hetero lose their significance. When no one cares who is gay and who is straight, there is no need to maintain a distinction between the two sexualities. Thirty years after GLF, I am still celebrating gay pride, but my eye is firmly fixed on the real prize: a world beyond gay and straight.

fields.headline: Sunscreen, swimsuit, shades...
fields.trailText: Roddy Doyle, Sheena McDonald, A.L. Kennedy, Sebastian Faulks and Fay Weldon on their holiday books
fields.body:
Roddy Doyle
Wild Swans by Jung Chang. I know it's old but lots of people have recommended it to me. Also Enduring Love by Ian McEwan. The third book I will be reading on the beach is Iain Pears's Instance at the Fingerpost , a kind of sixteenth-century whodunit. I think three books is plenty.

Sheena McDonald
I'm going to Cape Cod on Friday with In the Heart of the Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick. It's set in New England and it's the true story of how the whaling ship Essex was attacked by a sperm whale. I may also take Susan Greenfield's The Private Life of the Brain because, following my own experience, I've become very interested in how the brain works. That will be my heavy book.

A.L. Kennedy
The Total Library, several decades of non-fiction by Jorge Luis Borges. As a teenager, I loved his cool humour. I will also be returning to Raymond Carver's collected poetry, which is a little like returning to Da Vinci's knitting. Then again, it would be unreasonable to expect the man to have been a genius in two fields.

Sebastian Faulks
I am reading Experience by Martin Amis. The structure is interesting as it circles between three fixed points: father, cousin, teeth. I think Amis has misjudged how interesting teeth are, either in the tabloid lies or in his own truthful but over-long account. The passages on his father are the best: honest, grand and touching. I hope another volume will tell us more about his own novels.

Fay Weldon
I want to read the new Margaret Atwood, The Blind Assassin . I am looking forward to finishing Philosophy for Counselling and Psychotherapy by Alex Howard. Joyce Cary's books are out of print here now, which is disgraceful. On holiday I buy thrillers. They can be extremely informative.

fields.headline: Sunscreen, swimsuit, shades...
fields.trailText: James Brown, Allegra McEvedy, Richard Eyre, Marika Cobbold and Andrew Motion on their beach reading
fields.body:
James Brown
I'm reading Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty by Harland Miller. It's a very accurate report of inner-city speed and dole life. I'm also going to be reading Nothing by Paul Morley, a pretty moving account of how he came to terms with his father's death. I just think he is a quite unique voice and it is a very common story, people's parents dying young.

Allegra McEvedy
I'm going to be reading The Wind-up Bird Chronicle by Haruki Murakami. It is kind of magical realism: Raymond Carver meets Thomas Pynchon, about a man who sees things and has a wife who misbehaves. Nothing really makes sense and it leaves you hanging with lots of questions.

Richard Eyre
I shall be reading Martin Amis's Experience. Partly because I was taught by his father and partly because I find father-son relationships fascinating. I'll also read Graham Robb's biography of Victor Hugo. And I'm planning on reading all the novels of Iris Murdoch.

Marika Cobbold
I've just got The Human Stain by Philip Roth. I loved his American Pastoral and I Married A Communist. He is a writer of vision, passion and humanity. I'm also going to read All That Really Matters by Campbell Armstrong. It's a heart-wrenching and uplifting memoir of marriage, loss and redemption.

Andrew Motion
Derek Mahon's Collected Poems. Mahon rarely gives readings. He requested that this book sell under its own steam, and I don't think any copies were sent out for review. I recommend that anyone interested in poetry buy it. I read Wordsworth's The Prelude every summer and I want to re-read a classic like Robinson Crusoe.

fields.headline: Sunscreen, swimsuit, shades...
fields.trailText: Susannah Constantine, Mariella Frostrup, Tom Paulin, Magnus Mills and Julie Myerson on the pages they'll be turning this summer
fields.body:
Susannah Constantine
Winterdance by Gary Paulsen, because I'm obsessed with ice and cold climates. It's a true story about a guy who did the dog sled race in Alaska. I am also going to read Lost Girls by Andrew Pyper - a ghost story/ thriller set in Toronto (more snow).

Mariella Frostrup
I'm reading Kent Haruf's Plain Song, a haunting story about life and loneliness on the prairie land around Denver. I love non-fiction - all those old travellers like Norman Lewis. Also Savages by Joe Kane about the Huaorani Indians in Ecuador. It is the first book I've read since I was a teenager that has made me cry.

Tom Paulin
I will be reading Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies by Martin Allen, and Paula Backsheider's Daniel Defoe: His Life. I wanted to write a book on him but I couldn't get a grant. Donald Davie's Psalms in English will be going with me on holiday and I will also be re-reading Blake and reading the Irish Times - I might just end up reading the Irish Times.

Magnus Mills
I want to read Apsley Cherry-Garrad's The Worst Journey. He was on a journey to discover the Emperor penguins but also had supplies for Captain Scott's polar expedition. When they found Scott, he was very close to where Cherry-Garrad was. The man is obviously racked with guilt but never actually says it.

Julie Myerson
I'm going to read Inishowen by Joseph O'Connor. His first book, The Salesman, was one of the best novels I've ever read. I'm also just about to start Esther Freud's The Wild. It's about step families and the pain they inflict upon children. It is quite an autobiographical book but very relevant to my own life. The subject isn't really tackled in adult books.

fields.headline: Sunscreen, swimsuit, shades...
fields.trailText: Rowan Pelling, Sarah Bradford, Jung Chang and Susan Greenfield on the books that they'll be packing this summer
fields.body:
Rowan Pelling
The Caribbean writer Robert Antoni's Blessed is the Fruit . I read My Grandmother's Erotic Folktales by him. This is a great summer book - you really feel tropical reading it. It's got cricket, sex, strong lesbian undercurrents and really great writing. It made me want to get my hands on every thing he has ever writ ten.

Sarah Bradford
I've been looking forward to the paperback edition of the Memoirs of the Duc de Saint-Simon in three volumes. The hardback was far too heavy to carry around. I always read biographies. I have been writing one on Jackie Kennedy and Seymour Hersh's book on JFK (The Dark Side of Camelot) was very important so it will be good to sit down and read that properly. I will also read Salley Vickers's Miss Garnet's Angel and Elizabeth Berridge's Tell It to a Stranger.

Jung Chang
I don't normally read about China for pleasure as I'm buried in it for my work. But then I opened Pearl Buck's classic The Good Earth . It is so beautiful. It is incredible how the hard life of a Chinese peasant family, simply described, can give such totally absorbing pleasure.

Susan Greenfield
I really enjoy Philippa Gregory's novels. They are historically very well researched, but still untaxing. I will definitely be reading that. I will be taking Round Ireland with a Fridge by Tony Hawks. I recently read Playing the Moldovans at Tennis, which I loved. It is great to be able to just laugh out loud. As I'm always thinking about the brain and mind and how human emotions intermesh, I'm trying to get away so I'd much rather have something that is escapist.

fields.headline: Sunscreen, swimsuit, shades...
fields.trailText: Deborah Moggach, Arnold Wesker, Carol Vorderman, Nicholas Blincoe and Trinny Woodall on their summer reading
fields.body:
Deborah Moggach
Lucy Moore's The Thieves' Opera. It's all about seventeenth- and eighteenth-century crime in England, particularly London. I'm reading Alain de Botton's How Proust Can Change Your Life which I'm taking very slowly because it's so good. I read a chapter a night.

Arnold Wesker
Like a long exotic drink, I'm taking in the remarkable second volume of biography on Coleridge by Richard Holmes. The scholarship leaves me very humble. I've lined up a book I'm dreading to read, The Iron Wall by the brilliant young Israeli historian Avi Shlaim, who I fear may scuttle some cherished views. And my wife has just bought me Cruel Britannia by Nick Cohen.

Carol Vorderman
Genome: The Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters by Matt Ridley, and Newsweek magazine - and I read all the papers every day which takes me at least two hours.

Nicholas Blincoe
I'm reading Kristin Kenway's first novel Precious Thing which is beautifully written and has the feeling of a French film - all meandering incidents: she has conjured up a huge juggernaut of emotion. And Dave Eggers's wonderful A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius nestles next to my swimming trunks and sex wax.

Trinny Woodall
I'll probably read an easy novel like the new John Grisham, The Brethren, to take my mind off work pressures. I'll also read Europe: A History by Norman Davies which runs from when Britain was literally part of the continent to the present day. Then I'll read a work book about the internet. I always have three books on the go.

fields.trailText: Amanda Craig, David Hare, Dave Eggers, Auberon Waugh and Ian McEwan reveal what they willl be reading this summer
fields.body:
Amanda Craig
The new Margaret Atwood, The Blind Assassin, because I adore her. I'm also reading Matthew Neal's English Passengers about a group of emigrants going to Australia. I love thrillers so I've got Run by Douglas Hunter and Nicci French's Beneath the Skin. I'm desperate to read the new Harry Potter - I've read all the others four times.

David Hare
People who claim there are no great writers any more should ponder The Human Stain by Philip Roth. The rest of us can admire how a political perspective not only enriches written fiction, but also does wonders for your style. Michael Ignatieff's life of Isaiah Berlin is a superbly thoughtful work which leaves you questioning your own life.

Dave Eggers
I'll be in Iceland for a month so I'm planning finally to read Independent People by Halldor Laxness, which won that award the Norwegians hand out. Otherwise it'll be manuscripts mostly, especially The Neal Pollack Anthology of American Literature. After that, any spare time will be given, wholly, to pornography.

Auberon Waugh
I'll be taking Malcolm Bradbury's To the Hermitage on holiday, which is the funniest book ever written, and I'm also taking V.S. Naipaul's Reading and Writing because he's just excellent.

Ian McEwan
I'm going to Spain for my holidays so I'll take some Lorca and Michael Frayn's Towards the End of Morning which has been reissued. I'll also be taking a preview copy of Julian Barnes's novel Love Etc which isn't published until August, plus Colin Tudge's The Variety of Life which is a celebration of all the creatures that have ever lived.

fields.headline: England's day all round
fields.trailText: There was an agonising feel about yesterday morning. 188 to win, against a team noted for their amazing last-innings victories against all odds. Most hard-bitten journalists backed West Indies. With the help of Dominic Cork, we scraped home.
fields.body:
There was an agonising feel about yesterday morning. 188 to win, against a team noted for their amazing last-innings victories against all odds. Most hard-bitten journalists backed West Indies. With the help of Dominic Cork, we scraped home.

The drizzle that held up play for 50 minutes brought a false sense of security. Perhaps it wouldn't be so hard after all. Yet when reality intervened, it was business as usual. In the 40 minutes of play before drizzle caused an early lunch, Ambrose bowled 36 balls, almost all of them to Atherton, who eked out a meagre one run for a little push past silly mid-on. Apart from this, he went past the outside edge perhaps ten times.

At the other end Ramprakash at least got off the mark, off the outside part of the bat, through gully. I felt for him. He is a tense man, as well as an engaging one. I imagine from his recent play that he is in torment about it. He must get conflicting advice: 'Get your head down, this is your chance,' alternating with 'Relax. Imagine it's a county match. Think positive.'

He must wonder whether to look to get forward on these recent testing pitches, at Edgbaston and at Lord's, or back. If he tries hard to protect against outswing he over-adjusts, gets his leg too far over, and is liable to be lbw or caught off bat and pad (these being his dismissals at Edgbaston): when he readjusts he risks being caught at slip, as in the first innings here.

Yesterday he seemed to jump excitedly at a looser ball from Walsh, jerkily, not letting it come to him. The result was a crooked bat, and an inside edge on to the stumps. For his peace of mind, he needs to be left out. The contrast with Atherton, who had up to then been frequently all at sea against Ambrose, was revealed next over, when he hit an identical ball for four between gully and cover.

I thought that England made a selection error for this match. When Nasser Hussain had to pull out I thought we needed Graham Thorpe. He is capable of scoring off decent balls and is quick to latch on to the short ball, pulling with a tough quickness of eye and wrist, like the other left- handers Border, Langer and Lara. This ability forces the bowlers to pitch the ball up further. They also have to change their line for the left hander.

I would have brought him in for Ramprakash from the start. We shouldn't have hung about. But when Nasser dropped out, I was even more convinced that we had to pick Thorpe; we were asking for trouble to enter such a key match with three untried batsmen in the first five. Why have the scores been so sensationally low here? Since tea on day one, when West Indies were 170 for two, 285 runs had been scored by Friday night for the loss of 27 wickets. No one reached 30. What on earth happened? The ball has gone through quicker as the match has gone on, and deviated in the air and off the dead tufty grass.

The main change came in England's approach in the second innings. Someone obviously decided that the thing to do was to bang the ball in. This they did with transforming effect on Friday, in one of the most enthralling sessions of cricket I can remember. Caddick was, in Michael Slater's epithet, awesome. No longer merely the rigid guardsman, he ran in with menace.

Stewart gave him good fields; he was lucky to get Campbell, caught at third man, but the fielder had rapidly been deployed there, a case of luck partly earned.

To the left handers he placed two short legs, giving the bowler permission to bowl straight rather than wide of off stump, and shorter than usual.

Caddick has the astonishing statistic of averaging 36 in the first innings of Test cricket, and 18 in the second. This raises questions about nerves.

At Friday's play, Graham Gooch suggested to the openers that they find some way of disrupting the composure of Ambrose and Walsh. The England bowlers needed to rough them up, give them a dose of their own old medicine. ('Make him swallow the ball, Malcolm,' was one encouragement for the bats man in the days of Marshall). On the other hand, it was in the interest of West Indies to keep to their length and line. How they were to be riled was not revealed. Verbal nastiness was not, I imagine, what Gooch had in mind, but nor perhaps was running down the wicket as Brian Close did against Wes Hall in the amazing match at Lord's in 1963.

In fact we were incredibly lucky yesterday against Ambrose. He went wicketless for 11 overs in his first spell, whereas he might well have had five wickets. The last straw was a Chinese cut to fine leg for four by Vaughan.The incredulous, hand-on-hip glare at the end of his run-up became a regular thing, until he was finally reduced, uncharacteristically, to throwing his arms up in the air.

By now Atherton was sniffing the ball like a terrier the scent, and missing no chance to score, riding his luck, rel ishing the struggle. Vaughan too played some class shots. After 26 overs Ambrose had bowled 13 overs for 13 runs; unlike Caddick, the last line was key: no wickets.

Now England at last had the second line bowlers, King and Rose, on together. Pressure was heavy on them, too. Fours came, some even off the middle of the bat. Two slips only; Vaughan nicks Rose through third slip for four. It's our day.

webTitle: Why's Yahoo gone to Google? Search me

fields.headline: Why's Yahoo gone to Google? Search me
fields.trailText: The news that Yahoo! has decided to switch search engines from Inktomi to Google must have left many laymen and women puzzled last week. Who or what are Inktomi and Google? Who dreams up these daft names anyway? And isn't Yahoo! itself a search engine? Why should it need another one?
fields.body:
The news that Yahoo! has decided to switch search engines from Inktomi to Google must have left many laymen and women puzzled last week. Who or what are Inktomi and Google? Who dreams up these daft names anyway? And isn't Yahoo! itself a search engine? Why should it need another one?

The answer to this last question is that Yahoo! began life as a directory of websites, not a search engine. But as it became clear that its staff of indexers could not keep up with the growth of the web, the company contracted out the business of servicing searches to Inktomi, a specialist search engine company based in California.

It turns out that Yahoo! is not alone in this. Inktomi provides search engine facilities to various clients including AOL, Excite@Home, RealNetworks, the Microsoft Network and NBC Internet.

So every time an MSN subscriber (say) types a query, it is serviced not by Microsoft, but by technology created by Inktomi and licensed to MSN.

Why did Yahoo! make the shift? Nobody knows for sure, but here are some possible answers. Firstly, Google is widely regarded as technically superior. It ranks search results using a kind of automated peer review so that a page is judged partly by how many other pages on the Net link to it. Secondly, Google claims that it indexes more documents than anyone else (it was claiming half a billion documents last week) and therefore that searches on it tend to be more comprehensive (i.e. less arbitrary and selective).

Oh, and Google does not take money in return for boosting your site in its rankings, a fact which endears it to geeks and drives business folks to distraction.

Because the web is so vast, and grows so quickly, no search engine, not even Google, can provide anything other than a partial index. That means that users searching for information are dependent on their chosen search engines.

It also means that proprietors of search engines possess economic power, for they define who's visible and who is not.

As the world shifts increasingly to e-commerce, a presence in cyberspace will come to be as important as the possession of factories, offices and shops in the real world.

And if search engines can't, or won't, find your site then you will be, to all intents and purposes, rendered invisible. So one of the key concerns of businesses and organisations will be to ensure that when people go looking for them on the web, their site will be ranked prominently by the major search engines.

At present, search engine rankings are determined either by algorithms (like, say, the peer-linking algorithm employed by Google) or by economics. In the latter case, rankings can be improved by payments or by 'partnership' deals - which are really just payments in another guise.

However rankings are determined, the inescapable fact is that search engines already wield considerable power, and that this power is exercised entirely without regulation.

There is, in other words, a politics of search engines. Or, rather, there should be, for it's no good saying that the market will take care of the problem, that search engines will rise or fall depending on the quality of the service they offer to customers or users. An exclusively market-driven solution will lead to a web where the most visible organisations will be those with the deepest pockets and the widest range of partnership deals.

Alarmed by this prospect, Oneworld.org - a leading portal for NGOs and organisations interested in environmental issues and sustainable development - has already created its own specialist search engine precisely to avoid the looming threat of 'virtual invisibility'. You could say it was a way of ensuring that the Yahoos of this world do not inherit the earth.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Fenians' arch enemy on way to sainthood

fields.headline: Fenians' arch enemy on way to sainthood
fields.standfirst: A move to beatify Pius IX has united Irish Americans and Jews against the anti-Semitic pope.  Rory Carroll  and  Henry McDonald  report on intrigue in the Vatican
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II has sparked Jewish - and Irish - fury by planning to beatify a predecessor who kidnapped and forcibly converted Jewish children to Catholicism.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II has sparked Jewish - and Irish - fury by planning to beatify a predecessor who kidnapped and forcibly converted Jewish children to Catholicism.

The Pope will set Pius IX on the road to sainthood in September, despite protests that he was an anti-Semite who repressed Rome's Jewish community and excommunicated leaders of the Irish republican Fenian movement.

Liberal Catholics are also appalled that the man who promulgated papal infallibility and condemned progressives in the 1864 Syllabus of Errors should be held up as a beacon. Right-wing conservatives inside the Curia, the Vatican's administration, are believed to have championed the beatification in defiance of warnings that it would rupture Jewish-Catholic relations. Pius IX was a courageous opponent and victim of nineteenth-century anti-clericalism, they claim. But critics say he is being championed only to balance the simultaneous beatification of John XXIII, a reforming pope beloved by liberals.

Under Pius IX, laws were passed banning Jews from secondary and higher education, limiting their employment and property rights and invalidating their evidence in court.

The last pope-king, who reigned from 1846 to 1878, is most notorious for kidnapping. The most sensational case occurred in Bologna, then a papal state, when police snatched six-year-old Edgardo Mortara from his Jewish parents and seven siblings. Four years earlier he had had a fever and a servant girl had sprinkled water on his head in case he died.

Edgardo was declared subject to canon law, which required the Church to take religious charge of any person baptised. His parents never saw him again, despite international lobbying for his return. Edgardo was effectively adopted as a son by Pius IX and became a priest. He died in Belgium in 1940, a disturbed man, according to his diaries.

Jewish leaders held a conference in Rome last week to register their anger. Two decades of efforts by the current Pope to improve Vatican-Jewish relations were imperilled, they said. The Mortara case 'is the biggest wound that remains in the Italian Jewish world ... that still hasn't scarred over,' said Amos Luzzatto, president of the Union of Italian Jewish Communities. 'It is a fact that the name of Pius IX is associated among Jews with the sad memory of Jewish children baptised against the will of their parents.'

Echoing dismay from American Jewish groups, Richard Heideman, president of B'nai B'rith International, has written a protest letter to the Vatican congregation responsible for beatifications.

Elan Steinberg, of the World Jewish Congress, was puzzled why a Pope who recently prayed at the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem and apologised for centuries of persecution should now undermine Jewish-Catholic reconciliation. 'We have a paradox here,' she said.

A proposal to beatify Pius IX in 1985 was shelved after two senior cardinals and official biographers suggested he was unsuitable. It was not for the Jewish people to tell the Vatican who to make a saint, but the Mortara case went 'right to the heart of religious tolerance', said Steinberg.

Israel has not officially complained because it is saving its fire for the bigger battle over the possible beatification of Pius XII, who remained silent about the Holocaust during the Second World War, said one diplomat.

Meanwhile, one of Irish-Americans' most senior lobbyists in Washington has launched a coast-to-coast campaign against Pius IX's beatification. Father Sean McManus, a Catholic priest and leading figure in the Irish National Caucus, has called on Irish-Americans to put pressure on bishops and cardinals in the United States to persuade the Vatican to reverse its decision.

Under pressure from Britain's then Prime Minister, William Gladstone, Pius IX excommunicated the Fenians from the Catholic Church on 12 January, 1870. At the time the Fenians were en-gaged in acts of violence in both Ireland and Britain. In devoutly Catholic Ireland, the excommunication order effectively killed off any popular support for the revolutionary republican organisation.

McManus said he had no problem reconciling his Catholicism and his overall loyalty to the present Pope John II with his opposition to Pius IX becoming a saint.

'A great injustice was done against the Fenian movement by excommunicating them,' he said. 'The main reason I am opposing this beatification is hypocrisy. The Fenians were excommunicated because they used violence, but Pius IX also used violence.

'Pius IX had a standing army and used it to maintain the temporal power of the Vatican State. He even called for Irish volunteers to fight in the Papal Army against the troops of the Carbonari.'
