fields.headline: The taste of summer
fields.standfirst: Take more than 1,000 bottles, several long and lazy afternoons, and one heroic taster, and what have you got? Our cut-and-keep guide to three cases of perfect wines to suit almost every budget
fields.trailText: Take more than 1,000 bottles, several long and lazy afternoons, and one heroic taster, and what have you got? Our cut-and-keep guide to three cases of perfect wines to suit almost every budget.
fields.body:
Wines under £5

Sainsbury's Aged Amontillado (£3.49 per half, Sainsbury's). When will people catch on to the subtle delights of mature Amontillado Sherry? This deliciously nutty, dry, full-bodied fortified is a super example of the Andalusian alchemy which turns the boring Palomino grape into one of the world's great wines.

1999 Corbières, Domaine Madelon (£3.69, Majestic). I've tried a lot of southern French reds under £4 and this one still comes out ahead. It's soft, fleshy and deeply coloured with notes of black pepper, liquorice, blackberries and sweet plums. The tannins are very smooth for a wine at this price.

1999 Canepa Sémillon, Colchagua (£3.99, Unwins, Fullers, Waitrose). Sémillon is an unusual variety to find in Chile, where Sauvignon Blanc and Chardonnay are the grape varieties of choice. This lemony, pleasantly herbal white has medium-to-full body, refreshing acidity and an enticing finish.

1999 Riverview Sauvignon Blanc, Neszmély (£3.99, Safeway). If anyone is making a better value Sauvignon Blanc than this Hungarian stunner, then I'd love to see it. Grass and grapefruit are the dominant flavours in this intense, well-balanced white from ace winemaker, Akos Kamocsay.

1999 La Palmeria Merlot (from £4.49, Oddbins, Unwins, Fullers). This deeply coloured, fleshy Chilean Merlot has sweet blackcurrant fruit, succulent tannins and a touch of vanilla oak.

1999 Cuvée de l'Arjolle Rosé, Vin de Pays des Ctes de Thongue (£4.95, Justerini & Brooks, 020 7493 8721). Summer is a great time to drink rosé and this dry southern French example is absolutely delicious. It's refreshing, but also has plenty of rosehip and strawberry fruit concentration.

1999 Argento Malbec (£4.99, Sainsbury's, Tesco, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Thresher, Victoria Wine, Wine Cellar). Still the best value Argentine red on the market, this sumptuously packaged Malbec from one of South America's leading producers continues to impress with its richness and its plummy, oak-influenced concentration and its drinkability.

1999 Tesco Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon Reserve, Curicó (£4.99, Tesco). Tesco's own-label Chilean reds are excellent value and this Cabernet from Valdivieso is the best of the lot. It's minty and intense with finely textured tannins and flavours of currant and fresh blackcurrant offset by subtle oak.

1998 L'Arco Friuli Cabernet Franc (£4.99, Somerfield). London-based Aussie John Worontschak is the man behind this impressive north-east Italian red. Made from the Loire Valley's Cabernet Franc grape, it's grassy and soft with classic notes of green pepper and pencil shavings.

1998 Vouvray Hand-Picked, Denis Marchais (£4.99, Asda). Chenin Blanc can taste of apple cores when badly made, but this medium-sweet wine shows the variety's more attractive side. It's crisp and honeyed with flavours of Cox's apple and pear.

1999 Rock Ridge Chardonnay, Vinfruco (£4.99, Marks & Spencer). South African Chardonnay is improving with every vintage and can now compete with Australia under £5. Werner Engelbrecht's toasty, well-balanced, subtly oaked white is distinguished by the ripeness and purity of its fruit.

1994 Bernkasteler Badstube Riesling Kabinett, Sanctus Jacobus (£4.99, Majestic). A great follow up to the 1990 vintage. Fresh and extremely light on the palate with notes of apple and lime blossom, this is a great introduction to off-dry Mosel Riesling.

Under £10

1999 Santa Digna Sauvignon Blanc, Miguel Torres, Curicó (£5.49, Selfridges; 01442 870 900). Miguel Torres is more commonly associated with Spain than Chile, but the wines he's producing in the Curicó Valley are outstanding. This rich, concentrated, almost tropical Sauvignon Blanc could easily be mistaken for a top Kiwi white.

1998 Landskroon Shiraz, Paarl (£6.49, Safeway). This well-priced Shiraz is spicy and smooth, with powerful blackberry and raspberry fruit flavours and vanilla sweetness from American-oak ageing.

1999 Anjou, Domaine Ogereau (£6.99, Swig, 020 7431 4412). Youthful Loire reds are ideal for summer drinking, especially if they're chilled. This perfumed Cabernet Franc has got surprising depth and concentration, with flavours of cassis and green pepper and medium tannins.

1999 Pazo de Señorans Albariño, Rias Baixas (from £7.95, Tanners, 01743 234 500; Harvey Nichols; Valvona & Crolla, 0131 556 6066). The wines from Spain's Atlantic coast are some of the most underrated in Europe. This subtle unoaked white, with its understated flavours of peach and apricot and its zesty acidity is ideal summer drinking.

1997 Chianti Classico, Il Tarocco (£7.99, Oddbins). From a great Tuscan vintage, it's a blend of 90 per cent Sangiovese and 10 per cent Canaiolo with well-balanced oak, pronounced acidity, intense cherry fruit and a classic, almond finish. Needs food.

1999 Capel Vale Verdelho, Western Australia (£7.99, Majestic; £6.99 if you buy two or more bottles). A brilliant western Australian take on a classic Madeira grape. This is extremely lively with floral aromas, crisp natural acidity and flavours of lime and guava. The oak is so subtle. Delicious.

1998 Pinot Grigio Benefizium Porer, Lageder (£8.49, Majestic; Bibendum, 020 7722 5577). All too often insipid, Italian Pinot Grigio is capable of great intensity in the right area. This example from the best producer in the Alto Adige is soft and peachy with great concentration and super palate length.

1997 JJ Prüm Riesling Kabinett (£8.90, Justerini & Brooks, 020 7493 8721). Prüm is one of my desert-island producers, fashioning Mosel Rieslings of feline subtlety and elegance. This is a near perfect example of a Kabinett-style with lovely balance between sugar, acidity and fruit.

1999 Pisano Tannat, RPF (£8.99, Waitrose). Daniel Pisano makes Uruguay's best red wines. This well-structured Tannat is much softer than the examples you find in Madiran, the grape's other home, with flavours of mulberry, cherry and chocolate.

1998 Grüner Veltliner, Alte Reben, Oberfeld, Dr Unger (£9.40, Morris & Verdin, 020 7357 8866). Austria produces some of Europe's most exciting whites. This intense (and for Austria, underpriced) white is overtly spicy with flamboyant flavours of grapefruit and bay leaf.

1998 Tim Adams, The Fergus, Clare Valley (£9.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Australian Wine Club, 0800 856 2004). Tim Adams is one of my favourite Aussie producers. This Grenache-based Clare Valley blend is one of the mintiest wines I've ever tasted, showing spicy oak, ripe tannins and lush flavours of strawberry and brown sugar.

1999 Kuentz-Bas Alsace Gewürztraminer Collection (£9.99, Unwins, Fuller's). Alsace Gewürztraminer can be a bit of a one-glass wine, but this is an exception. It's got the classic lychee and rose-petal aromas, but the wine is dry and extremely well-balanced.

Under £20

1998 Glazebrook Merlot/Cabernet, Hawkes Bay (£10.99, Roberson's, 020 7371 2121; Swig, 020 7431 4412). 1998 was a fantastic vintage for red wines in New Zealand, so it's no surprise that Hawkes Bay (the best area for Bordeaux blends) came up trumps. Alwyn Corban's blend of Merlot and Cabernet is a delicious alternative to top claret.

1997 Von Blauem Schiefer, Heymann-Löwenstein, Mosel (£11.80, Morris & Verdin, 020 7357 8866). Most dry German whites are barely drinkable, but the wines from Heymann-Löwenstein are simply stunning. This green-tinged, medium-bodied Riesling is beautifully balanced with flavours of ripe apple and passion fruit.

1997 Rosso Conero, Sassi Neri (£12.45, Berry Brothers & Rudd, 0870 900 4300). Top-notch Montepulciano from the Marches, showing intense colour, a vibrant, attractively oaked nose, rich tannins and flavours of currant, plum and black cherry.

1998 Domaine Borie de Maurel, Cuvée Sylla, Minervois (£12.99, Oddbins). Languedoc reds don't get much better than this. The nose is massively concentrated with aromas of herbs, spices and ripe blackberry. Will improve for five to 10 years.

1997 Chorey Les Beaune, Tollot Beaut (£13.65, Berry Brothers & Rudd, 0870 900 4300). Not a great vintage in Burgundy, but this Pinot Noir is drinking beautifully now. Fragrant with notes of raspberry and wild strawberry and attractive oak flavours.

Mavrodaphne of Patras, Karelas (£13.95, Orchard Hive and Vine, 01568 611 232). Discovered by an Observer reader, this 50-year-old Greek sweet wine is one of the best things I've tasted in years. Rich and full-bodied with hints of prune and leather.

1997 Coldstream Hills Reserve Chardonnay (£14.99, Oddbins). Cool-climate Aussie Chardonnay has improved dramatically in the past five years, typified by the advances at Coldstream Hills in the Yarra Valley. A very complex wine with notes of toast, butter and fudge underscored by acidity.

1998 Tokay Pinot-Gris Grand Cru, Sonnenglanz, Bott-Geyl (£14.99, Majestic). Top Alsace wines are some of France's finest whites. This rich Pinot Gris from a Grand Cru site is soft and spicy with flavours of peach, melon and fennel.

1996 Quinta do Portal Grande Reserva (£15.95, Great Northern Wine Company, 01765 606 767; Ellis of Richmond, 020 8943 4033; Great Western Wine Company, 01225 322 800); Charles Hennings, 01798 872 485). French consultant Michel Rolland had a hand in this exciting Douro red made principally from Touriga Nacional grapes. This is peppery and intense with sweet fruit flavours. 1992 Tokaji Aszu, 5 Puttonyos, Disznoko (£15.99 per 50cl, Oddbins). From a Bordeaux-owned estate, this is a sweet, tea-leafy Tokaji showing the influence of the benign botrytis mould.

1998 The Virgilius Viognier, Yalumba (£16.99, Oddbins Fine Wine; Noel Young, 01223 844 744; Bennetts, 01386 840 392). Yalumba has produced an Aussie white that compares with the best Condrieus from the northern Rhne. Subtle oak and flavours of white peach and apricot.

1997 Ridge Geyserville (from £18.95, Adnams, 01502 727 220; Friarwood, 020 7736 2628; Harvey Nichols; Lea & Sandeman, 020 7244 0522; Morris & Verdin, 020 7357 8866). Zinfandel specialist Paul Draper is one of California's most intelligent winemakers. This Zin-based field blend from very old vines is heady, almost raisiny stuff with notes of tobacco, spice and sweet vanilla oak.

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's potato recipes
fields.standfirst: Whether roasted with rosemary or in a warm duck salad, summer is the humble tattie's moment for glory
fields.trailText: Whether roasted with rosemary or in a warm duck salad, summer is the humble tattie's moment for glory
fields.body:
This is the time of year when those things I normally treat as accessories to a meal become the meal itself. I am thinking of the untidy heap of green beans on the side of the plate that, with a little chopped shallot, mustardy dressing and some shredded butterhead lettuce, becomes a light lunch. The grilled tomatoes that are normally an adjunct to a steak that find themselves dumped on garlic toast and playing a starring role in a bruschetta and goat's cheese garden lunch. The side order of couscous that gets a more elaborate seasoning (say a couple of slices of grilled salmon, matchsticks of cucumber and masses of mint) and ends up as my entire supper.

I cannot deny that I like the idea of these culinary underdogs getting their moment of glory, but then I am someone for whom a baked potato has always been dinner, rather than just a lump of starch nestling next to the meat. It is the same with potato salad - though its traditional job may be to sit aside some thick slices of cold ham or beef, I find it can, if well made, make a good principal dish. In fact, that is just what it has been in my house since the sun started shining.

Note the epithet 'well made'. This means starting with some decent spuds rather than those that have been sleeping in the vegetable rack. This is the occasion for splashing out on waxy-fleshed salad potatoes, such as the tapered La Ratte or Charlotte and the most tiny, most earthy of Jerseys, or perhaps just some seriously floury 'main-crop'. Organically grown potatoes taste noticeably better, too. You can't say this about all organic vegetables or fruit, but you can certainly say it about most food grown underground, such as carrots and parsnips.

Received wisdom says that waxy potatoes are the ones for salad - those with a yellow flesh and thin skins. I both agree and disagree. While a candle-fleshed potato keeps its shape after tossing in the dressing, there is nothing quite like a crumbly main-crop tattie in a rustic presentation, falling apart temptingly in the mayo.

Whatever, the more recently dug the potato, the more chance it will have a deep flavour, though, of course, much depends on the variety. Potatoes lose their flavour more quickly than you would think, and I see every reason for buying them as regularly as we buy the salad. I know this goes against the grain of convenience shopping, but good eating has never been without its inconveniences ever since man first had to chase a mammoth for his supper. I buy my potatoes, as with any other vegetable, when I need them, and cook them the day I get them home. Anyone who has eaten the potatoes from their organic bag from a farmers' market on the day of delivery will know what I mean.

A potato salad can be an elegant affair where cherubic, kidney-shaped new potatoes, carefully scrubbed and boiled with mint, come dressed with hand-beaten mayonnaise, or an altogether rougher deal with coarse slices of pungent onion, the floury spuds crumbling into oily, vivid yellow mayo. Both can be good.

To peel or not to peel? I can only say that it is an entirely personal thing, and anyone who gets into a fume about a flake of skin on their Jerseys doesn't have enough to do. On the other hand, the skin adds nothing except a bit of fibre and has an annoying habit of sticking to your knife. I find the skin a good thing only if it is very thin and meticulously scrubbed. But tell me I am not alone in finding something quietly perfect about a dish of scrupulously de-skinned new potatoes without the remotest flake of skin, dressed with a classic vinaigrette and some spanking fresh parsley.

Roast new potato salad with rosemary and mustard

Serves 4 as a side dish.

25 new potatoes

1 head of garlic

olive oil

a couple of sprigs of rosemary

for the dressing

2 tbsps red-wine vinegar

2 tbsps smooth Dijon mustard

5 tbsps olive oil

Scrub the potatoes thoroughly, then put them in an ovenproof dish or roasting tin. Break the garlic into cloves, but don't peel them, then add them to the potatoes. Drizzle over a little olive oil, then scatter with flakes of sea salt and the leaves from the rosemary sprigs. Bake at 200 C/gas mark 6 for 45 to 60 minutes till they are puffed and golden, their insides fluffy.

Pour the vinegar into a small lidded jar with the mustard, olive oil, some salt and pepper and shake it hard to give a thick dressing. You can use a little whisk if you prefer. When the potatoes come from the oven, press down hard on each one with the back of spoon so that they crack open slightly, then pour over the hot mustard dressing. As you eat, press the soft garlic from its skins.

Warm duck salad with fried potatoes, peas and mint

Serves 2 as a main dish, 4 as a snack.

2 large duck legs

1 big, juicy lemon or 2 less generous ones

500g new potatoes

a bunch of mint

100g shelled peas

a little olive oil

Put the duck, skin-side up, in a small, shallow, ovenproof dish. I use one of those French enamelled cast-iron numbers. Squeeze over the juice from half of the lemon, liberally season with salt and black pepper and put into a hot oven (200 C/gas mark 6) to roast until the skin is crisp and the meat is brown all the way through (about 50 minutes to an hour).

Scrub the potatoes so thoroughly you can barely see any skin (it will only get in the way when you fry them later), then drop them into boiling salted water, adding about half of the mint. Meanwhile, bring another pan of water to the boil, salt it lightly and add the peas. Boil till tender and sweet, then drain them.

Once the duck has roasted for half an hour, tip the fat off into a shallow pan (the sort that can go on the hob) and return the duck to the oven for a further half hour.

When the potatoes are tender to the point of a knife, drain them thoroughly and cut them into thick slices. They will crumble a bit, but no matter. Warm the drained duck fat over a moderate heat and add the sliced potatoes and any crumbs of potato. They will slowly crisp. Dislodge them from the pan every now and again with a palette knife.

Remove the duck from the oven, lift it from the dish with tongs on to a chopping board, and cut the meat from the bones, discarding any obviously excessive lumps of fat. Cut up the flesh a little, but try to leave it in fat, juicy pieces. Tip it into a salad bowl. Drain the peas and add them, too. Pull the remaining mint leaves from the stalks and chop them, then add them to the duck and and peas.

When the potatoes are golden and crusty, lift them out (tongs or a draining spoon are best for this) and add them to the duck and mint. Pour most of the fat from the pan into a heat-proof pot and let it cool - you can use it to fry potatoes or to start cooking onions for a casserole. Put the pan back on the heat and squeeze in the remaining lemon juice. Stand back from the heat as you do this (mine jumped out and burned me), then scrape at the pan to loosen any golden crusty bits of potato, then quickly swish it into the salad bowl. Turn the pepper and salt mills over it once or twice, and add a splash - no more - of olive oil, then pile on to plates.

New potato, herring, rocket and crème frache salad

A sweet-sharp salad with a creamy dressing. Avoid the temptation to over-mix the salad when you are dressing it - the beetroot is inclined to send everything a very unfetching shade of marshmallow pink. Serves 4 as a light main course.

300g waxy 'salad' potatoes

4 small, cooked beetroot

6 fillets of pickled herring

4 medium-sized gherkins

1 small sweet onion, peeled,

or 4 trimmed spring onions

200g rocket leaves and fine stems

a small bunch of dill

1 tbsp red-wine vinegar

1 tbsp olive oil

1 tsp smooth Dijon mustard

100g crème frache

100g live yogurt

Scrub the potatoes and bring them to the boil in deep salted water. Let them simmer for 15 minutes or so, until they are tender to the point of a knife.

Peel the beetroot, then cut them into thick wedges and put them in a mixing bowl. Remove the little wooden sticks that inevitably come with soused herrings and cut each fillet into six chunks, then add to the beetroot, but do not mix.

Thickly slice the gherkins, then add them to the beetroot and herring. Peel the onion and slice it very finely, or chop the spring onion, and add to the bowl. Rinse the rocket leaves and check them over, removing any thick stalks or wilted leaves. Keep them separate from the rest of the ingredients. Chop the dill and add it to the beetroot and herring.

Drain the potatoes, and peel off their skins as soon as they are cool enough to hold. Don't let them get cold - you want to dress them while they are warm. Cut each potato in half if they are very small, into quarters if not, and add them to the mixing bowl.

With a fork, mix the vinegar and olive oil in a small bowl or jar, and season with salt and black pepper and the mustard, then beat in the crème frache and the yogurt. Gently fold the dressing into the rest of the ingredients in the bowl, but stirring only lightly to avoid the beetroot sending everything pink. Divide the rocket between four plates, and pile the potato salad between them.

I am thinking of the untidy heap of green beans on the side of the plate that, with a little chopped shallot, mustardy dressing and some shredded butterhead lettuce, becomes a light lunch. The grilled tomatoes that are normally an adjunct to a steak that find themselves dumped on garlic toast and playing a starring role in a bruschetta and goat's cheese garden lunch. The side order of couscous that gets a more elaborate seasoning (say a couple of slices of grilled salmon, matchsticks of cucumber and masses of mint) and ends up as my entire supper. I cannot deny that I like the idea of these culinary underdogs getting their moment of glory, but then I am someone for whom a baked potato has always been dinner, rather than just a lump of starch nestling next to the meat. It is the same with potato salad - though its traditional job may be to sit aside some thick slices of cold ham or beef, I find it can, if well made, make a good principal dish. In fact, that is just what it has been in my house since the sun started shining. Note the epithet 'well made'. This means starting with some decent spuds rather than those that have been sleeping in the vegetable rack. This is the occasion for splashing out on waxy-fleshed salad potatoes, such as the tapered La Ratte or Charlotte and the most tiny, most earthy of Jerseys, or perhaps just some seriously floury 'main-crop'. Organically grown potatoes taste noticeably better, too. You can't say this about all organic vegetables or fruit, but you can certainly say it about most food grown underground, such as carrots and parsnips. Received wisdom says that waxy potatoes are the ones for salad - those with a yellow flesh and thin skins. I both agree and disagree. While a candle-fleshed potato keeps its shape after tossing in the dressing, there is nothing quite like a crumbly main-crop tattie in a rustic presentation, falling apart temptingly in the mayo. Whatever, the more recently dug the potato, the more chance it will have a deep flavour, though, of course, much depends on the variety. Potatoes lose their flavour more quickly than you would think, and I see every reason for buying them as regularly as we buy the salad. I know this goes against the grain of convenience shopping, but good eating has never been without its inconveniences ever since man first had to chase a mammoth for his supper. I buy my potatoes, as with any other vegetable, when I need them, and cook them the day I get them home. Anyone who has eaten the potatoes from their organic bag from a farmers' market on the day of delivery will know what I mean. Both can be good. To peel or not to peel? I can only say that it is an entirely personal thing, and anyone who gets into a fume about a flake of skin on their Jerseys doesn't have enough to do. On the other hand, the skin adds nothing except a bit of fibre and has an annoying habit of sticking to your knife. I find the skin a good thing only if it is very thin and meticulously scrubbed. But tell me I am not alone in finding something quietly perfect about a dish of scrupulously de-skinned new potatoes without the remotest flake of skin, dressed with a classic vinaigrette and some spanking fresh parsley. fields.headline: Race victims await their fate
fields.standfirst:
The Gypsies were forgotten victims of the Holocaust. Now Britain is deciding the future of Roma asylum seekers fleeing a new racism. Jay Rayner reports

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Maria Danielova lived to see the worst of the twentieth century. During the Second World War, along with 6,500 other Roma Gypsies from what is now the Czech Republic, Maria was deported to a Nazi concentration camp, in her case Auschwitz. Like nine out of 10 Czech Roma, her mother, father and sister died in the gas chambers. Maria was one of only 600 to survive.
fields.body:
Maria Danielova lived to see the worst of the twentieth century. During the Second World War, along with 6,500 other Roma Gypsies from what is now the Czech Republic, Maria was deported to a Nazi concentration camp, in her case Auschwitz. Like nine out of 10 Czech Roma, her mother, father and sister died in the gas chambers. Maria was one of only 600 to survive.

Communism kept a tight social lid on anti-Roma racism after the war but now the evils that Maria experienced have caught up with the next generation. Her son, Milan, was beaten up by police during an anti-racist demonstration. Her grandson, also called Milan, was attacked by 'skinheads' with baseball bats. They shattered his knee, broke his hand and fractured his skull. Her nephew was assaulted.

'My grandmother saw too many children die in the camps,' says Milan Jnr, now in north London with his family waiting to hear whether their application for asylum is accepted by Britain. 'Now she saw all of us being beaten up too. For my grandmother history was repeating itself.'

Maria died in 1995. Two years later her family fled the Czech Republic to escape the rising tide of anti-Roma violence which they, and many others, assert is allowed to continue by state authorities - local police, town councils, mayors - who are as racist as the thugs. 'Under Communism it was safe, because you could go to the police,' says Milan. 'Now most of the skinheads are policeman. Gypsies don't have any rights.'

The story of Maria and her family illustrates the depth of suffering of a people who have fought for generations for recognition of their plight. The violence they have experienced is horribly commonplace, yet that Maria had children at all is unusual. 'Of the few Czech Roma who survived the Holocaust a large proportion had either been surgically sterilised while in the camps or rendered infertile by their treatment,' says Dr Donald Kennrick, one of the few academics to have carried out research on the Nazi genocide of gypsies.

Since the death of the Eastern bloc in the Nineties there have been countless incidents of Roma being murdered or assaulted, of their homes being firebombed and their businesses being destroyed. If the victims were the families of Jewish survivors of the Holocaust it is unimaginable their persecution would not be met by international condemnation. But, because they are Roma and have been less than successful in publicising their own cause, it has slipped by widely unremarked.

The problems faced by the Roma of central and eastern Europe do not appear to trouble Britain. Since the autumn of 1997, when there was a sudden increase in the number of Roma from the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Romania claiming asylum in Britain, the Home Office has maintained a policy of refusing almost 100 per cent of claims at point of application.

By contrast, Canada has accepted more than 85 per cent of similar claims. 'It's clear from examination of the claims that the overwhelming majority are purely economic migrants,' the Home Office said last week; it's a position that has done little to discourage racist press comment with which some tabloids and local newspapers have greeted the Roma's arrival in the UK.

The Home Office may not be able to sustain opposition to Roma asylum-seekers for long. On Thursday the House of Lords will give its judgment in the case of Milan Horvath, a Slovak Roma who entered the UK with his wife and child in October 1997.

He claimed asylum on the grounds that he had a well-founded fear of persecution. In 1985 his father was murdered by racist thugs, a killing police failed to investigate. His brother was beaten up by a group using chains and baseball bats, and other Roma neighbours were killed. His home was set on fire and ransacked so many times that he and his family took refuge in a makeshift dugout in the back garden. The police, says Horvath, did nothing.

Home Secretary Jack Straw has argued that the authorities in countries like the Czech Republic and Slovakia have the powers to investigate racist attack and that therefore Roma cannot claim a well-founded fear of persecution as understood by the 1951 International Convention on Refugees, because the racism is not state-sponsored.

Horvath's legal team is arguing that, whatever the theoretical position, in practice the authorities in Slovakia are so racist that they will not act, leaving their client in fear of his life. The House of Lords is being asked to decide what level of police inaction amounts to the state condoning racist violence. Should it find in Horvath's favour, the ruling will apply to other countries.

In the early stages of Horvath's case the Home Secretary refused to accept his account of his family's suffering. Straw said it was unbelievable his family had been attacked so often. Since then, as the case graduated from the asylum tribunals to the court system, his account has been taken as fact. Even so, says Peter Jorrow of the Refugee Legal Council, which has represented Horvath, the Home Office has little time for the details.

'They've been ignoring the evidence,' Jorrow says. 'We put in lots of evidence on the plight of the Roma, from the US State Department and the UNHCR [the United Nations' refugee agency]. All they put in was a letter from the Slovak ambassador. The Home Office refuses to engage with the issue on an evidential basis. All they say is, in our view it doesn't amount to persecution.'

Milan Daniel will be interested in the outcome of Horvath's case. 'The British government say the Czech Republic is a safe country and this is why we must go back,' he says. 'They are very, very wrong. I have to thank the British government for all they have given us, but they mustn't send us back. We have nothing to go back to.'

The Bock family, now living in a council flat in Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, will be watching the Horvath case closely. Villem Bock' s father, Frantisek, spent years as a child in Auschwitz. He was one of only three children of 11 to survive. 'All the time my father would talk about the camp,' Villem, 48, says. 'He told me how he saw his parents being taken to the gas chambers. That was the last he saw of them.'

Sixty years later, Villem also found himself detained in a camp, this time British. When he, his wife Valeria and their 10-year-old daughter Marie arrived at Stansted Airport on 1 March, Villem was interviewed for three days before being detained at Tinsley House, near Gatwick.

Back in the Czech Republic, Valeria's brother, Daniel, had been murdered by racists. Valeria and Villem had, in turn, been forced out of their jobs and then from their homes. 'They were beating people up in the streets,' Valeria says. 'They burned down Roma houses. They did everything they could to make life harder. We moved to a new town and the people told us we had to leave.' So they did. 'I couldn't help but be worried for my children.'

Their journey took them to Canada, which they left when Villem's mother, still in the Czech Republic, was diagnosed with cancer. They left two teenage daughters behind, who now have refugee status in Canada. As soon as they arrived back in the Czech Republic they realised conditions were no better. They got out, first to Norway and then to the Netherlands, each country refusing their application. Villem was released from Tinsley House, on payment of a surety by a supporter of the Roma cause. All the family care about now is that they are not returned to the Czech Republic. 'The Roma are still being attacked,' Villem says. 'It feels as if it will soon be the same as when Hitler was in power. The skinhead movement is too strong.

'Everybody has forgotten about the Roma. The concentration camps were for the Jews and the Gypsies but nobody remembers the Gypsies.' There are no museums to the Gypsy dead of the Holocaust, he says. At Lety, in the Czech Republic, a concentration camp for Gypsies was established during the Second World War. There are no memorials there of the sort established at Auschwitz or Dachau. The land is now a pig farm. 'They did it because they think of us as pigs.'

For the Bock family and the Daniel family the Holocaust is not part of a history that must be remembered for the sake of remembrance. It is part of their present, the brutality of their family's past echoing down the years.

The judges in the Lords might like to listen to those echoes as they reach their judgment this week.

fields.headline: Welcome to the pleasure dome
fields.standfirst: The literary editor  recommends books for the summer, from the Bard to Monroe  and from Seth to pulp fiction...
fields.trailText: The literary editor recommends books for the summer, from the Bard to Monroe and from Seth to pulp fiction...
fields.body:
History

Caryl Phillips: The Atlantic Sound (Faber) Powerful re-examination of the slave trade and its terrible legacy.

David Starkey: Elizabeth (Chatto) The book of the television series, but superior to your average tie-in.

Frank Kermode: Shakespeare's Language (Penguin Press) A great literary critic examines the playwright's canon and concludes that after Hamlet his work reached new heights of innovation and originality. A deft counterblast to some younger critics.

Nick Cohen: Cruel Britannia (Verso) Swiftian evisceration of New Labour by one of our last radical journalists.

Rupert Christiansen: The Visitors (Chatto) A fascinating account, casting interesting new light on English philistinism, of the great European artists, for example Wagner, who came to Victorian Britain in search of new audiences.

Travel

Tony Hawks: Playing the Moldovans at Tennis (Ebury Press) A drunken bet takes our hero to eastern Europe and, yes, he does play tennis with the Moldovan football squad. This quirky and entertaining travelogue was the much-fancied runner-up for the Samuel Johnson Prize.

Jan Morris: Venice (Faber) Still essential, even if you're nowhere near St Mark's Square.The gold standard in post-war travel writing.

Memoir

William Goldman: Which Lie Did I Tell? (Bloomsbury) The veteran screenwriter (Butch Cassidy , The Princess Bride etc) dishes the dirt on the dream factory. The perfect book for a long flight, and best read in conjuction with Goldman's masterpiece Adventures in the Screen Trade .

Dave Eggers: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador) A cult bestseller in America, this coming-of-age anti-memoir is probably one of the most important literary debuts of recent years.

Martin Amis: Experience (Cape) You've read the extracts, and scanned the interviews. The real thing is richer, deeper and more finely wrought than anything he's done before.

Shirley Hazzard: Greene on Capri (Little, Brown) An American novelist, who used to meet Graham Greene at his Italian retreat during the summer holidays, paints a surprisingly touching portrait. Essential reading for the fans.

Colin Clark: My Week With Marilyn (HarperCollins) A footnote in the life of a great star becomes an engaging slice of memoir in the life of Alan Clark's younger brother.

Thriller

Nicci French: Beneath the Skin (Michael Joseph) The psychology of the stalker with a twist in the tail.

Bernard Cornwell: Sharpe's Trafalgar (HarperCollins) Nautical derring-do in the Napoleonic wars. One of the best in the bestselling Sharpe sequence. More C.S. Forester than Patrick O'Brien.

Chris Paling: Newton's Swing (Cape) A gripping account of a murder and its aftermath. Paling is a name to watch.

Crime

Walter Mosley: Walkin' The Dog (Serpent's Tail) Mosley is, of course, President Clinton's favourite writer.This second collection of Socrates Fortlow stories confirms his gift for hard-boiled, but thoughtful fiction.

Peter Robinson: In a Dry Season (Macmillan) Chief Inspector Banks investigates the macabre secrets of a submerged village.

Reginald Hill: Arms and the Women (HarperCollins) Leftie campaigner leads Dalziel and Pascoe into a tangle with Irish republicans and Colombian drug barons.

Biography

Richard Holmes: Sidetracks (HarperCollins) Romantic biographer reveals the secrets of his trade. Picked-up pieces from the acclaimed author of Shelley and Coleridge .

Jean-Luc Tadié: Proust (Viking) Among many new biographical treatments, this is the last word. Longer than Edmund White's pocket masterpiece (Weidenfeld), but probably not as good on gay Paris.

Andrew Motion: Wainewright the Poisoner (Faber) The poet laureate explores the underside of the Romantic movement .

Marion Meade: The Unruly Life of Woody Allen (Serpent's Tail) A scissors-and-paste biography, with plenty of gossip.

Christopher Frayling/Sergio Leone: Something To Do With Death (Faber) Behind-the-scenes at the making of spaghetti westerns .

Science

Malcolm Gladwell: The Tipping Point (Little, Brown) Little things make a big difference - an entertaining look at the mechanics of consumerism by smart New Yorker journalist with a sharp eye for a trend.

Stephen Jay Gould: The Lying Stones of Marrakech (Cape). The seasoned scientific polemicist bids farewell.

Steven M. Wise: Rattling the Cage - Toward Legal Rights for Animals (Profile) Perfect for annoying your country friends, and well-written too.

Fiction

Amit Chaudhuri: A New World (Picador)A master miniaturist at his finest to date: the heir to R.K. Narayan.

Timothy Findlay: Pilgrim (Faber) An enthralling historical tale of a man who has lived forever by Canada's greatest living writer.

Josie Barnard: The Pleasure Dome (Virago) Betty Trask award-winner's second novel. Belle, a bisexual stripper, is working at Xanadu to shock her mother. Tough, funny, and very sharp-eyed on the seedy underworld of contemporary London. Barnard is one to watch.

Will Self: How the Dead Live (Bloomsbury) An audacious new novel from the enfant terrible of contemporary English fiction. Lily Bloom lies dying and these are her morphine dreams.

A.S. Byatt: The Biographer's Tale (Chatto) Complex and typically subtle novel from the author of Possession .

Zadie Smith: White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton) The outstanding debut of the new millennium. Inexplicably passed over for the Orange Prize, this must be a very hot tip for the autumn prize season.

Jonathan Keates: Smile, Please (Chatto) Delightful collection of fairly gay stories by a seasoned novelist.

John Lanchester: Mr Phillips (Faber) A day in the life of an ordinary man. Mesmerising.

Jane Smiley: Horse Heaven (Faber) Jilly Cooper meets an American Creative Writing seminar.

William Maxwell: The Chateau (Harvill) Landmark novel by a truly great American writer.

Philip Roth: The Human Stain (Cape) Since American Pastoral , Roth has simply got better and better. A must.

John Updike: Gertrude and Claudius (Hamish Hamilton) A crafty exploration of the Hamlet story, based on legends.

Nicola Barker: Five Miles From Outer Hope (Faber) Dark-horse winner of the acclaimed Impac Prize.

Michael Arditti: Easter (Arcadia) A latterday Passion story of great distinction.

Alexandar Hemon: The Question of Bruno (Picador) Short stories inspired by the break-up of Yugoslavia. Hemon has been compared to Kundera and Nabokov, but he is triumphantly his own man.

Paperback fiction

Tiffanie Darke: Marrow (Pocket) Bright new arrival in the field of pulp fiction.

P.G. Wodehouse: Right Ho, Jeeves (Penguin) Twenty-five years after his death, this great comic writer is delighting new fans. Everyman and Penguin are committed to reissuing most of his backlist.

Helen Fielding: Bridget Jones - The Edge of Reason (Picador) A second helping of thirtysomething angst. Bridget wins love and loses it, natch. So she ought to read, but probably never will...

Kazuo Ishiguro: When We Were Orphans (Faber) A celebrated detective searches for the truth about his childhood in war-torn Shanghai. A complex and subtle new novel by the author of The Remains of the Day .

Jilly Cooper: Score! (Corgi) High jinks in the orchestra pit from the queen of her genre.

Edna O'Brien: Wild Decembers (Phoenix) The final volume in a trilogy about contemporary Ireland. O'Brien at her passionate best.

Damian Lanigan: Stretch, 29 (HarperCollins) An inventive, funny debut about the adventures of a serial underachiever approaching middle youth.

Anita Desai: Fasting, Feasting (Vintage) India and New England collide in this deft Booker Prize runner-up, the book that some of last year's judges were eager to support.

Popular fiction

Sally Brampton: Love, Always (Heinemann) The pain of long-term commitment by an under-appreciated novelist. Another one to watch.

Joanna Trollope: Marrying The Mistress (Bloomsbury) The queen of the home counties fiction ventures into adultery.

Amy Jenkins: Honeymoon (Headline) The most hyped novel of the season.

Joe Klein: The Running Mate (Chatto) More political intrigue from the author of Primary Colors . Essential reading for America junkies.

Thomas Harris: Hannibal (Heinemann) The return of the celebrated serial killer is outstandingly grotesque.

Robert Harris: Archangel (Arrow) The quest for Stalin's Little Black Book. Intensely readable.

Vikram Seth: An Equal Music (Phoenix) Harmonies and discords in the lives of three musicians.

Marika Cobbold : Frozen Music (Phoenix) A heartrending romance between an English hackette and crusty Swedish architect. No one does it better than Cobbold.

Sport

Andrew Anthony: On Penalties (Yellow Jersey Press) The story of the penalty kick, from its Irish beginnings to Euro 2000. A tour de force of narrative journalism and essential reading in Holland.

John Duncan: In the Red Corner: A Journey Into Cuban Boxing (Yellow Jersey Press) A Bacardi-fuelled romp through the byways of Havana.

fields.headline: Dreaming spires
fields.standfirst: Towering delphiniums herald high summer, childhood memories and a slap-up meal for slugs
fields.trailText: Towering delphiniums herald high summer, childhood memories and a slap-up meal for slugs.
fields.body:
Now here's a funny thing. We breed slugs and snails in this garden at the rate that Bill Gates gains interest on his interest. This is where slugs come on sabbatical as a reward for exceptional service. It is a slug health farm. And everyone knows that slugs and snails regard a delphinium as a delicacy beyond all others. In previous years, our attempts at delphinium growing have foundered on the smacking of slug lips. Yet this year we have perfect delphiniums - uneaten towers of shimmering azure blue, violet and purple. Monkland church spire can only echo them hazily across the fields beyond the river.

In the chalky soil of North Hampshire where I grew up, delphiniums marked hot summer days like pillars of flowering righteousness - as reliably present in the summer herbaceous border as church was on Sundays. I would return from school in early July to find them there unheralded and confident on a summer's day.

The memory of this makes me very sad. The thing I resent and regret most about being sent away to boarding school at seven was that the seasons of my subsequent childhood were lost. You'd say goodbye to home in mid-spring and return in high summer with all the shifting movement and subtlety of growing things discarded. May and June were glimpsed as though from a train, beyond all reach save memory. I cannot remember any flowers at school. Just-mown grass, the smell of linseed oil and the horrible rhododendrons. You can take the child away from home but you cannot take the home from inside the child. You learn to hold it inside and, long past the usefulness of that particular trick, it hangs on there: gardens, fields and whole parishes tucked away as a survival kit.

Years later, in the mid-80s, Sarah and I are driving down to Kent at about this time of year. We go round a corner and the barley, still green, suddenly billows and ripples like silk on the downland. And I feel the same acute pang of homesickness as I did as a child, allowed out for a day, seeing the beech tree fill with leaf and the hedges smoky with cow parsley. Spring drifting into summer without me. It was then that I knew London was a place of exile, and probably the moment I mentally pulled out of our business and started screwing up that patch of our lives.

So now we have delphiniums of our own, in our own grown-up lives, growing here in Herefordshire, a hundred miles from Hampshire and so many miles of water under the bridge. We haven't done anything particularly out of the ordinary this year that has made the flowers grow so tall and unpalatable to the slugs and snails. I am talking of Delphinium elatum hybrids, which are the most common and easiest to grow. We have two types, 'Black Knight', which is a dark indigo with a black eye and 'King Arthur' - inky blue with a white eye.

White is officially banned from the Jewel garden, but keeps sneaking in under some guise or other, and it passes the colour police in this instance because the combined effect is not white and blue but a violet made softer and paler. We bought them as young plants and planted them in last April. They did nothing to write home about last summer and we did not protect them in any way over winter, although conventional wisdom advises putting a mulch of grit over the crowns in winter to protect them from slugs.

We have D 'Faust' on order - I saw it at Chelsea and loved its intensity of dark purple - although I see that it is described in the RHS Encyclopedia of Garden Plants as being 'deep cornflower-blue... overlaid with purple, and with indigo eyes'. Whatever. The effect combines to a shimmering Rothko-like intensity of purple. The hybrids come in colours ranging from deep purple to white, via blue, mauve and pink. But I want my delphiniums to be essentially blue. This partly to reclaim lost emotional territory, but also because blues don't come cheap in the garden and should be encouraged and nurtured at every opportunity. Delphiniums don't just turn out willingly in indigo, navy, cobalt, aquamarine and icy sapphire, but they do so with the volume turned up. They make a big blue sound and, despite my own maudlin memories and the connotation of the blues, it is a joyous noise. A blue party.

Of the D elatum hybrids, the 'King Arthur' group, 'Nimrod', 'Nobility' and the 'Black Knight' group all give you rich, dark blues. 'Fenella', 'Blue Tit' and 'Blue Nile' are lighter, clearer tones. D grandiflorum has a solitary flower of a staggeringly intense blue. I say that, I admit, only on the evidence of a photograph in Nori and Sandra Pope's book Colour by Design (£25, Conran Octopus) as I have never grown it myself. They class it as a perennial, though it is normally treated as an annual. It is much smaller than a 'normal' delphinium, but they flower for longer, keeping going all summer if they are kept cut.

You can get small delphinium hybrids with stumpy stems, but what is the point? Delphiniums take up their space in the air and even the smallest garden can be made to seem bigger by good strong vertical growth. Of course, a flower spike 6ft tall or more needs staking.

If you find that slugs make it hardly worth the bother of persevering with delphiniums, then their cousin the monkshood - or aconitum - is the nearest thing to creating that massed, blue/violet effect. Slugs steer well clear of aconitums and their poison. But inedibility aside, they are a good, if less intense, substitute for delphiniums. We have Aconitum napellus 'Sparks Variety', which is a deep violet, flowering now and will last for most of the summer. A 'Newry Blue' is on order, and has lighter, bluer flowers. Christopher Lloyd, in Lloyd's Garden Flowers (£30, Cassell) says magisterially of A napellus: 'It need not detain us.' I was so struck by the dismissiveness of this that I have just nipped outside to check on its detainability. Right about a lot of things, he's wrong about this one. It fails any specimen-plant test, but is invaluable in a border, guaranteeing an uneaten intensity of blue and violet that is otherwise so rare. But, I concede, it ain't no delphinium.

A carmichaelii sounds good, as do A carmichaelii 'Barker's Variety' and the darker blue 'Kelmscott'. Whatever the variety of carmichaelii, they flower late in summer, coinciding, if you are lucky, with the second flush of delphiniums. Unless, of course, you have been dispatched to boarding school, in which case you will miss everything. Very much.

fields.headline: On the outside, looking in
fields.standfirst:
As Germany and France move closer together, with the support of their voters, Britain is in danger of being left in the EU's slow lane. Jason Burke in Paris, Kamal Ahmed in London and Denis Staunton in Berlin assess the significance of the meeting between Blair and Schröder last week and of France's rekindled love for Germany

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: As Germany and France move closer together, with the support of their voters, Britain is in danger of being left in the EU's slow lane. Jason Burke in Paris,  Kamal Ahmed in London and  Denis Staunton in Berlin assess the significance of the meeting between Blair and Schröder last week and of France's rekindled love for Germany
fields.byline: Jason Burke in Paris,  Kamal Ahmed in London and  Denis Staunton in Berlin
fields.body:
Tony Blair's dinner with German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder near Berlin's Glienecke Bridge last Thursday lasted longer than expected. The two leaders discussed the future of Europe over stuffed turbot and rack of lamb, washed down with a 1997 Baden Riesling and a mellow Spätburgunder from the same year.

The discussion, after quips from Blair about how England and Germany should forge an alliance in 2004 to make sure that France don't win the next European Championship, quickly turned to the speech last Tuesday by the French President, Jacques Chirac.

When Chirac got up to speak in the Reichstag he knew that what he was about to say would toss the finely balanced European debate into stormy waters. France and Germany were still the leading players, he made clear, and if other nations (namely Britain) didn't want to forge ahead with plans for closer integration, then they would be left in the slow lane.

Chirac had opened the way to a two-speed Europe - with Paris and Berlin in a sleek Mercedes on the highway to integration while Britain phut-phuts along in an easily overtaken old Morris Minor. This is supposed to be the unspoken British worry. And Chirac had just spoken about it.

Foreign Secretary Robin Cook was briefed on Chirac's idea to form a 'pioneer group' of countries which would form a continental power base. His response was rapid: 'It is important that we have a Europe of equal member states, in which all states have the same rights and all states participate fully in the projects of the EU.'

Talk of a two-speed Europe sends a shiver down the spine of the Government. They don't mind talking about 'flexibility' with some states having different arrangements on defence or border controls. But two-speed? That is not part of Blair's vision.

So, what is going on? Was Chirac rubbing Blair's nose in it? Were he and Schröder signalling that Britain had better get on board with the euro or suffer the consequences? Would Blair find himself locked out of the key European decision-making bodies? No, it is all far more complicated than that.

To understand Chirac's speech you need to understand the byzantine ways of French politics. Observers point out that the centre-right Gaullist President has previously been relatively cautious on Europe. Last week's conversion, the cynics say, was a cleverly judged manoeuvre to boost the President's popularity in France and his profile at home and abroad.

In 2002 France goes to the polls to choose the next President and elect a new government. Currently Lionel Jospin, an old-style Socialist, is Prime Minister and governs with the help of the Communists and the Greens. But he has presidential ambitions. Previously Jospin and Chirac have set aside their differences in the interests of smooth government. Now, 18 months before the elections, it seems that battle has commenced.

Key to the campaign, and to last week's speech, are the group of Chirac advisers dubbed la douzaine europhile. They include bureaucrats, businessmen and politicians. All are ferociously capable. All have been close to Chirac for years. They are also very keen to be still walking past the Elysée Palace's liveried footmen and through its corridors lined with Gobelin tapestries in several years time.

They include a former Prime Minister, Alain Juppé, at least two former Ministers and, most interesting of all, Jérme Monod, a heavy-set 69-year-old bureaucrat turned businessman, a Commander of the Légion d'Honneur and a key Chirac aide for nearly 30 years.

Monod's role is vital. Over the past few months the staterooms of the Elysée Palace have seen a fierce debate between aides who wanted Chirac to make an impact with his Reichstag speech, those who wanted to wait and those who opposed any kind of major statement on Europe. Monod - who has always favoured a strong French role at the heart of an increasingly unified Europe - is thought to have been essential in convincing the President that the time was right for a major pronouncement.

Though the decision on the speech was taken several weeks ago, spectacular confirmation of the political acumen of the President and his closest advisers came last week. Last Monday the newspaper Libération published a poll which showed that 59 per cent of the French now describe themselves as 'enthusiastic' or 'favourable' to the European project. An amazing 70 per cent felt political and economic unification should be accelerated.

Chirac's words caught the public mood perfectly. He spoke in relatively vague, visionary terms, but maintained a stress on the importance of the nation state. He also outmanoeuvred Jospin, who was reduced to making churlish comments about how the President's position did not reflect current government policy. His remarks were barely reported.

Somehow Chirac has sensed a seismic shift in public opinion. The significance of the change the Libération poll reveals is difficult to underestimate. Just three years ago polls showed the nation split equally been sceptics and euro-enthusiasts.

In many ways the Germans stole the initiative when Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer made his controversial speech in May, saying that a federal Europe should be the EU's endgame.

Chirac nicely stole it back. 'We know it is going to happen and we need to be a major player,' said one French journalist last week. 'We also need to keep up with the Germans if we are going to keep them in check. As for the British, it is a bit like your style of football. You are looking a little dated and a little marginalised to the average Frenchman these days. If we bother looking at all.'

In France the consensus is now clear. The prospect of greater integration provokes little controversy. In fact it is seen, if anything, as a bulwark against the spread of 'McDonald's culture' and the 'Americanisation of the world'.

Yesterday the French assumed the rotating presidency of the European Union and the government's avowed intention of overseeing a steady overhaul of the EU to ready it for further expansion has the genuine support of the electorate. The French national mint has already stopped printing francs in readiness for the full introduction of the euro in 2002. There has been no word of protest. A few lone voices - some from Chirac's own Gaullist party - carped at the President's Reichstag speech. Right-wing politicians spoke of 'accelerating a fatal process for France and the other nations of Europe'. Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the extremist Front National, said the President's proposals were 'adventurist and anti-democratic'.

But in the cafés of Paris last week there was little support for his views. In the Brasserie de la Bourse last Thursday the clientèle packed the terrace to watch Holland play Italy in the Euro 2000 semi-final. The entirely French crowd was split three ways: for the Dutch, for the Italians and for both. 'We are all Europeans now,' explained the patron as he served another beer.

Just as the French debate on Europe is archly political, so it is in Britain. Every statement is pored over for any sign that Britain is becoming more euro-sceptic or euro-positive. Last Tuesday there appeared to be a significant shift. Helen Liddell, the Trade Minister, was reported as saying in an interview with Thomas Wendell, economics editor of the Berliner Zeitung , that the pound could be scrapped 'faster than we all expect it'.

The headlines said it all - Liddell breaks ranks to push for faster integration. Michael Portillo, the Shadow Chancellor, called the comments explosive. The next day government officials quickly claimed that Liddell had been mistranslated. But the release of the transcript only served to muddy the waters further: 'I can't say how long it will take to ensure that Britain meets the five economic tests, but we certainly envisage a very early referendum.' The row reveals the difficulty the Government has maintaining a united front in the face of a sceptical press.

If Liddell had been in Britain last week, she would have been ordered to the Foreign Office for a monthly briefing on the Government's 'core script' on Europe. Here, in the map room, Keith Vaz, the Minister for Europe, explains to junior Ministers the exact line to take in all interviews.

Last week Ed Balls, Gordon Brown's special adviser, was invited to the meeting to lay down the Treasury law. In the room with him and Vaz were Ministers Barbara Roche, Tessa Jowell, George Foulkes and Joyce Quinn. Balls explained the five economic tests and made it clear there must be absolutely no deviation from the 'prepare and decide' line. 'And Liddell was messing about in Germany,' one government source snorted. 'It would have been better if she was there listening.'

This week the European debate will rage on. Robin Cook is making a speech before the pro-European Trade Unionists for Europe. Vaz and European Commissioner Chris Patten are speaking at a conference looking at bringing the Balkans closer to the EU. The Government is very comfortable with such talk of enlargement.

And while all the meetings continue, the big three lions - Britain, Germany and France - will circle one another. It's all about who, exactly, is leading the European debate. Schröder, in fact, has a warmer personal relationship with Blair than with any other European leader. But there is little left of the political alliance between the two centre-left leaders that once appeared to threaten the dominance of the Franco-German relationship within the EU.

At the dinner last week Schröder spoke just once about a triangle of Berlin, Paris and London leading Europe. 'The triangle is not going to happen and, whether we like it or not, the Franco-German axis remains the most important,' said one German official.

But although there are tensions, Germany and Britain are still close. German officials are impressed by the way Blair has formed alliances with EU member states on individual issues, abandoning the go-it-alone policy favoured by Thatcher and Major.

'It was always 14-to-one in the past and nobody wanted to side with Britain. Blair's Government has been much more intelligent and flexible in finding allies,' said one German diplomat.

Now that Blair has signalled that he will not attempt to block the Franco-German proposal for 'enhanced co-operation', he can work with like-minded leaders such as Spain's Pedro Aznar, Austria's Wolfgang Schüssel and Ireland's Bertie Ahern to place conditions on such co-operation.

The euro remains the ultimate test of Britain's commitment to Europe. Schröder has given up waiting for Blair to make a decisive move and German officials say that, until he does so, Britain will remain firmly in the slow lane of European integration.

'He's much better than his predecessors and the atmosphere is completely different. But as long as you stay outside the euro, nobody will listen too closely to what Britain has to say about Europe,' said one senior official. webTitle: Don't let UK spoil the euro show Euroland leaves UK to its angst agonising

fields.headline: Don't let UK spoil the euro show Euroland leaves UK to its angst agonising
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour Party is just as obsessed with the pound's ill-fated adventures within the European Exchange Rate Mechanism as the Conservatives were and are. It is noteworthy that, when he is pressed on the need to be 'more positive' about the euro, the Prime Minister reminds the over-enthusiastic about the ERM episode.
fields.body:
The Labour Party is just as obsessed with the pound's ill-fated adventures within the European Exchange Rate Mechanism as the Conservatives were and are. It is noteworthy that, when he is pressed on the need to be 'more positive' about the euro, the Prime Minister reminds the over-enthusiastic about the ERM episode.

And so he should. The economic history of this country during the past 75 years has been characterised by long periods of overvaluation of the exchange rate, from the return to the Gold Standard in 1925 onwards. Many reputable economists, such as Peter Kenen of Princeton University, are arguing that the elimination of the pound's volatility (at least vis-à-vis European currencies) weighs heavily on the pro side of the pound's entry to the single currency. Nevertheless, the rate at which it enters is crucial to the long-term viability of the British economy, given its historical propensity towards relatively high wage inflation and relatively low productivity. The management of Nissan will endorse the point about the rate.

On the very day last week that President Jacques Chirac was setting the cat among the Trafalgar Square pigeons with his vision of a 'pioneer group' of European countries pressing ahead with further integration, the former President of the Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, made some interesting observations on Britain and Europe at a Hawk Point gathering.

Pohl recalled the sensitive matter of Britain's ERM experience somewhat differently from the account in John Major's memoirs. Major writes of the decision to enter in October 1990: 'I phoned a delighted Robin Leigh-Pemberton [Governor of the Bank of England] and Karl Otto Pohl, who congratulated me on a "brave and courageous decision". He was very supportive, and made no adverse comments about the rate at which we intended to enter.'

Pohl's version is that Major said: 'Good news, Karl Otto, we're coming in.' And Pohl replied: 'At what rate?' When Major said DM2.95, and Pohl told him 'you can't do that', Major said: 'But she [Mrs Thatcher] has decided.'

The former Bundesbank President, who is an informal adviser to Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, thought the rate was too high then, and says that if we joined the euro: 'There would have to be long discussions to decide the right rate... At its current rate the pound is clearly overvalued... It will come down to more realistic levels.'

Ironically, Pohl wonders whether Britain might not have been better off if it had, like Denmark, pegged its currency to the euro when the single currency began.

While he was not notably enthusiastic about the setting-up of the euro, Pohl believes the elimination of exchange-rate volatility and risk within the eurozone has had remarkable benefits. But he warns that higher wage rates in some countries could be 'dynamite for monetary union', via losses of competitiveness and higher unem ployment. These have been concerns of Eddie George and some of his colleagues at the Bank of England.

Pohl thinks that for now the consequences of, for example, higher wage inflation in Italy are being mitigated by the fact that such countries had a certain leeway because Germany itself joined the euro at an overvalued rate.

In theory, sectoral or regional decline caused by losses of competitiveness can be mitigated by transfers of funds from Brussels, but this is generally seen as unthinkable in view of the budgetary strains of EU enlargement.

Given that, despite all the money supply mumbo-jumbo, inflation is basically caused by cost pressures, the combination of the euro and the single market is likely to put heavy pressure on the European wage bargaining process. This is one reason why the Treasury stresses the need for Britain to control its real exchange rate: even nominal exchange rate stability has, in the past, been accompanied by too high a 'real' exchange rate, because of upward pressures on UK costs.

But while we continue to agonise about the euro, the continental debate has moved on. This is not, I think, entirely out of a desire to embarrass Britain. The push for closer integration is partly a consequence of concern on the part of passionate 'Europeans' that there is an absence of the 'great men' who propelled the EU forward in the past, and a wish for the forces of darkness to be resisted. Because of its nervousness about closer EU integration, Britain, in the run-up to Maastricht, championed 'enlargement', rather than 'deepening', of the EU,

Interestingly, it is the very prospect of enlargement that seems to be prompting the inner core of the EU to deepen further. Political vision has been dimming in the face of the prospective cost of, for example, agricultural deals with east European countries; and there is alarm about the thought of too much migration from there. Behind the talk of flexibility of decision-making in an enlarged EU (certainly needed) there are basic fears about not wanting to give away too much of the cake.

Meanwhile, as turf wars develop over the financial regulation of Europe, there is Britain (in the EU but outside the euro) and there is Switzerland (outside both).

Britain's difficulties, and French pretensions to run the eurozone, ought not to be allowed to ruin the show.

fields.headline: My night with Diego
fields.standfirst: Mark Brealey went to Havana in search of sun and cerveza. So how come, after stumbling into him, he ended up having dinner with Diego Maradona?
fields.trailText: Mark Brealey went to Havana in search of sun and cerveza. So how come, after stumbling into him, he ended up having dinner with Diego Maradona?
fields.body:
We arrived at the white-painted detached house to find it hidden from the road by a swathe of palm trees. The night air was warm and sticky, and on opening the car door the first thing we heard was loud, bellowing laughter, as if from an over-excited boy.

In the garden sat a group of friends and family drinking wine, beer and mineral water, and eating birthday cake. The faces were smiling and animated, and all were indistinct, except one. The thick dark hair, olive skin, intense eyes and joyous smile. Then there was that boyish laugh again. I knew him instantly.

Sitting there, dressed only in a pair of black Versace swimming trunks and clutching a fat Cuban cigar, was Diego Maradona. As we made our way towards the group he looked up.

'Andres!' he exclaimed on greeting my friend.

Then, with equal vigour, he welcomed me with an illuminated face and outstretched hand. Quickly I took it, unable to avoid the irony of the situation: I was shaking the Hand of God.

Only an hour earlier such an extraordinary meeting had seemed highly unlikely. My holiday in Cuba was coming to an end. I had been staying with my friend Andy Cawthorne in Havana - 10 years ago we trained together: now while I work for BBC Radio Leeds, Andy is Reuters' man in Havana - and soon after I arrived Andy told me that he had met Maradona several times since the Argentine arrived on the Caribbean island in January at the invitation of the Cuban leader Fidel Castro.

Andy added there was a chance that I, too, might meet Maradona, but then came the news that he had left the island on the very day of my arrival, and would be away for several days in Germany, playing in a testimonial match for Lothar Matthäus.

I shrugged off my disappointment and had almost forgotten about it until one night, two days before I was to return to England, the phone rang at Andy's apartment. We'd just finished dinner and I was slumbering in a hammock when Andy shouted, 'He's back!'

The call was from Alfredo, an Argentine cameraman who worked with Andy and who had become one of Maradona's best friends in Cuba. Alfredo had travelled with Maradona to Germany, but had returned home ahead of him. Now, Maradona was back in Cuba and had gone straight from the plane to Alfredo's house where they were having a party to celebrate the 12th birthday of Alfredo's son Santiago.

As we drove along Havana's bumpy, broken streets I have to confess that that for a moment I wanted to turn back. We carried on, and the moment we shook hands I knew we had made the right decision. Despite the 10-hour flight Maradona's energy and charisma in the flesh were remarkable. Of course the figure I was now looking at was very different to the footballer I remember. His bare torso was bloated and he looked at least a couple of stone overweight. At 39 the man is still unmistakable, but the mistakes of the man have left their mark.

The garden was perfect for such a gathering. A large patio area was filled with a few tables and chairs, and a big brick-built barbecue glowed and gave out delicious smells.The dozen or so of us included Andy's wife Euridice, Alfredo and his wife Vicki, and the couple's young sons Santiago and Frederico. There was also Maradona's great friend and manager, the white-haired Guillermo Coppola, and a few other family and friends.

To begin with there were three or four people sitting between me and Maradona - or Diegito, as he is known to his closest friends - and I simply listened. Suddenly as we were finishing off the birthday cake, Maradona burst into song. His voice was surprisingly good. The songs were slow Argentine tangos with sad melodies, normally telling the stories of lost loves, reflecting a melancholic side to his nature. After singing three or four on his own, he enlisted one of his friends for a duet. Then, as it headed towards midnight and a few of the guests started to drift away, I seized my chance. I got up and took a seat at the round garden table, directly opposite him.

For a moment I didn't know what to say. In the end I opted for a subject I know both of us know a lot about: his brilliant goal against England in the 1986 World Cup. 'Is it,' I ask, a little hesitantly, 'the best you ever scored?'

He listened patiently, almost like a teacher to a pupil.

'Si!' he roared excitedly, and then gripped the gathering with a precise, near-photographic recital of how he took a ball from his Argentine colleagues, then danced gracefully through the English team. Amazingly he could still name the players he left in his wake.

'Butcher. Fenwick. Reid.'

I helped him with the pronunciations. Then, in perhaps the most surreal moment of the whole evening (and there were a few), he asked me where Mark Hateley was nowadays.

'I don't know,' I was forced to confess. 'The last I knew he was player-manager of Hull City, but I'm not sure now.'

Then, like two guys sitting in a pub, we started talking football. He began by going back to the 1982 World Cup, and how the German goalkeeper Harald Schumacher notoriously tackled an attacking player, leaving him injured on the ground.

'Battiston?' I said. 'It was Battiston who was hurt!'

'Muy bien! Muy bien! Muy bien!' he repeated, clearly impressed that I remembered it so well. I rose to imitate the dreadful tackle by Schumacher, and Maradona nodded encouragingly.

We talked of my home-town team, Derby County. Earlier some of the other guests had mocked when I asked if they had heard of the Rams. But Maradona simply nodded.

Had he heard of our Argentine striker, Esteban Fuertes, who'd been forced to return to Argentina because of irregularities with his passport?

'Yes, and he was a good player,' said Maradona.

'We could do with you playing for Derby,' I joked.

'I'll come and be manager!' he fired back, with a big smile.

'And I can be your assistant!' I shouted, and together we rose from our chairs and did a high five on the deal.

I asked him who would win Euro 2000. 'Holland have a great chance,' he replied, 'first because it's local for them.'

Then we debated who should host the 2006 World Cup. 'It's time for the Africans to have a World Cup, and who better than South Africa?' he said.

Who was his own footballing hero?

'George Best. He's my idol.'

As for the redevelopment of Wembley, his view was emphatic. 'Wembley is the stadium,' he said. 'I wish they could have just remodelled it, instead of destroying it.'

In the way that family snaps are passed around at parties, envelopes of photos were being circulated in our small gathering, but these were of Maradona in Germany several days earlier. 'It was fantastic, very emotional. I felt marvellous because I could run. I felt as if time had not passed. I felt fantastic with the ball at my feet. The crowd had not forgotten anything about what I used to do on the pitch.'

And he was in no doubt where the credit lay for the turnaround in his fortunes. 'When I reached Cuba my heart was at 30 per cent, not even that,' he said. 'I went to play [in Germany] with 60 per cent, almost like a normal person. For that I want to thank the Cuban doctors, Fidel, all of Cuba, for their support and respect. Of course I dedicate that game to all the Cubans. Here I have found peace, tranquility.'

(Certainly as I looked at him his time in Cuba appears to have been well spent. Yes he was still overweight, but he seemed much better than the swollen, sorry figure who arrived in the country at the start of the year. He is expected to stay on the island for several more months, his presence and slow recovery there seen as a publicity coup for Cuba's health service. And he's playing football again: not just the Matthäus testimonial - which won rave reviews - but regularly in Havana, on a concrete pitch behind the health spa where he lives.)

At one point, as if to emphasise his gratitude to his new - albeit temporary - home, he leapt up and dived into the swimming pool, splashing around chanting support for Fidel Castro, and Cuba. When he removed the towel from his shoulders, I could clearly see the tattoo of Che Guevara on his right shoulder. (On Maradona's other shoulder is another ornate tattoo, of what looked like an eagle. On each wrist he wore a Rolex.)

We talked for more than two hours, and often he would burst into laughter, wave his arms, or puff out his chest to make a point. As it became clear that it was nearly time to go, I reached for the pocket camera I'd hidden when we arrived.

Maradona, who must have been through the ritual a thousand times, was charm itself as we posed together. Then went to the car to retrieve my Derby County shirt. I'd left it there when we arrived, having no faith that I'd actually be able to persuade the great man to sign it for me.

Of course he did. Drawing his famous number 10 by the signature, he wrote:

'To Mark, Con Carino [with affection], Diego.'

Mark Hateley, 38, is currently not playing professional football. After leaving Hull City as manager he played two games for Ross County in the Scottish Division Two last September. Since leaving them he has been linked with the the manager's jobs at Raith and Portsmouth and is currently doing radio work in Scotland. This summer he is playing in the PFA Masters tournament.

webTitle: Virgin's train site loses net hallmark

fields.headline: Virgin's train site loses net hallmark
fields.trailText: Richard Branson, pioneering founder of cutting-edge businesses, was this weekend contemplating a humiliating rebuff: the official website for Virgin trains has lost its quality hallmark.
fields.byline: by Sarah Ryle, consumer affairs correspondent
fields.body:
Richard Branson, pioneering founder of cutting-edge businesses, was this weekend contemplating a humiliating rebuff: the official website for Virgin trains has lost its quality hallmark.

Thetrainline.com, a subsidiary of Virgin Rail but in the process of being demerged, is only the second trading site to be ejected from the Which? Web Trader programme. The first was Jungle.com, since reinstated. 'The main source of complaint was regarding purchase of tickets which were not received, even though customers' accounts were debited,' said Katie Hammond of the Consumers' Association, which set up the kitemark scheme to encourage more people to shop online. It sets stringent standards and monitors the 850 registered retailers.

Customers who complained to thetrainline.com told Which? the staff were unhelpful. The complaints were passed on to the retailer but another 22 similar gripes were recorded in the space of three weeks. 'We have withdrawn their membership due to the fact that unsatisfactory progress had been made to rectify the problems,' said Hammond.

Trainline.com's chief executive, Alan Meekings apologised to customers. 'Every complaint which finds its way to Which? is like a stab in the chest.' But he said they had to be set against the 50,000 transactions made each week. The crux of the problem, he said, was a failure to transfer new timetable data correctly, leading to ticket-issuing problems. This caused a log-jam in the system.

He added: 'We are demerging because we are an impartial provider of tickets for all routes sold by all operators. Our aim is to provide the best route at the cheapest price.'

He said 40 per cent of all current inquiries result in sales of Virgin tickets.

fields.headline: Hague pledges to 'save' schools
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague will trigger an angry battle over education this week by branding Britain's school system 'one of the worst in Europe' and promising to save it.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff, chief political correspondent
fields.body:
William Hague will trigger an angry battle over education this week by branding Britain's school system 'one of the worst in Europe' and promising to save it.

The Tory leader will mount an audacious raid on traditional Labour territory by pledging to make education his top priority, arguing that schools have been ruined by a 'liberal establishment'.

But Education Secretary David Blunkett will launch an aggressive pre-emptive strike the day before, dubbing him 'half-truths Hague' and demanding whether he would scrap popular Labour reforms such as the literacy and numeracy hours.

In his speech to the right-wing thinktank Politeia on Tuesday, Hague will concede there are 'individual success stories', but paint a bleak picture of the system as a whole adding: 'Parents have little choice, standards are declining, teacher morale is at an all-time low, head-teachers are powerless, discipline has broken down, waste and bureaucracy are rampant, grammar schools are victimised, the tyranny of political correctness has run riot, and the whole thing is in the grip of a liberal establishment whose theories of progressive education have, over 40 years of mismanagement and interference, brought some of our nation's schools to their knees.'

However, the Blunkett camp pointed out that for much of the 40 years during which Hague says the damage has been done, Tories were in charge.

Blunkett will pre-empt the speech by 24 hours with a direct attack on Hague, arguing his 'free schools' plan to strip powers from local education authorities risks confusion in vital services such as special-needs teaching, and accusing him of plotting to scrap reforms like the literacy hour and performance-related pay for teachers.
